text.wiki:
Yamashita Park (山下公園, Yamashita Kōen) is a public park in Naka Ward, Yokohama, Japan, famous for its waterfront views of the Port of Yokohama.


== History ==
Much of Yokohama was destroyed on September 1, 1923, by the Great Kantō earthquake. A Scotsman, Marshall Martin, advisor to Mayor Ariyoshi Chuichi, is credited with persuading the city government to use rubble from the Kannai commercial district to reclaim the former waterfront as a park.Yamashita Park was formally opened on March 15, 1930.
The park was requisitioned in 1945 during the Occupation of Japan for military housing, reverting to Japanese control in 1960.  Across the street from the park is the Hotel New Grand where General Douglas MacArthur spent his first night on his arrival in Japan on August 30, 1945.


== Park attractions ==
As well as public green space with trees, flower beds, fountains and memorials, Yamashita Park is also noted as the location of:

The Hikawa Maru, a Japanese ocean liner built in 1929 for Nippon Yūsen Kabushiki Kaisha ("NYK Line") now a museum ship.
The Port Service, an operator of seabuses, excursion and restaurant ships, operating from the park pier. Ship services include scheduled public lines as far as Yokohama Station as well as larger charter ships.
The Guardian of Water, a Donal Hord sculpture gifted by Yokohama's sister city San Diego in 1960. A replica of the sculpture located in front of the San Diego County Administration Center.
Yokohama Indian Water Fountain. Donated by the local Indian community to show its gratitude to the Japanese for aiding the Indian survivors after the 1923 Great Kantō earthquake, as well as to remember those who perished in the disaster.
Girl Scout Statue - Dedicated March 18, 1962 on the Fiftieth Anniversary of the founding of the Girl Scouts. (two of the three models for the statue are Libby Watson and Hiroko Tanaka)
Statue of the Girl with Red Shoes (Akai Kutsu)
Monument of the Children's Song "Seagull Sailor Man"
Monument of General Artemio Ricarte - Philippine General, erected in 1972

		


== References ==
text.quote: Opened in 1930, this popular seaside park features flower beds & monuments, plus a fountain.
trip: The park is at the shore and nearby the Chinatown area. Yokohama marine tower and the doll museum is at the end of the park, a historic ship also parked there.

yokohama people loves to walk YAMASHITA Park nothing special just only open sky and port view but sky is blue and beautiful sun rise can been seen also location is almost center of all attractive place of Yokohama

Beautiful well kept park by the water. Feel fresh just stroll along the sea front. Sit at the bench and enjoy the surrounding. The guardian of the water statue is at the main entrance. Perfect for relaxation.
Lively park benches, fountains, amazing view, flowers, birds and great people watching! Plenty of walking with great views of the water and bridges and skline.
i love this place very much, the beauty and environment is truly beautiful. i could tell this is must visit place for tourist.
The place is rather pretty. I am not a flower lover, but i do enjoy the scent of the flowers. Tastefully done. Will come again.
The park is long is stretches along the Yokohama Bay. You can take a stroll at any time of the say to enjoy the view.
I loved walking by the sea and it has a beautiful rose garden. When you get to one end of the park you are close to China Town.

It's beautiful place especially in the cold evening, where you feel more chill under the shadow of trees than in the open seaside. Close to Chinatown and you can't miss it. Very rarely one gets a beautiful green park on the seaside, just enjoy it.
Yamashita Park is very clean and well maintained, close to the Yokohama Bay area, maybe you should take a umbrella in case of wind and rain!
The park is very clean and well maintained. Nice big fountain and lots of space to relax or walk around. This park is also close to the cruise port. My wife and I liked the view from here as well.

perfect for a short stroll along the harbour. A sping fountain, lots of banks to sit and relax allow a long stop. There is a museum ship in front.
Enjoyed our stroll through the park, interesting statues, manicured garden beds, lots of seats/drinking fountains/toilets and good views of the port/boats.

it is a short walk from chinatown and a nice place for stroll and views. i find it nice to sit and take pictures and stroll and sit down to enjoy some moments of quietness and across the street, visit the Kanagawa Soka Gakkai Kaikan. everthing around is within walking distance,

A fine place to walk from point A to B. Not much to see and very exposed when the hot sun is out. It’s along the water.

A place for the pokemon festival 2019 in Yamashita Park. peaceful, spacious. Remember to bring along an umbrella to block the sunlight. Late afternoon is better, not hot but cooling. Check this park out.

Nice park by the harbour. Lot of spaces to sit around and watch the ships berthed in the harbour. There are a number of nice statues in the park. The rose garden is one of the major attractions. If you are on a day trip to Yokohama, take a day ticket on the Aksai Kutsu hop on
The park is large and free. A lot of various flower so you can enjoy the view. The park near the harbour so you can see various ship.

I was here by chance during the dragon boat festival. It was a beautiful day and a fun festival. Not sure what the park is like when there’s not a festival going on- but it was filled with vendors and very enjoyable.

This is the harbour park of Yokohama. You may take a nice stroll by the sea surrounded by flower gardens and fountains, a few cafés and landmarks. Combine with a visit to Chinatown and / or Motomachi.

Next to garden necklace Yokohama, which is fantastic. Garden is very nice with some flowers blooming. Lots of green space with families picnics going on.

We fell in love with this park. It is a wonderful walk and there are many people who brought their dogs for walk. We love the display of flowers as there is a flowers exhibition. The air is very fresh in the morning. Will visit this place again if I am in Yokohama.

Highly recommend visiting this park. It is so beautiful! We were there in April and all the flowers were in bloom. And the park is located right on the bay. It was spectacular. There were also a lot of people - of all ages (from babies to the elderly). From the park, you can
We walked from the cruise ship terminal -Osanbashi. The park starts 5 minutes from there. The spring flowers were beautiful. So many tulips and other flowers in full bloom.
Yamashita Park is located not far from China Town, very clean and also the air is very fresh, in the afternoon many people come to this park just for relax
Its a true breathing space in the city Lots of beautiful plants and trees only a bit crowded on weekends and holidays Nice sea view with sea port for all touristic local ceuizez

Japan keeps its public spaces very clean and tidy and Yamashita Park is one shining example. It must be the upcoming Rugby World Cup or something, because Japan seemed even tidier on this trip.

Japanese parks are just beautiful and this is no exception! Nice waterfront walking area with fountains next to the Brick Warehouses.

Very lovely park next to the harbor. Nice breeze great place to relax and have a picnic lunch. Don't go exactly at noon too much sun

Hey, this is nice stroll and some lovely gardens and views across the city, waterfront and out to the bay. Close to Chinatown and cruise terminal.
Yokohama complements Minatomirai (modern) with Yamashita (old Yokohama). In this sense, a visit to Yamashita and its park is an interesting one for culture afficionados.

So tranquil So quiet So peaceful So cool and mostly out of the sun Some places to sit but more needed Really enjoyed it

I have to say we really enjoyed our visit. I liked walking around and enjoying the fresh air. The flowers were beautifully and walking along the harbor was fun.
Just had a great time here in this local free park which goes all out at this time of year with flowers upon flowers..

Was here in the evening with a friend of mine. It looked quite pretty and was still pretty crowded yet peaceful instead of noisy. It is a good looking park where you can also relax

This park is a great place to walk or just sit and relax. There are flower gardens to enjoy and many places just to sit and lookout over the bay.

Yamashita park stretches along the waterfront east of Minato Mirai. It's the place where locals come to have their lunch sitting on a bench or walking their dog. Ship movements can be observed from here, passenger ships dock at the Grand pier to the west. The Hikawa Maru ship

On the water with a nice garden. Good place for a picnic & people watching Very relaxing place with a good view. Easy to walk around and has many street fairs in the summer Very nice views of Yokohama too

Yokohama harbour front area is one of our favourites so we come here every trip to Yokohama.The park is between the main road and the sea and really comes right up the harbour wall. There are lots of benches in the park and plenty of trees to give protection form the sun. School

Yamashita Park stretches its green limbs from the end of an elevated promenade up to Nihon Odori, not far from the entrance to Chinatown. It is a well manicured park where one strolls lazily between city and sea. There is a cafe on the promenade side.
Its like the famous destination to go when you visit yokohama.. it only took 1 hour by train from tokyo. The park is packed with tourist and also local... but it still good to visit

Very pleasant and clean park. Close to the bay and great for an evening picnic or spending time with friends and family. I used this area quite a bit as part of my evening walk. Feels like a nice place to be.

We spent the afternoon in the park after checking in on our cruise ship. There was a flower show going on and the flowers were fabulous. From this park, and on the main street down to the stadium. Buying an ice cream and watching the local people enjoying the park was very

We walked from the cruise terminal along the park with hundreds of other walkers, ending on the Motomachi Shopping Street: Rodeo Drive of Japan. The gardens were very well maintained and the roses were spectacular.

...........and what a change ! Park now beautifully maintained, clean and spacious offering fabulous views of the general development of the Yokohama Port area (including the very modern International Terminal). Well worth a wander.
Did a couple of morning jogs here. Not a very big park but well-kept and offers a good view of the harbour.

Nice small park along the sea line, good for a stroll and some downtime. Some nice sculptures and a pretty rose garden towards the far end.

This park was in front of our hotel when I visited Yokohama. There are tress, grass area, benches and others. Many people were jogging while breathing a very fresh air. I really enjoyed the view, fresh air and also spacious area in this park.

Beautiful seaside park for picnics and strolling. There were colorful flowers at one end of the park along with bathrooms at both ends.
If in Yokohama or Tokyo... worth the view! So much to see, hear and the flowers freshen the air with the site of the Bay!
Pet friendly. Clean clean clean! We took morning jog three days in a row. There is a small shop at the end with food and drink.

A park to rest and enjoy the sea view and sea breeze. A place to people watch as well. There are performances by buskers too.

The park is one of the famous places for tourist in this town. The park faces seaside and you can feel sea breeze there. It might be comfortable except crazy hot summer season. You can see the passenger vessel named Hikawamaru which used to assigned schedule passenger ship

If you are for a serious sweating, this is the place where you can run or jog at your own phase while looking at the view. Magnificent green surroundings and blue sea!!! This is also the place where you can relax and enjoy with the family. You can have a picnic and play ball

If visiting by cruise ship, this lovely park is ideally located to spend a couple of hours to stroll and enjoy the manicured gardens, shade trees and impressive flower beds.

The most famous park of Yokohama. You get views of landmarks 360 degrees and the park has many places to sit down.

If you happen to be in the Minato Mirai area, this park is a must visit. Beautiful flowers are what fill this park and there's places for you to roll out the blanket for a picnic or simply sit on a bench and watch the people go by. Chinatown is a 5 minute walk from here if you

It is walking distance from Chinatown with sea view with ship. There are varieties of flowers in the park, even though crowded you can find a spot for oneself and relax.

During our visit there by late April, we were lucky enough to see the Garden Necklace flower display in the garden. Lots of fresh and beautiful flowers were there and you could strolled around to take photos or to have nice views on the harbor or just sit down on the benches
The gardens and landscape design was delightful. Even though there were a lot of people the area still had a serenity that made spending time in the park pleasurable

It is especially nice to enjoy a breakaway from your hectic itinerary. Less than a 10 minute walk from China Town. Take a relaxing stroll on the promenade to enjoy the array of flowers and the spectacular sea view. You can see locals running and walking their dogs. Of course,

A really great place to see the Hikame maru ship from outside before you go in. A nice serene place. There are some good restaurants around the place and the tickets fro the sea bass are right around the corner.

Very near to China Town. You can enjoy sea view while walking along the park. It takes around 15 minutes to walk to Red Brick Warehouse. Take your time, slowly walk and put all stress away while walking.

This park is beautifully maintained and designed. It provides a great setting for early morning runs and evening walks. Close proximity to Chinatown and the train network. A must see while in Yokohama

A sunny day in January, perfect. It's not so much the park itself that is worth the visit, more the waterside promenade. The harbour front is busy, many things to see, and the water is clear. The park links to many of the main attractions in Yokohama such as the Ferry Terminal,
Very nice park, for having a stroll and enjoy the sea-view. Many people with dogs, so if you are a dog lover, this is a great place. Nice place for a picnick.

Yamashita Park, located just a few streets away from Yokohama Chinatown and Motomachi shopping street is a beautiful park to have a stroll and enjoy the beautiful harbor view of Minato Mirai 21. Highly recommended if you have extra time and would love to have a good walk. We

We enjoyed walking through the park but due to the season was not looking at its best. Blooming flowers and blossoms in spring would be the best time to visit. Glad we saw the statue of 'A little girl with red shoes on' after hearing about the background story.
Just strolling around . Because of the great view taking pictures is a must i you vist this plce . You can just walk here from the station

Nice park on the Yokohama Bay. Beautiful gardens nice architectural monuments. Great park to stroll and enjoy the views of the bay. If you're there early morning the work crews haven't got around to clean so there's usually a little trash i.e. Cigarette butts, pop cans, etc. but

Lovely park right opposite the New Grand Hotel in which I stayed. I felt very safe and comfortable here. You can walk through the park heading over to the Red Brick Warehouses. Lovely, well maintained gardens.

We took the Seabass boat to Yamashita Park and were surprised by the beauty of the park and of the rose bushes. There are some wonderful places to eat on the adjacent main road, so go get some lunch or dinner afterwards!

This park is full of greenery and flowers. Many rose gardens. People use this area for relaxing or workouts. Nice place to do your morning jog.

As with most Japanese parks, Yamashita Park did not disappoint. The Girl with the Red Shoes is a nice statue and is along the way to the Red Brick Building. The Red Brick Building is a real treat. Lots of very interesting, modern and tastefully appointed stores. A lot of people,
Stayed for 2 nights near here and found it very relaxing in the afternoons after spending the mornings walking around Chinatown and Minato Mirai.

I walked through this park on my way to another area. The park I suppose fills its function for a Quick recreation or walking the dog but it was neither so big or pretty and most of the grass was off limits. I would recommend other parks or other activities before coming here

We walked to this park from the Red brick house towards Chinatown. The park is well maintained with a very green section filled with trees and bushes, followed by grass patches for picnics, the a fountain with flowers and then a beautiful rose garden.
Like the title says, it's a unique area in Yokohama. I recommend going for a walk if you have the chance but only if your in the area.
A nice view of the sea, a lovely garden, and a good place to walk around. It was quiet on a Monday afternoon. I enjoyed my time here.

It is a large park with manicured lawns and plants where people can come sit down, play games and relax. Parts of the park were cordoned off presumably for lawn maintenance but that did not stop the walk through. There are food outlets nearby as well as other attractions.
This park is very near to Osanbash pier. Main things to see inside park are: Indian fountain, A girl with red boot statue, flower park and guardian of the water statue.

I had to search for the statue of the girl with the red shoes! The surrounding park was so neat and well maintained. Loved the area to stroll around. Plenty of grass or benches to sit on and enjoy the harbour view too

The Park occupies some 200 metres of the Port frontage with well manicured gardens, statues and fountains. On our visit in July there was some substantial areas being refurbished and restocked. However it is close to Port Hotels and provides a pleasant early morning walk!
A great place to walk around And experience Y bay and see lots of local people practicing musical instruments. Good for morning jog.
We had a lovely walk through the park this afternoon. There are plenty of benches to people watch. Many locals were walking their dogs. Some grass space to run in but no play equipment.
Beautiful park with nice views of the harbor. Lots of history in the area. If you are touring, buy a book and read about Yokohama and the Yamashita-cho area.

Attended this park when the dragon boat racing was being held. The place was certainly not overcrowded, which would suggest that it seldom is. The gardens were nice, lots of flowers, but not as meticulously maintained as one would expect.

Yamashita Park is one of my favorite spots to just walk around and relax. The ocean view on one side and the grass on the other make for a beautiful, peaceful afternoon. You can sit on a bench facing the ocean, or you can sit on the grass and have a picnic. You can also sit at

The view is really amazing, the flowers are just beautiful. NYK Hikawamaru looks stunning and is one of a kind experience.

Here is nice area for everyone. I have a good memory in here. Walking so cool,Running so comfortable ,Date for couple so attractive!! You can also watch the Hikawa-Maru ship.
A nice little peaceful park by the water. A pleasant place to walk or jog with lots of beautiful flowers

every visit to japan, i always give some moment to come to this park. calm and relaxing park with bay view that bring peace in mind. it bring nostalgic moment to me. my children love to run along the park and enjoying the atmosphere. great for family

A good place to sit and relax, with a good view of the harbour. Spacious with lots of benches, beautiful sculptures and landscape.

After alighting from the Seabass ferry, we walked through a considerable amount of the park. It is lovely, relaxing, but not for "active" jaw-dropping tourism. Yes, there are joggers, but strolling seems to be the norm.

Such a lovely park, with beautiful views, nice greenery, and many people to watch. There are festivals of various kinds there, too. The girl with the red shoes statues is there, too.

Gorgeous gardens, fountains, flowers, very pretty. a joy to walk thro and take it easy for a while. Very very nice.
Nice little park by the harbour. Good for a stroll after visiting nearby shops and attractions. Very calm.

Very pleasant to run through, well lit and safe, plenty of people there even early in the morning. Walking, cycling, tai chi etc.

A small park located in an adjacent area to the Pier. Fair... it worths the visit if you have free time.
When the flowers are in bloom, the caretakers do a wonderful job of making sure the whole place is alive with all kinds of colors. Great date spot!

Nice park area by the sea, usually has something going on at a weekend. Just a short walk from minatamirai and china town areas
We went to the Belgian Beer Weekend festival which was held in the Yamashita Park. The entire area surrounding the park was phenomenal. Beautiful views of the Bay!

I love the sea and Yokohama has a wonderful view on it. I had great time walking along the Park and watching at the landscape.

This is a lovely area to visit if you are looking for a relaxing picnic place and it's great for people watching.

Yamashita park is one of the great location for photographer who is looking for a good place at Yokohama Japan. Evening view is spectacular for long exposure shot. Great opportunity to view this marvelous park while enjoying taking photos.

We walked through here one Sunday afternoon after Mass in Yamate Cathedral and breakfast at the Cheesecake Cafe. A very relaxing break and excellent for people watching. Not many tourists here - just people out enjoying the park and sea air.

Incredibly gorgeous park overlooking Yokohama Bay, if I lived there I would consider taking up jogging just to go through it!

A very relaxing stroll. Lot's of people and it's a very calming experience. Not as long as some others say it is.

It is a stretch of grass next to Yokohama port...............that's it. Hard to get too excited about a park actually.

text.wiki:
Sankei-en (三溪園, Three Creeks Garden) is a traditional Japanese-style garden in Naka Ward, Yokohama, Japan, which opened in 1906. Sankei-en was designed and built by Tomitaro Hara (原富太郎) (1868–1939), known by the pseudonym Sankei Hara, who was a silk trader. Almost all of its buildings are historically significant structures bought by Hara himself in locations all over the country, among them Tokyo, Kyoto, Kamakura, Gifu Prefecture, and Wakayama prefecture. Ten have been declared Important Cultural Property, and three more are Tangible Cultural Properties of Japan designated by the City of Yokohama. Badly damaged during World War II, the garden was donated in 1953 to the City of Yokohama, which entrusted it to the Sankeien Hoshōkai Foundation (三溪園保勝会, Sankeien Hoshōkai). Sankei-en was then restored almost to its pre-war condition.


== Features ==
Sankei-en has a total surface of 175 thousand square meters and features ponds, streams, and undulating paths designed by Sankei Hara himself, plus many historic buildings, such as Tōmyō-ji former three-story pagoda (旧燈明寺三重塔), originally constructed in Kyoto in 1457 and relocated in 1914, and the Former Yanohara House (旧矢箆原家住宅), originally the private residence of the Yanohara family.Work on the garden started in 1902 and ended in 1908, two years after it was opened to the public. During Hara's own lifetime, the place became an aggregation point for Meiji period artists. World War II caused great damage to the buildings. In 1953 the garden was donated by the Hara family to the City of Yokohama, which created the Sankeien Hoshōkai Foundation for its repair and maintenance. The Foundation started the restoration in 1953 and, five years later, the garden was back almost to its original form and reopened to the public.The Japanese government has designated ten structures in Sankei-en as Important Cultural Properties, while three more are Tangible Cultural Properties designated by the City of Yokohama. The garden is popular for its cherry blossoms, ume blossoms, and the changing leaves in autumn.


=== Kakushōkaku ===
Next to the entrance, the Kakushōkaku (鶴翔閣) was formerly the private residence of the Hara family. Today it can be rented by the public and used for meetings and parties. It is one of the three buildings on the premises designated as Tangible Cultural Properties by the City of Yokohama. Only during the summer, the Kakushōkaku is open to the public.


=== Sankei Memorial ===
Located immediately after the Kakushōkaku, the Sankei Memorial (三溪記念館, Sankei Kinenkan) was built to introduce the public to the garden and its creator through exhibits, images and works of art. A Gifu Prefecture native, Hara was the eldest son of Yanaizuchō village's headman. From childhood he liked and studied the fine arts, Sinology and poetry, finally beginning formal studies in 1885 in what is now Tokyo's Waseda University. After graduation, he became a teacher at the Atomi School for Girls. Born Aoki, he changed it later after marrying one of his students and being adopted by her family. He became the head of the family trading business and was very successful. After moving to Sankei-en's present location in Honmoku, he started collecting old buildings, rebuilding them in his garden. He then decided to open the garden to the public for free in 1906.


=== Outer Garden ===
The Outer Garden, that is, the area next to the Main Pond, was the first part of the garden to open to the public in 1906. The buildings it contains are Tōmyō-ji former three-storied pagoda, a tea room called Rindō-an (林洞庵), a tea hut called Yokobue-an (横笛庵), Tōkei-ji's former butsuden (旧東慶寺仏殿, Kyū-Tōkei-ji butsuden) and Tōmyō-ji's former hon-dō (Main Hall) (旧燈明寺本堂, Kyū-Tōmyō-ji hon-dō).Tōmyō-ji's former main hall (Important National Cultural Property) was brought here from Kyoto and is an example of Muromachi period (1336–1557) architecture. Bought in 1988, it was completely restored with intensive work of restoration and reconstruction that lasted five years.Tōmyō-ji's former three-storied pagoda (Important National Cultural Property) is visible from any point of the garden and is its symbol. It was moved to Sankei-en in 1914.
Tōkei-ji's former butsuden (Important National Cultural Property) used to be the main hall of a Rinzai Zen temple in Kamakura. Its structure and name are typical of that sect. It was bought and moved to Sankei-en in 1907.


==== Former Yanohara House ====
The Former Yanohara House (旧矢箆原家住宅, Kyū-Yanohara-ke Shūtaku) (Important National Cultural Property) used to be the private home of an Edo period (1603–1868) wealthy family, the Yanohara. It is the only building whose interior is open to the public all year. It was brought here from Gifu Prefecture's Shirakawago, an area listed among the World Heritage sites. The house contains the original hearth, bathroom and kitchen used by the Yanohara. The second floor houses an exhibition of Japanese folk articles.


=== Inner Garden ===
The Inner Garden, north of the Main Pond, was opened to the public in 1958, and was until then the Hara family's private garden. Its buildings are the Gomon Gate (御門) (Tangible Cultural Property), the Hakuun-tei (白雲邸) (Tangible Cultural Property), the Rinshunkaku (臨春閣), Tenzui-ji's former Jutō Ōidō (旧天瑞寺寿塔覆堂, Kyū-Tenzui-ji Jutō Ōidō), the Shunsōro (春草廬), the Kinmokutsu (金毛窟), the Gekkaden (月華殿), the Tenju-in (天授院), the Chōshūkaku (聴秋閣), and the Renge-in. Only during the summer, the Rinshunkaku and the Hakuun-tei are open to the public.Of particular value is the Rinshunkaku (Important National Cultural Property, see photo below), formerly belonging to the Kii House of Tokugawa. It is often compared in beauty to the World famous Katsura Imperial Villa in Kyoto. Originally the summer residence of Tokugawa Yorinobu, the first head of the Kii House, it used to stand in Iwade, Wakayama prefecture. Acquired by Hara in 1906, it was rebuilt over a period of three years between 1915 and 1917. Divided in three sections, it was decorated by famous artists Kanō Tanyū and Kanō Yasunobu. The transoms between pavilions are decorated with sculpted waves (first pavilion) and special paper containing poetry (second pavilion). The third pavilion's transom is decorated with real gagaku instruments like shō and flutes.
The Gekkaden (Important National Cultural Property) was built in 1603 by Ieyasu, the first of the Tokugawa shōguns within Kyoto's Fushimi Castle. It was bought in 1918 together with the Shunsōro and moved to Sankei-en. Hara then connected it to a pavilion he built, the Kinmokutsu. The paintings on the room partitions are attributed to Momoyama period artist Kaihō Yūshō. The Gekkaden can be rented by the public.
The Tenju-in (Important National Cultural Property) was originally a Jizō-dō in Kita-Kamakura near the great Kenchō-ji Zen temple and was bought in 1916. Tenju-in was Hara's Jibutsu-dō (持仏堂), the temple which enshrined his tutelary gods.Tenzui-ji's former Jutō Ōi-dō (Important National Cultural Property, see image above) was built in 1591 by Toyotomi Hideyoshi as a resting place for his mother, and is one of the few extant buildings attributable with certainty to him.The construction of the Chōshūkaku (Important National Cultural Property, see photo below) is traditionally attributed to Iemitsu, third of the Tokugawa shōguns. The pavilion is open to the public in spring and in November for the traditional viewing of the autumn colors.The Shunsōro (Important National Cultural Property) is a tea room believed to have been built for Oda Urakusai, brother of the more famous Oda Nobunaga. Urakusai was a well-known practitioner of the tea ceremony.


== Getting there ==
From Yokohama, take the Negishi Line to Negishi.
From bus stop No. 1, take any of the buses numbered 58, 99 or 101 and get off in Honmoku.
Cross the street, walk to the convenience store, turn right and walk straight to the garden (about 500 meters)


== Other information ==
Opening hours: 9:00 to 17:00 (entrance allowed until 16:30)
Ticket price (as of December 2017): 700 Yen


== Gallery ==

we were lucky and saw a guitar concert live in one of the temples on the garden grounds...it's such a beautiful place and slightly off the beaten path in Yokohama. I imagine the fall foliage is also so pretty.

text.wiki:
CupNoodles Museum Yokohama (カップヌードルミュージアム 横浜) is a museum dedicated to instant noodles and Cup Noodles, as well as its creator and founder, Momofuku Ando.
Museum located in Yokohama, which features four stories of exhibitions and attractions. This location includes various exhibits to display the history of instant ramen and Momofuku Ando's story.


== References ==


== External links ==
Official website
text.quote: Child-friendly exhibits on creative thinking, instant ramen noodles & their inventor, Momofuku Ando.
trip: This is the second cup noodle museum I visited. The area is much bigger than the one in Osaka. The exhibition is also different, the movie before you enter the exhibition is very interesting and really helps you understand the story of cup noodles. The booking system for making

Its a very spacious compound with every section laid out neatly, it shows the history and life story of founder of Nissin Mr Momofuku Ando. How he overcame his problems and came up with a noodle that changed our lives. It is very informative and the entire space is bright and

The museum is very spacious . Unless you participate in their activities (extra charge) , there’s not much to see. The reason why I’m giving them 4 star is because of their staff. Very helpful and goes out of their way to show us how to get to our next destination, despite their

This is a 'must do' on every Japan itinerary and a highlight on the trip, it is a short 10 minuet walk from Yokohama JR station. This quirky museum is split into several sections all by separate admission. The main museum costs around £3 and tells the evolution of instant
We had an amazing time at the museum which was very neatly organized with many interactive educational things to play around with. We really enjoyed making our own Noodles.

I fully concur with many of the other reviews. Making noodles is silly, but it was educational and great fun. The young staff seems as organized as a Swiss watch. And friendly. Beyond the noodle-making, the museum was medium (not great, not bad)

I'm also working in a tourism industry, this is the place that inspired me and gave me a lot of ideas, it's also a family friendly place, they are able to build such a big museum with a simple idea about cup noodles is just amazing.
it has all the instant noodle from 1960 up to now,it show how to make and you can choose what you want in the cup noodle it has a small food court with 6 different taste of noodle,and with a dessert,

It all sounds silly but designing your own cup noodles together with hundreds of others - locals and tourists, couple and families alike - is great fun and typically Japanese way of spending a few hours. Overall the museum is well-organised and informative. A great tribute to

The online booking process was smooth and easy. We booked ourselves for both the cup noodle and instant chicken noodle making experience. The former was more a fun decorating and viewing experience, and the latter was handson make the dough from scratch and watch your own

The museum itself was quite informative with an English audio app. Personally I think it would be worth going to only if you make your own ramen in the classes - there were only about one floor's worth of displays.

We went there on a rainy day. Hence, it was a rather uncomfortable walk from yokohama station to the cup museum. Once in, we immediately book the ticket to make the cup noodle at 300 yen per cup. We get to decorate our own cup noodle and choose the ingredient. It was fun for the
Spent about 2 hours just exploring the place. We didn’t have time to create our own noodles but had fun!

If you are a fan of cup noodles in general, this museum would be a good attraction to visit where you get to learn about the history of cup noodles. You'll also be able to make you own cup noodles and also ramen noodles at the museum itself. But there'll be additional charges to

This is a fun place. Very popular with families. Open at 10am. You can make your own cup noodles but you need to queue. Worth the wait. The Noodles Bazaar is also great. 8 different types of noodles from outside Japan. The stand out and must try is the cup noodle ice cream. It

You will learn how the cup noodles started. You will see on display all the different versions of cup noodles made by Nissin from different countries.

Great story. Learned so much about the founder and perseverance. Inspiring. Viewed the walls of noodles and decorated a cup and got personalized noodles. Great museum. There is a play area for the little ones. It’s was crowded when I went but the lines move quickly. Highly

This was so much fun. We did both experiences (cup noodle and chicken ramen) and they were brilliant. Making our very own chicken ramen was definitely a highlight of our trip so far. Loads of children taking part too so suitable for all ages 😊 they cater for English speakers

Nice place and good to know behind Japan cup noodle history, Nice trip Is good try to came visit After visits can design ur own cup noodle at level 4 If wan take a short break got drink and food stall Nice view at level 4

Walked in the Cup of noodles and this is a newer museum alongside the Yokohama bay area, and giving Yokohama city lots of credit for creating and atmosphere and shopping areas along the Bay side of Yokohama!

...if I could read Japanese. There was some English but just titles and dates on most displays. I didn't make my own cup noodles because I didn't really think it would add anything to my life. Looked like there was a lot of kids on school trips having fun. I guess I should

This museum dedicated to the Cup of Noodles meals tells the story of the person that came up with the idea to create this ready to serve meal. It also has an interactive area where you can create and make your on Cup of noodles. Had a wonderful time with everyone.

This is a perfect place for children. It takes relatively little time. They can touch anything and everything, and take a ton of pictures. Plus you can make your own CupNoodle as a souvenir, for 300 yen. It’s a bargain. For adults, you can be inspired by the inventor, Mr. Ando.

We took a pleasant 15-minute walk from Ōsanbashi Pier one sunny morning. While it was midweek, the waterfront was fairly lively. So was the museum - a distinctly simple building with an understated entrance. The main lobby is anchored by a grandly magnificent minimalist

Visited this museum twice already. We still want to go back. Interesting, educational, and interactive. You will never get bored. My kids love it here.

Great history on instant noodles from the beginning  to present day.
A lot of fun making your own cup and eating all the international noodle dishes

Overall, we enjoyed the museum. It could use more English translations for some of the exhibit, however it was still great. Of course the best part is when you get to create your ramen and take it home with you..
Great, modern museum. Enjoyable for all ages!
Fun place to go with kids and learn about the history of cupnoodles

500 yen entrance (access to 2 small exhibits). 300 yen for making your own cup noodle. There are other floors / activity with their own fee.
Better for groups / families / kids.
So much fun! Busy but worth a visit even if you're not a fan. Food court has great noodles for a quick bite.

Very interesting place where you get up close and personal with your favourite cup noodles. Create your own cup noodle and learn the entire preparation process. A must visit in Yokohama and be prepared to spend an afternoon there
Great experience but other than the booklet, most of the exhibit is in Japanese. Creating our own cups was fun and the whole walkthrough probably won't take more than 1.5 hours.
Very clean and no blocked/crowded areas throughout museum. No time limit when drawing on your cup. Line moves very quickly, bottleneck is people picking their 1 broth and 4 ingredients

So good! Surprising how interesting they have made the subject matter here. You'll learn about the process but most important you'll learn about why dried noodles were such an important invention. I loved the different noodles packages from …

I visited this place because I love ramen and noodle soups in general. For some reason I thought the small bowls of noodles in the ‘noodle bazaar’ would be amazing. They weren’t the worst bowls of noodles I ever had but they were below …

Wonderful experience in learning and making my own noodle. Fantastic.
Love the experience.

One of the highlights of my trip to Japan. The building itself is beautiful in it's minimalist design. The exhibits are well thought out and are inspiring.
Do not miss the make your own Cup noodles experience. It may sound crazy but get …

A creative and cute way to present the innovative history of the humble cup noodle. Except for an introductory video and some bold titles, English information is scarce. Don't miss the chance to create your own cupnoodle (for 300¥ extra). It make a tasty memory!

Extremely beautiful building and laid out really well, entry is cheap but unfortunately very little text is in English, audio tours are available.

Making your own ramen is pretty cool, but limited to one type of broth and four toppings. …

Although I has a great time and the staff was really  helpful , I have nothing bad to write about this place. The fee is very small of 500 yen to explore the entire meuseum and free re entry throughout the day . For only 300 yen you can …

Absolutely worth a trip here if visiting Tokyo. The short video explaining the history is very interesting and they offer the audio in English. Make sure you have cash to make your own unique cup noodles!

A fun tour of the history, manufacturing process and trivia of the cup noodle industry. This culminates in the opportunity to create your own custom cup noodle. Quirky, whimsical fun revolving around a common staple item.

Highly recommend to take children and families. There was so much cool information - learned a lot about the invention of instant ramen, and it’s presented in a kid-friendly way with animations and recreations. Admission includes a short …
Very interesting and learnt a lot. Recommend the theatre show to learn about the inventor of instant ramen!
Aside from the fun attraction of building your own Cup Noodle, I found that the other parts of the museum were quite boring.

Really cool museum centered around Nissin's original chicken noodles! Admission is pretty cheap and there are a lot of interesting interactive exhibits. Minor negative for people who do not speak Japanese, there are several exhibits that …
Fun atmosphere designing your own cup Noodles. A good selection of ingredients that will suit your tastes! Try the cup Noodles ice cream for an interesting taste!
!!!  Never give up! <- You'll understand after you visit.  Great place for those who have a knack for designing their own cup noodles!
A very good place if you go with a family or a more friends. Funny for children and a great alternative when it's raining in Yokohama.

I've been to a lot of museums in Japan and this museum is alot smaller and does not have as many exhibits as the rest. The focus seems to be on the creative process of their founder.

Come early if u want to make your own personalised cup noodle as the tickets for the event was out of stock by the time we arrived.
Make your own cup noodles at yen300 only!

Very fun to see the origins of cup noodles. Be sure to get here early so you can grab a ticket to make your very own cup noodle! They give you markers to design the cup and you can pick ingredients that go inside. Note that the cup noodle expires in 30 days.

It's not a huge attraction, it's a museum with a build your own Cup Noddles. The build your own was a little bit disappointing to me. They only let you put in one of the four flavor powders and four ingredients. I wanted to make the …

Book every experience!

If this is your first time at the Yokohama Cup Noodle Museum, experience everything it has to offer! The CUPNOODLE factory was my favorite as they let you customize the design of the cup and flavor of the ramen. It’s …

As I am noodle lover, I enjoyed this place. Very reasonable to go in. You can design/ make your cup noodle there. Also there is another session of making actual instant noodle bit ?  I will try that next time ! There are restaurant as well where you can eat noodle dish from all over the world. You love noodles? You gotta go here.
Slightly small and boring but it's worth checking if you are a tourist checking out Yokohama.
500 yen entry fee. 300 yen to make your own cup noodles. They have a food bazaar on the 4th floor that serves noodles from around the world using their own noodles. Highly recommend the tom yum.

The Noodle Bazaar is amazing and super unexpected and delicious. Getting to learn the history of instant noodles was cool too, but the BEST part is being able to design and customize my own cup noodle for only 300¥!

Was very good. Made our own noodles cup which we had for dinner that night and you get to decorate your own cup. It's smaller than I expected though and you need to pay extra to actually make your noodles from scratch. Overall enjoyable.
One of my favorite museums so far.  Very inspiring too
Interesting experience. You can design your personal cup noodle!
Fun to see how the Nissins Cup noodles are made

Great experience making your own cup noodles, however the place closes too early at 6pm, we got there at 5 and no one warned use they would be closing soon, by the time we finished making our cup noodles it was already 6.  It's still a must …

Very boring and bad experience. It DOES NOT DESERVE A 'MUSEUM'. The feeling is like spending 500 yen to take participant an enterprise advertisement, I will never come back the second time. If you like quiet atmosphere but went in a holiday day, then you may feel disappointed.(５００円で企業研修を受けた)
Lots of fun. Head straight to the line to get a time slot for the make your own cup noodles. Better to head early as wait can be long.
Very crowded and long line for making your own cup noodle. It was interesting to see the history behind it. Kids will enjoy if you can get in time for make your own.
Staff was helpful and friendly! They have an app for English speakers to hear the writing on the walls in the exhibits however we couldn't get it working

Really cute museum! You can make your own custom cup noodle at the end too but go early and reserve your tjme! The museum is a great mix of fun yet educational. Had a great time as adults there. The noodles were yummy
Nifty thing to do while in Tokyo, if visiting definitely visit the noodle bazaar

Made noodles from scratch! The staff were super helpful and it was a great way to spend an afternoon! I was really surprised how much fun and how interesting they made the experience! There was a great mix of people young and old and they …
It was a fun place to spend the afternoon with the whole family.

A must visit! We absolutely enjoyed our time here especially making our own cup noodles! There is also an international noodle food court with noodles from Japan, Korea, China, Italy, Vietnam, and Indonesia!

This is one of a kind in the world. It describes all of Momofuku Ando's achievements regarding Chicken Ramen and Cup Noodles. These achievements are very important, as they have changed the world. Also, making your very own Cup Noodles is …
Lots of pictures, made my own cup of noodle.  They need to the the english speaking app working as there is no translations.
A good place for a kid to experience and learn about noodles, not so much for an adult, but if you looking for something to do why not?
Great stop to stretch legs and eat some ramen. Great setup and great info on history.

A wonderful little museum on cup noodles. The price to enter is reasonable. There is an English audio guide for the video about the history of cup noodles. It was all very interesting to learn about cup noodles. Creating my own cup noodles was also a fun activity. Highly recommended for people that like cup noodles and kids.
It was very crowded but worth the 500 yen entry fee. You can make your custom cup noodles for another 300 yen. Great place for children, but the queue is long for the activities
Very good place to bring your children

Entertaining and charming little museum. They have a cartoon about the cup noodle inventor, English translation is available. You can design your own cup noodle cup and have it filled with incredients of your choice. For this you need a appointment which you get with your admission

Must visit when in Yokohama, busy but well organised museum, mainly celebrating the founder. Really enjoyed making my own cup noodles to take home, you get to design the cup and pick the ingredients.

There is also an area where you can try noodles from different countries, serving sizes are small though, more of a snack than a meal.

text.quote: Old-fashioned ship museum where visitors can explore the captain's office, crew cabins & more.
trip: Best time to be at Sakuragicho station. Just walk over and you can go on the Nippon Maru training ship for a cheap fee. Go in the evening and then take in the beautiful night scene of Sakuragicho by the bay and even watch the Pokémon parade now till 12th Aug every night. The
If you like historic ships, then visit. If not, then there's not much of interest. This is a typical walk-thru and look into cabins experience. Nothing overly exciting.

Berthed almost walking distance from Yamashita park and Minatomirai, this ship is a treat to watch. Didn’t really have plans to visit it but spotted it while I was cycling with my kid. ps: take a picture with the wheel in the background and reflection in the canal

It was built in 1930 as a training ship for cadets, training 11,500 cadets for 54 years until 1984. During her service, Nippon Maru sailed 45.4 times around the earth, 1.83 million km. Now, it is docked permanently at Minato Mirai area. For those keen on port and ship history

This was a really interesting experience to see the whole ship. The best part was the guide, a man who had served as a cadet himself on the ship. who explained everything in detail with kindness and a nice sense of humor.

We have visited Nippon Maru, the great Japanese training ship, tied up to the pier, just under the huge landmark tower of Yokohama. The two icons present a stunning and contrasting view of "old" and "new", a perfect photo opportunity for visitors. The ship is an immaculate
This stunning ship is next to the landmark tower and worth a visit. Some explanations in english, and inside/outside everything is quite beautiful
The old sailing ship are anchored here in Yokohama. Now it's a floating museum for study a history of Japanese Maritime. It's very close to a train station. easy to walk there.

The ship is great to wander through especially if you are interested in tall ships, the museum is great for giving you an insight into the history of Yokohama and maritime history of Japan. There are very good interactive bits for kids (and 57 year old kids) to have a play with!

The Japanese sail training ship "Nippon Maru" in Yokohama is a very nice object to visit. The amusement park nearby makes this the trip to the Japanese Segelschulschiff quite reasonable. Admission to the sail training ship is low and opens up the possibility to explore a sail

This is a lovely and rather large ship. While it does not have the complete charm of a real old ship, it's still impressive and when the wind blows through its sails - it's magic. Not for anyone suffering for sea sickness.

I have admit I love old ships but this display was brilliantly presented and the self guided tour really well set up. All the displays and audio are in both English and Japanese and the entire display is wonderfully preserved and presented. There is no pressure to rush you tour

Formerly a training ship in Yokohama, now sits in the Minato Mirai area dockyard. It serves as a museum and like a famous landmark in Yokohama. Worth the visit for any tourist and a great place to have a photo shoot, day or night it's still awesome =).

its worth a walk about. it is grand and it is a training ship it is also a museum just like the Missouri battleship. very nice. quite a surprise inside as it is still a functional vessel to some extent.

With a combined ticket you can visit both the Nippon Maru and the port museum just behind. I liked the visit, there are signs in Japanese and English at almost every significant place but it's much enjoyable if you have the luck of making the tour with one of the guides. During

500 yen to get in, which isn't great, but not too bad. Tour is preset, so you have to follow that, no random exploring, which is what I prefer. Unfortunately, you only get to go only one deck below; would much prefer to see engine room and forward compartment. Other than

The tall ship was great to see- you could climb into the bunks, visit the helm, go into most rooms, and take lots of pictures. Plus, the museum in the pavilion was incredible. (No photography allowed in the museum). Everything was displayed with English translation & the guides

One of the mission for this trip is to visit the Nippon Maru Ship in Yokohama. The ship is one of a good memory of my dad who spent about 2 weeks on this ship from Thailand to Japan when he's a teenager. The ship is well-maintained with informative signage from the entrance.

Was a ship with lots of history. Well worth a visit. It has a history spanning both pre and post WWII. Most of the insides of the ship is open for viewing. Part of the ships history puts a different angle on WWII.

During a recent business trip to Japan recently, I took the opportunity to visit the training sailing ship "Nippon Maru", which is now permanently moored adjacent to the Landmark Tower in Yokohama. The vessel is an ex-merchant navy cadet training vessel. Being ex Merchant Navy
Visited both the ship and the museum beside it. Both very worthwhile. Plenty of signs in English and English speaking guides.

Very interesting experience to know how ship works and how the people or ship live.

Every day we see the old photo album and diary from the Kaiwo Maru on our book shelf . It has been there since the 1970's  we look forward to soon visiting the Kaiwo Maru or it's sister ship in the coming months . The men inside the album want to go home
Good place to visit
The ship is in a n interesting contrast to the surroundings. You can have a tour of the ship, or just enjoy from a far.

Well preserved and well located ninety year old sail training ship. Many signs in English and reasonable entry charge. Gives you a great idea of what life was like back then. Surprising to see that so many items built into the ship were made in the UK. Good area to be located in as well with many other attractions close at hand.
Beautiful on sunny day and night.

text.wiki:
Yokohama Station (横浜駅, Yokohama-eki) is a major interchange railway station in Nishi-ku, Yokohama, Japan. It is the busiest station in Kanagawa Prefecture and the fifth-busiest in the world as of 2013, serving 760 million passengers a year.


== Lines ==
Yokohama Station is served by the following lines:

East Japan Railway Company (JR East)
JT Tokaido Main Line
JO Yokosuka Line
JH Yokohama Line
JS Shōnan-Shinjuku Line
JK Keihin-Tohoku Line
JK Negishi Line
Keikyu
KK Keikyu Main Line
Sagami Railway (Sotetsu)
 Sagami Railway Main Line
Tokyu Corporation
TY Tokyu Toyoko Line
Yokohama Minatomirai Railway
 Minatomirai Line
Yokohama Municipal Subway
 Blue Line (B20)(JR Central's Tokaido Shinkansen passes through Shin-Yokohama Station, not Yokohama Station.)


== Station layout ==


=== Keikyu and JR East ===
The JR East and Keikyu platforms are located in the main above-ground portion of Yokohama Station. Keikyu's section consists of platforms 1 to 2, JR East operates platforms 3 to 10.

		
		
		
		
		
		


=== Tokyu and Minatomirai ===
Tokyu Corporation and the Yokohama Minatomirai Railway Company share the same underground station located in the 5th underground level of Yokohama Station, to the west of the JR platforms.

		


=== Yokohama Municipal Subway ===
The Yokohama Municipal Subway is located on the 3rd basement level, west of the main station.


=== Sotetsu ===
Sagami Railway is an above-ground structure to the west of the main station, connected to the Sotetsu Department Store.


== Adjacent stations ==
Notes


== Bus services ==


=== Expressway bus (daytime) ===
Yokohama City Air Terminalfor Haneda Airport
for Narita Airport
Eastside bus terminal
for Tokyo Disney Resort
for JR Gotemba Station (Mount Fuji), Hakone Tōgendai (Lake Ashi)


=== Expressway bus (overnight) ===
Yokohama City Air Terminal
for JR Nagoya Station, JR Okayama Station
Eastside bus terminal
for JR Kyoto Station, JR Ōsaka Station, JR Sendai Station, JR Akita Station


=== Local routes ===
Yokohama Municipal Bus
Sotetsu Bus
Kanachu Bus
Keikyu Bus


== Surrounding area ==

The west and east have a complex underground business district which spans over several floors and is directly connected with the buildings which surround the station. Yokohama station has three bus terminals, and two other bus terminals are located near the station.


=== East entrance ===

Porta (underground shopping mall)
Sogo (department store, with Yokohama station eastside bus terminal)
Lumine (shopping building)

== History ==


=== First station ===

On May 7, 1872 (June 12 in Gregorian calendar), Yokohama Station (original station, now Sakuragichō Station) opened as one of the first railway stations in Japan.
On July 11, 1887, the railway was extended from Yokohama to Kōzu Station. Through trains between Shimbashi Station and Kōzu Station required a switchback at Yokohama Station.
On August 1, 1898, a line bypassing Yokohama Station was opened to avoid the switchback. Through trains stopped at Kanagawa Station or Hodogaya Station instead of Yokohama Station, and shuttle trains connected Yokohama and Hodogaya until Hiranuma Station opened near present-day Hiranumabashi Station on October 10, 1901. Hiranuma Station had no connection to public transport such as trams, so that major part of the passengers for the city continued to use trains that stopped at Yokohama Station.


=== Second station ===

On August 15, 1915, the second Yokohama Station opened close to the present day Takashimachō Station to allow Tōkaidō Main Line trains to call at Yokohama Station. The original Yokohama Station was renamed Sakuragichō Station. JR East uses this date as the opening date of the current Yokohama Station.
The terminal of the Keihin Line (present-day Keihin-Tōhoku Line) had been in Takashimachō since 1914 and was merged to the new station. The government-run electric line was later this year extended to Sakuragichō.
On 1 September 1923, the station was destroyed by a fire in the 1923 Great Kantō earthquake.
Six days later, the station reopened with a temporary building.
The city of Yokohama and the Ministry of Railways agreed in February 1924 that the station would be relocated.On May 18, 1928, the Tokyo Yokohama Railway (now the Tokyu Toyoko Line) extended from its former terminal of Kanagawa Station was connected to the station. The extension line passed through the construction site of the new Yokohama Station of the government railways.


=== Third station ===

On October 15, 1928, the third (current) Yokohama Station opened on the north side of the second station. The Tōkaidō Main Line also moved to its current route, which was the route of the bypass line opened in 1898. The government railways and the Toyoko Line shared the station from the beginning.
On February 5, 1930, the Keihin Electric Railway (now the Keikyu Main Line) was connected to the station.
On December 27, 1933, the Jinchū Railway (now the Sotetsu Main Line) was connected to the station. On December 9, 1957, the north side underground entrance opened. On December 1, 1965, the MARS on-line ticket reservation system was introduced at the station. On September 4, 1976, the Yokohama City Subway Line No. 3 was connected to Yokohama Station. On November 7, 1980, the new east station building and east-west passage opened. On January 31, 2004, The Tōkyū Tōyoko Line platform reopened underground, and on February 1, 2004, the Minatomirai Line opened.


=== Future ===
On August 26, 2010, JR East announced the development of a new station building to replace the current West Entrance, tentatively named the Yokohama Station West Station Building (横浜駅 西口駅ビル, Yokohama-eki Nishiguchi-eki biru).  Scheduled to open in 2020 before the Tokyo 2020 Summer Olympics, the development will include a 26-story retail and office building, Station-front tower (駅前棟, Ekimae-tō), on the site of the current West Entrance and a nine-story building to the north-east, Tsuruya-cho tower (鶴屋町棟, Tsuruyamachi-tō), which will include parking and childcare facilities.


== Passenger statistics ==
In fiscal 2013, the JR East station was used by an average of 406,594 passengers daily (boarding passengers only), making it the busiest JR East station in Kanagawa Prefecture and the fourth-busiest on the JR East network as a whole.The JR East passenger figures for previous years are as shown below.

text.wiki:
The Yokohama Landmark Tower (横浜ランドマークタワー, Yokohama Randomāku Tawā) is the second tallest building and 4th tallest structure in Japan, standing 296.3 m (972 ft) high. Until surpassed by Abeno Harukas in 2012, it stood as the tallest building in Japan. It is located in the Minato Mirai 21 district of Yokohama city, next to the Yokohama Museum of Art.The building contains a five-star hotel which occupies floors 49–70, with 603 rooms in total. The lower 48 floors contain shops, restaurants, clinics, and offices. The building contains two tuned mass dampers on the (hidden) 71st floor on opposite corners of the building.On the 69th floor there is an observatory, Sky Garden, from which one can see a 360-degree view of the city, and on clear days Mount Fuji.The tower contains what were at their inauguration the world's second fastest elevators (installed by Mitsubishi Electric), which reach speeds of 12.5 m/s (41 ft/s) (45.0 km/h (28.0 mph)). This speed allows the elevator to reach the 69th floor in approximately 40 seconds. The elevators' speed record was surpassed by elevators of Taipei 101 (60.6 km/h, 37.7 mi/h) in 2004.
The building was designed by the architecture and engineering division of Mitsubishi Estate, now Mitsubishi Jisho Sekkei and Hugh Stubbins and Associates, later KlingStubbins.

text.wiki:
The Yokohama Landmark Tower (横浜ランドマークタワー, Yokohama Randomāku Tawā) is the second tallest building and 4th tallest structure in Japan, standing 296.3 m (972 ft) high. Until surpassed by Abeno Harukas in 2012, it stood as the tallest building in Japan. It is located in the Minato Mirai 21 district of Yokohama city, next to the Yokohama Museum of Art.The building contains a five-star hotel which occupies floors 49–70, with 603 rooms in total. The lower 48 floors contain shops, restaurants, clinics, and offices. The building contains two tuned mass dampers on the (hidden) 71st floor on opposite corners of the building.On the 69th floor there is an observatory, Sky Garden, from which one can see a 360-degree view of the city, and on clear days Mount Fuji.The tower contains what were at their inauguration the world's second fastest elevators (installed by Mitsubishi Electric), which reach speeds of 12.5 m/s (41 ft/s) (45.0 km/h (28.0 mph)). This speed allows the elevator to reach the 69th floor in approximately 40 seconds. The elevators' speed record was surpassed by elevators of Taipei 101 (60.6 km/h, 37.7 mi/h) in 2004.
The building was designed by the architecture and engineering division of Mitsubishi Estate, now Mitsubishi Jisho Sekkei and Hugh Stubbins and Associates, later KlingStubbins.

Yokohama Landmark Tower is a great masterpiece. I loved this building. There were not so many people around. It is worth visiting!

We went in June 2020. Absolutely no one was up there. The bar/cafe serves great stuff. Nothing better than a beer or coffee looking at a stunning view. When it was empty it was amazing, I'm sure it would lose its appeal as it gets more crowded.

We were at Yokohama when Typhoon Hagibis hit Tokyo area. Most of the attraction are still closed after the typhoon except the observation deck in landmark tower. The night view is awesome, and you can even see tokyo tower and skytree from far. You can also take the world fastest

1000 Yen entrance fee was well worth the price. This was one of the best observatories I've visited so far. Aside from offering stunning 360-degree view of Yokohama, Sky Garden also has a cafeteria/bar and some shops in there too. Also has the fastest elevator in Japan (?),
It’s nothing comparable to this. The view is outstanding. I was traveling alone and not leaving disappointed
More expensive than Tokyo SkyTree and Pointless if you visited Tokyo SkyTree. Go for other spots in Yokohama.
Beautiful views and reasonably priced Great place to watch the sunset There is a bar/restaurant and a gift shop

Crazy fast elevator wisks you up to the observation level for great day and night time views of Yokohama. See Mt. Fuji, Tokyo downtown, the harbor area and of course the mesmerizing Cosmo Clock 21 (ferris wheel as we call it) and it's ever changing light themes. It is crowded,
For us, a 'must do' and we always get up the tallest building and work the camera quite hard. Well worth doing.
Well worth a visit at 4.45 and watch city change from day to night. Incredible views and Japan fastest lift, 69 stories in 40 second.

Went there in evening before sunset and enjoyed both day and night views. Views are really stunning much better than I had expected. The Bay Area is visible and so is the flyer and 360 degree views of city. Night views are stunning and ticket price is reasonable. Must visit
This was a 30 min activity for us. There were no lines and we made it to the top in under 10 min. It’s always interesting to see a city by night.

Really good views of Yokahama from the 69th floor, as you walk around the circular 360 degree viewing area Mount Fuji stands out, the mega fast lift was out of action due to the Typhoon raging the day before but the standard lift was still fast. Gift shop and cafe bar available

Every time I have family and friends visiting us in Minatomirai I take them to the Sky Garden where we start our tour around the area. The 360° view from the 69th floor of the tower is an excellent way to give my guests an idea of the directions of places I intend on taking them.

Worth the admission fee if the weather is good, there is a sign that informs you of visibility conditions prior to paying for entry. Super fast lift. Enjoyed coffee and sandwiches from the cafe/bar, whilst soaking up the views in a comfy sofa.

Take up trip to the Landmark Tower Sky Garden for some AMAZING views. Gift shop and bar at the top. Great photo opportunities. Suitable for large or small groups, children will also enjoy the trip to the top. Toilets available,

Yokohama Sky Garden in a great attraction, if you half an hour to spend. It offers great views of Yokohama, especially the port. It is not as expensive as the one in Tokyo (Sky Tree). The observation deck in quite big, and they have a gift shop as well.

We went up to Landmark Tower sky Garden observation deck after reading positive reviews on trip advisor. Well worth the minor cost. The elevator ride is very fast but you almost do not feel the acceleration. Views are great and you see just how Yokohama is growing. Recommend

Spent an hour or so in the Tower - lots of good eating places and shops selling touristy tat - the Olympic 2020 shop is worth visiting
Short trip Tokyo must have visit Yokohama as one place good for place. Nice spot photo angle as well.

69 floors in just 40 seconds and I could have easily sip a hot cup of coffee without spilling any! Once on top, we enjoyed the 360 degree panoramic view of Yokohoma at night.
Fabulous view at night from the observation deck on the 69th floor Above large shopping mall with eateries on the first level
Just for the view it is worth the expense. However, don't go looking to have a nice cocktail while watching the world go bye, not a popular drink in these parts,

After missing out on seeing Fuji for the majority of my trip, it was a beautiful and clear day the morning of my flight. I wandered around taking some Sakura photos and then I saw the sign indicating that you could see Mt. Fuji from the Sky Garden! I hurried, bought a ticket
It was totally worth the money to get to the top! We were able to see sunset over Mt Fuji and watch Yokohama light up for the night.
At Landmark Tower you have a nice view around the Yokohama bay. Inside there are a lot of shops and restaurants. I had a great time.

Simply the best place to visit in the winter, with clear skies in Japan, make sure you see Mt Fuji with a covering of snow, and no cloud. The 69th floor café faces the direction of Fuji, so you can have a seat, and eat/drink and watch the fabulous Winter sunsets behind Fuji.
After a ride up a fast elevator, you're greeted with a great view of Yokohama and the surrounding areas.

Priced right on the right nights, or consecutive nights, and worth the price. Good view day or night. Good amenities. Attached to Queen Square mall, high end shopping and always a display, event, and art to see.

The food was nice, slightly pricey. The only reason didn't give 5 stars is because they got my order wrong and I had to wait for the correct order to be brought out The cocktails were great (and cheap)

It's a 1000Yen trip to the top of the highest skyscraper in the Kanto region. And it's worth it. I haven't enjoyed anything the skygarden, but the view. In winter there is often a great view to the snow capped Mt. Fuji.
The building has the fastest elevator to the top floor 69th within 10 secs. I love the view and ice-cream there.

Well worth the trip to the top to get 360 degrees of Yokohama from some 270m up in the sky. On a clear day not only you can see the suburbs of Tokyo which are highlighted / identified in matching photos above the viewing windows but also of Mount Fuji. Local landmarks and
Amazing views from this building, including in the elevator. Going at night is definitely better with all the lights of the attractions around it and colours reflecting off the water.
Had to ride the high speed elevator & see the grand view, got to see Fugisan with snow. Well worth the charge for the ride. Also wonderful high quality shopping in the tower. Enjoy!!

I would highly recommend a trip to the top of the landmark tower when you’re in Yokohama. Breathtaking views whichever way you turn and small lessons of history dotted on the walls of the viewing deck.
Japan was quiet hot during July and then rainy as well, finding this area was great as you could sit have a beverage and then look around the city and mt fuji Fabulous.

The Sky Garden can provide wonderful 360 degree views from Yokohama Bay. If it is hazy or raining, don't bother as you won't see much, but when it's clear, you'll see for miles. There are signs above the windows pointing out important landmarks.

Its amazing tower and have world fastest elevater. it go up 64 blocks withing seconds..marvelous pictures square when we observed top of the tower.
Went up here in the early evening and really enjoyed the experience, Great views over the city in every direction. No cues and not too expensive either.

I have been here before but believe the view is worth the charge. I can't remember exact fee but around 1000 yen for adults and less for pensioners,kids. Taken up to viewing platform within seconds. you can spend as long as you like talking photos from four different angles

You have to pay a fee to go up to the observatory. Best time to go up is between 5pm - 6.30pm because you'll get day shots and night shots of Yokohama bay area. Yokohama is one of the most beautiful city at night. Overlooking the iconic view of the Cosmo World and

Top views but not sure if worth the money to see. Given we were staying at the Park Royal Hotel the views from our hotel room were spectacular without spending the extra for the Sky Garden. Annoying to be staying in the actual hotel and not being allowed to the bar to purchase a

On a clear sunny day, you will be able to see up to Tokyo Tower and Tokyo Skytree. If you are really lucky, you can get a fantastic view of Mt. Fuji. You can ask the staff before buying tickets if the skies are clear or not. Sometimes they give discounts if the weather is bad
This place is one the best place to have some drinks while enjoying the view of Yokohama and, if your lucky, Mt. Fuji!

The Landmark Tower can be seen from almost anywhere in Yokohama-shi. The area around it is pretty cool in its own right, but the view of it from this observation deck is fairly spectacular. I went at night, and the 360 degree view of downtown Yokohama is breathtaking. There were

Towers can tend to be too pricey for what they offer, but not the Landmark Tower. Not only were the views impressive, but the photos showing the views in 1993, and 2012, allows the viewer to get a feel for the development in the city over time. Even though we didn't see Mt. Fuji
This is a beautiful landmark in Yokohama, full of shops and restaurants. A nice building when viewed at night from the bay.

The observation deck is on the 69th floor and is free to enter. You can get great 360 degree views looking over Yokohama city and the bay with its impressive bridges. Definitely the best viewing spot in Yokohama

I honestly thought this was going to be a minor curiosity. Go up, take a look at the view and go back down. Done and dusted in 10 minutes. Boy was I wrong. First of all, the view is AMAZING. Maybe it helped that the weather was clear and sunny when I was there. In the

This tower has the fastest elevator in Japan. It is in the Guinness book of records! Cool. The view from the deck is great and in sunny weather you can see Fuji! The deck is never crowded you can enjoy it!
fastest lift in the World (Guinness book) for a very beautiful view on Yokohama on its port.. I would recommend to go end of day to stay for the night lights as well...
Lovely views over Yokohama at the Landmark tower, even better at night when everything is lit up. Great for some panaramic photography of the city
Loved the mall and the plaza Everything clean but not clinical The lift ride fab and the view 360 amazing No crowds when we went on a Tuesday Really interesting

Excellent location if you like taking photos. The trick is to get there just before the evening sun to catch the cross over to night view.
Good view over Yokohama and a great chance to see the sun setting over Mt Fuji. A little disappointed that it's cash only but at 1000yen for an adult it's very good value.

A great experience, from the ride in Japan's fastest lift up Japan's tallest building. Panoramic views of the whole Yokohama and Tokyo area, with Mt Fuji the main reason to visit/view. Restaurant on the observation level to get drink and food. Admission is ¥1,000.

This spot offers 360 degrees of overview of Yokohama and beyond. A nice time to go is the change over from day to night as the view changes so radically. On a good clear day you can see Mt.Fuji, which is always a bonus.

free for tourist to entrance you can see the yokohama bay with diverse colors , it's very romantic! good for photography! (bring your tripod)
Brilliant tower experience about $20AUS but worth it. Allow about 2 hours to view in detail each section. Clear day you can even see Mt Fuji in the distance.

Very good height & price. Suprised not busier! It's fantastic. Better than SkyTree as you can walk around, not busy at all when we went, a cafe to sit on their sofas and chill out for abit. Look at the views, so good!! Go here!!
Well worth the 1000 yen to get the 360º view of the skyline. Look at the old versus new pictures located along the periphery. Food in the building is just so-so.

I loved going to the top of this tower. The view was spectacular. I went in the daytime, but I'm sure the nighttime view would be awesome as well. I also liked the shopping on the lower floors. It's a must if you're in Yokohama.

Good place for shop and view all Yokohama and Fuji Sam from the Sky Tower, good experience and fun for all.

My second visit to this 360 dregree view of Yokahama and Mount Fuji. I went on a clear day with a friend of mine and this time I was lucky enough to visit on a clear day so we had a wonderful view of Mount Fuji. The tower is situated in a large shopping mall - an added bonus

Don't go here looking for amazing service or excellent drinks...go for the stunning views. Expensive, service & drinks a let down, but it's worth seeing it at least once- 70th floor with views over Yokohama & on to Tokyo.

1000 yen for adults 800 yen for students offers you a great view of the entire city and bay. You can see Mount Fuji on a clear day. Overall it's a decent value if the weather is great.
Whilst the entry fee is a little expensive I am glad we went. Seeing Mt Fuji is always a risk in the summer as there are many hazy days. Happy we went.

passed by and walked on this area only to see a lot of sights to behold especially during night time!

If you are into high buildings and great views I can recommend a visit to Yokohama Landmark Tower Sky Garden. Go on a clear day and you will see Fuji San and Tokyo. There is a cafe where you can get refreshments and sit and enjoy the view. I spent about an hour.
Pretty simple offering. Quick lift ride up. Wander around. Have a coffee and look all around. No surprises and worth a trip.

We did a few observation decks in and around Tokyo and I really enjoyed this one. We were lucky to see Mt Fuji which was a great experience. They do tell you before you go up if you can see Mt Fuji. If that's what you're going to see, you don't have to pay and be disappointed.

This was the second high building we had visited and it was so good. Access is good, the staff are so polite and helpful and the cafe up top is great for relaxing and taking in the marvellous vistas.

The Yokohama Landmark Tower Sky Garden is Japan's highest observatory deck. You get a 360-degree view of Yokohama city and beyond. It's worth a visit for the breathtaking view.
Every big city must have a view tower this this. The view of Yokohama is nice but no surprises. People could spend 30 minutes for look around here and enjoy the food on the restaurant here.

I visited Landmark tower with my family and it was not as great as I expected and pretty expensive, you can view similar scenes from any other building. Only elevator was impressive! It is not recommended to visit in the evening since you will not see the whole scene!
Fair price for entrance. Fast lift and very good service from the staff. Clear day and then a good view over the whole harbour/city
The highest building in Japan. A must-go landmark in Yokohama from where you can see the splendid panorama of Minato-Mirai.
Highly recomend to go to the 69 floor at dusk when all the lights are on. Amazing view for every side of the city.
Definitely gained the appreciation of the view once I made it to the top! The way up was exciting with the group I was in. The city is beautiful from the tower!!!!

The view was magnificent and gave a great overview of the city. It was a pretty clear day and we could see Tokyo Tower in the distance but due to cloud we could not see Mount Fuji. Well worth the visit to see how big the city really is.

A bird's eye view cannot adequately describe the scenic beauty you are given when you reach the top floor. It's a must try and at a good day, you can take a peak of Mt. Fuji!

This was amazing. Go up before dusk when the weather is clear. We saw the sunset with Mount Fuji and then the amazing city lights come on. We went in Summer on a Tuesday evening and it was not too crowded at all.

Located in Minaro Mirai, Yokohama Landmark Tower bring to you the perfect observation desk. In clear day, you can see the top of Fujji Mountain from here.

Yokohama Landmark Tower Sky Garden - there's perfect view of Mt. Fuji, Yokohama harbour and Tokyo Metropolis. In march there were no queues, so in 3 minutes very fast elevator takes me to the top witch 360 degrees view. I can definitely recommend this attraction.
