text.quote: Japan's largest Chinatown, with around 250 Chinese-owned stores & eateries & a colorful entry gate.
trip: Come to Yokohama Chinatown hungry! The plethora of restaurants can make choosing just one can be difficult. Other than Chinese restaurants, there isn’t a whole lot else here, save a Chinese supermarket or two and a couple souvenir shops.

Food was very good. Shops were mostly clothes, shoes and perfume. The streets do get crowded. I did not find anyone that spoke english but menus had pictures and some were translated. Excellent temple was there. They have guides and allow pictures which many temples do not.

The Yokohama Chinatown is supposed to be the biggest China town in Asia. However, I found it just average, with a lot of restaurant there. Some interesting street food, but it's all the same from the beginning to the end of the street.

I've been to China Town in San Fran, New York, LA, and a number of other cities. So, when my wife and I decided to visit Japan's China Town, in Yokohama, we just knew we were in for a real treat. Ha. The hardest thing for us, was trying to find a good (Chinese) place to eat.

Many shops here and well organised to walk around. Shops selling Chinese products and a lot of eateries serving Chinese and Japanese food. You can try the dumplings, buns and tea or coffee. Definitely crowded but many places to take a rest. There are at least two temples if you

always a good time in chinatown. there's so much to do and fireworks at many times of year. you can't go wrong with the pork buns scattered around the street and sometimes the places with the longest lines aren't even the best. you really can eat almost anywhere here... I've

Absolutely amazing area! The wife and I took the train in from Tokyo and headed straight here to explore. There are many Chinese restaurants to sample almost anything you can think of as far as cuisine goes. The attached picture is of a selection of dumplings we purchased

If you visit Yokohama, you should go see the Chinatown there. It is massive and the smells walking along the street are so good! So many things to see, shops, bars and of course chinese restuarants! On the street corner you can buy a giant steamed dumpling the size of a

We are big fans of all the different china towns around the world, but I have to say i was really unimpressed with this one, lots of restaurant all offering the same dead all you can eat buffet see pictures, we got 9 dishes and two of them were ok. I'd 100% not go back to the

The best china town I have been to. No nasty smells and the people are friendly. The establishments are small and warm. Good shopping with some interesting finds here. Go at night to see the lanterns lit which is beautiful.

The whole street was sold with baos, unlike London's Chinatown where they are famous for their duck, there isn't really a speciality meat in yokohama's chinatown. We ended up having a dimsum buffet that cos approx 1,700Yen per pax, was not really worth it and the Chinese food
A lot of chinese immigrants here. Much of the restaurants offer buffet meals. A place to get some simple souvenirs.

Chinatowns are living, vibrant communities with a diversity of restaurants, grocery shops, communal halls, etc. Check out NewYork, San Francisco, London. This Chinatown is huge and glittery, but walk-in the streets and lanes and you’ll find dozens of lookalike restaurants
A very large China town with lots of shops and restaurants. Easily accessed from the port for cruise visitors.

It's just like a movie set minus the kung-fu fighting. Looks good in pictures, but very sterile up close. Just a lot of shops and restaurants. Unfortunately we also had the bad experience of randomly choosing a restaurant with the worst Chinese food ever that cost us JPY2,200
A good vibe in the area, especially at night when the lanterns are lit and the steaming street food looks more appetizing. The gomu gomu (sesame ball) is a must try.

Of all the Chinatown places that I've visited, this is definitely my favourite Chinatown to visit. The buildings in Chinatown is fascinating to see as its fill with vibrant colors and also has that early 1900's characteristic to the building design. Yokohama Chinatown is also

You never feel unsafe but this place is very busy. 100s of restaurants and shops along a very walkable area located downtown Yokohama not far from the train station. Very vibrant even during the day but if possible go at night for it is very well lit. Some English is spoken.
We loved this place! Much nicer and cleaner than the San Francisco Chinatown. There was so much to see and do. Shopping and food everywhere.
Whenever we are in the Motomachi area we stop in Chinatown either for lunch or just to sight see.. It has a very beautiful Chinese temple but hard to get a clear picture due to the crowds.

Don’t forget to try Peking duck... and you can get to buy bonsais which you can come home and grow... they come in small pots all set to grow.... and then there are so many dumpling shops.... all neat and squeaky clean...

I came here with the sole intention of eating some great food and the mission was accomplished! The area is popular so prepare for crowding. There are so many food choices available that will make you hungry. Although there were model food sculptures in the windows, not all have

The experience of Chinatown with a Japanese flavour was quite unique. The food, so much to chose from and the blend of Japanese penchant for fresh with the Chinese flavours was truely delicious This was the best Chinatown I have ever visited
There are a wealth of restuarants to choose from. It is so colourful and bright. You feel very safe walking around here at night.
We saw it very crowded, and very empty the day of the typhoon! A very large Chinatown with lots of atmosphere, and of course, just too many restaurants.
Not anything worth rushing to see.we had a starter and were asked to leave when we wanted a main course as told it was after 10pm.all Chinatown closes down after 10 ??? Why.
A must visit for any tourists .such choices of restaurants .we took a taxi ride from the hotel . Reasonable prices . Some restaurants have dance shows

Chinatown was fun there were plenty of interesting shops and a bewildering choice of food from plethora of rstaurants. it is truly daunting and much against my better judgement chose my meal from pictures!! however, the noodles, soup, dumplings, pickle and fruit were all great

Awesome place to spend time and to eat great food. Has some cool.shops to buy souvenirs bit expensive though. Very nice vibrant place and don't forget to walk back to yamashita park and the beach side stroll. If you are in yokohama, this is the best place to be, apart from

The place was interesting and full of colour & vibrancy. We didn't stop to eat but there is a huge array of restaurants offering meals & snacks. I've only given it a 3 as it's very much the same as many other Chinatowns in other cities. Definitely go if you haven't been to a

Went a walk around this today in the rain and visited the temple that is under construction and the man at the door was lovely and showed us around. Visited the hedgehog cafe and then had these fab pork ball things in a take away that you can see them being made! They are
Visiting Yokohama the past several years has been a treat, because the Intercontinental hotel area is still going strong, and Chinatown in Yokohama is still about the same style as years ago!

After spending time in London's Chinatown, we now realise we have been spoilt. Terrible food (2 different meals, different places) means we would not go to Chinatown again, and why did we even go when so much of the Japanese food had been excellent.
Came here to eat on our first night in Japan - there's a massive range of restaurants and a good atmosphere

I was in Chinatown on a busy Sunday and it was heaving with people. There are lot of reasonable priced restaurants however I just grabbed some amazing steamed buns from a place I can't find on TripAdvisor. Worth taking your time to walk about and soak up the atmosphere.

The cleanest China town in the world, and also the best. People from all over Japan also see it as an attraction, that means it must be good if it attracts locals. Many restaurants with different cuisines, also interesting shops.
A very bustling area of town, very much worth the walk to. The streets were bustling and exciting with many great places to eat.
This is China Town colourful chaos. It is so busy but full of life - so many places to eat and/or buy stuff. Enclosed by a series of magnificent gates - even the car park looks themed.
Like most Chinatowns it was very colourful and busy. Mostly food but no one hassled you to visit. We had a good dim sum meal at a reasonable rice.

Yokohama China Town…what can I say. It's a busy, crowded place, like all things in Japan. The challenge here is to find a good place to eat, wher to spend your money and fill your stomach with exactly what you want. Good Luck! It is very hit and miss. But, just take a stab at
One of the best Chinatowns I've visited - it's huge, buzzing atmosphere, we enjoyed having lunch there.
Lively Chinatown with lots of shops and famed for over 250 restaurants. We did street food for starters and sat in a restaurant for mains. Look out for the Peking Duck restaurant which is fabulous!
Well worth the time. Go hungry there are so many great things to eat. It is a visual treat as well with more than the mind can absorb. Look for the panda bau buns.

Good place to get the feel of chinatown as well as some chinese cuisine and buffet - the queue for the hot bun and xiao long bao is too long too but you can feel the vibrant and activities in this busy street

This was an awesome area to visit. Last stop on the subway and an easy walk from the station. The food was great. Especially the soup dumplings! We also visited the hedgehog cafe and would recommend it.
But, having been to Bangkok's China town this one is not that great and feels like a big tourist trap. So I don't recommend visiting Yokohama for it.

Decided to have a walk around waiting before being able to board our cruise ship. Interesting place, lots of food and drink stall along with shops. Friendly people and not hassled which made it more enjoyable. Was a bit of rubbish around after the Typoon and a bit hot and humid.

It’s basically a shopping and food street. Clearly targeted at tourists. Good for a walk around, and there are plenty of restaurants there catering to all food types, so you won’t be hungry. Can get very crowded with tourists, so if you’re not big on crowded areas, this may not

We have been to Japan many times over the last 2 decades. When in Yokohama we visit Chinatown for sushi, sashimi and black sesame ice cream. The place is lively and vibrant especially at night. The food variety is exciting and reasonably priced. Eat what the locals eat and

We were told this is the largest Chinatown outside of China. Not sure if this is true, but it is still a most interesting place to visit. We had dinner here one night. The restaurants vary in cost from very inexpensive to quite costly. But there's lot to choose from to suit

It is not unlike other Chinatowns in major cities in Japan or other countries with all its hustle and bustle surrounding the numerous Japanese-Chinese restaurants and shops selling sundry goods and trinkets. The outstanding point is perhaps the explosion of colours of the place
Just an ordinary China Town for me. If you have some time to spare while in Yokohama, then you can have a stop by.
A nice area to walk around. It is not like other Chinatowns and is quite touristy. Lots of restaurants if you are after something different.

Streets of Chinese foods. Amazing. Many stalls offer familiar food such as bubble tea, little dumplings, and many more. Japanese and many other cuisine foods are offered too. Near yokohama station exit.

Fun and vibrant place that is full of life and colour. Rarely quiet this bustling centre of all things Chinese in Japan is a must see. A huge variety of shops and eateries selling delicious food at every step of the way.

My wife was born in Yokohama and she came here as a child , it’s vibrant and full of life , lights and variety we decided after 40 years to come back and visit , we had a really great time , would recommend as an alternative to Japanese food and culture while in Japan..

Apparently it's one of the largest Chinatown's in the world, but doesn't feel big to be honest. Easy to find and easy to walk around. Good atmosphere, plenty of street food and restaurants and of course the obligatory tut shops and tourist traps.
Went to do shopping for cheap things and to eat Chinese street food, also both oolong tea , in china town you can have the best oolong tea,actually it is always cloudy there until midnight
The place is not too big but there are too many good food there. Lots of restaurants and street food. Love the desserts store too! Definitely the highlight of Yokohama.
Yokohama Chinatown is like any other china towns offering many shops, restaurants.. Do not expect much but it's good for a quick visit
The complex is huge with a lot of various chinese restaurant and store. Better have a map or you will get lost there

This place is big. And with so many restaurants it’s almost impossible to choose from. In the end we decided to follow the lines and eat where there was crowd trying to get in. That paid off. The food we had was fabulous. So much to see as well. Definitely worth the visit.

The two times we visited Chinatown was during Golden Week so you would expect the place to be buzzing - which is an understatement - it was packed - wall-to-wall full of people. In fact we were on the Akai Kutsu (Hop-On Hop-Off) bus and the journey that should have taken 10

It isnt too big, but if you're in the mood for some chinese food or street foods, give it here a try. You can probably do some gift shopping as well as some street food shopping as well. Duration of about 1-2 hrs might be good for this area.

Our local friend suggested we go have lunch in Chinatown. We had actually been to Beijing a year ago so it was fun to see the Japanese version. It was very cool to walk through and have lots of things to take photos of. We stumbled upon an excellent chinese restaurant that we
Very typical China town. Chinese goods and resturants of all types Cantonese and Szechwan. Greta way to spend some time in Yokohama. Very old China town here with a long history
Fantastic district with hundreds of restaurants and different shops. A must place to go in Yokohama.

Absolutely worth a walk around! Day or night it is really something to see. We were walking around until 11 pm and felt totally safe! We bought some great souvenirs, had awesome street food and were surrounded by unbelievable sights!

Nothing spectacular for a Chinese, but probably interesting for non-Chinese. Most of the shops do not open until after 10am, and many are simply chain shops spread out all over. Also noticed many fortune-telling shops around, targeted at local tourists.

Have ventured to many Chinatowns around the globe however this one is quite sizable and has about four entry gateways. In the evening the signage of the restaurants and storefronts really illuminate the area,very reminiscent of Hong Kong and Macau. Pretty touristy but has
Would be a nice place to experience Chinese foods and culture in a different setting- Japan :). After all, this is one of the largest Chinatown in Japan, and established since 160 years now.

Having been to China, I did enjoy the atmosphere in Yokohama’s China town. The streets had traditional gates, lanterns, and other decorations that tell you exactly where you are. We passed by very early (~9:30am) and the stores and restaurants were just opening but there seemed

As I have been to this place many times but love the cuisine here and every corner has something very good for you and the city Yokohama is the best as it’s big and still the environment very clean green and quite . Love with this place

Easy and fast to get to from Tokyo with just 1 train stop. Also within walking distance from the train station in Yokohama. The grand Chinatown arches are impressive with rolls of eateries & restaurants along the main walkway. We should have tried the street food eateries that
A large number of shops and restaurants. Lots of choices, and a shrine. Can be a very busy area. Lots of fun to visit.

Yokohama Chinatown is considered to be the largest in Japan. And even in the world. I doubt about the world, because I've been in many. I can't even remember all: Santo Domingo, Sydney, Adelaide and Melbourne, San Francisco, New York, Bangkok, Seoul, Kuala Lumpur, Singapore. I

I went to have a quick look as it's so famous. I arrived in the evening and with the lights, it's very atmospheric. There are a lot of Chinese restaurants, but there are also Chinese cake/pastry shops, other smaller cafes, sushi places and souvenir shops. I tried a little xiao
The lights were fantastic in the evening, many types of restaurants, fun to explore. Many small shops selling interesting items.

I visited Yokohama China town back in 2005. It has certainly changed and the only thing that I can recognize is the temple. What brought me back is the atmosphere. I love the crowd, the buildings and the eatery. It makes me feel like I am in China but cleaner... Highly
I had great time waking around. Chinatown Searching for resturat and sights It's was really great experience

we were meeting with friends for lunch in Yokohama‘s chinatown, it was a monday, but the streets were already busy and crowded. the delicious smell of chinese kitchens was everywhere. great experience...
The atmosphere was gut but it was quite hectic. Nice small shops and restaurants. Good place to go for a little Walk.
It was a very busy place .There are lots of restaurants to choose from not just Chinese food.Lots of souvenirs shops.There some side streets with red papers lanterns
Bring your Spirit of Eater and try Chinese food and Japoneses in a street full of stores. The decorations are unique.

Walking around Chinatown was awesome, great dim sum and Chinese food. There were two beautiful temples with incredible architecture. Several streets had decor over the entrances. Many restaurants offer all you can eat options, but these are not buffet style you order off the

It takes about an hour from Tokyo to get to Chinatown and I just don’t think it’s really worth it. There isn’t much to do there and all the restaurants sell the same things - shanghai dumplings, roast duck, the same types of rice and noodle dishes. We went to the animal cafe
China Town in Yokohama, very crowded, there are many restaurants options along the way, but worth visiting
This is a nice Chinatown with lots of good food options. It is very crowded and a bit hard to get around, but worth visiting.
This is a Small china town in which vendors sell the same goods. This neighborhood gets packed. The food is meh.

Crazy, packed, busy and FUN! We were in Chinatown on a holiday for Spring Solstice, and we were so fortunate to see a parade and all sorts of fun stuff! We bought trinkets, ate steamed pork buns and just enjoyed ourselves!! Bring comfy shoes, a backpack and money for all the

The area itself is picturesque but it is very touristy Basically it is restaurants, palm readers and knic knack shops over and over again. We enjoyed walking around for about 40 minutes but we have been in larger and more authentic china towns elsewhere in the world. I
This is a great Chinatown! Food was awesome and we had fun just walking around and doing some people watching.

This is a fun large Chinatown with food everywhere. Most businesses seem to sell food with lots promoting all you can eat lunch deals ranging from ¥1680 to ¥1980. But our advice is to ignore these and queue for food off street side stalls. We had soup dumplings, fried

Not an amazing tourist spot, unless you are staying nearby. We spent an hour travel there from Tokyo, not too far however we found that the whole street in Chinatown basically is selling the same food and same products. It’s not amazing but could make a very short visit for a
Chinatown is an eclectic mix of shops, healers, food stalls, restaurants, and bars and well worth a visit.
all kinds of foods , goodies &souveniers you can find in Yokohama Chinatown..accessible to train station & other parks ..a must see part of yokohama.
If you are looking for some Chinese food for lunch this is the place to be. Some shopping can also be done in this corner of Yokohama.

As its name suggests, China Town is a small china in Japan. You can eat the best of Chinese food while in Japan. The advantage is that it is located close to many tourist attractions of Yokohama such as Land Mark Tower, Red Bricks shopping mall and others. worth knowing
Busy couple of streets, noisy, interesting restaurant window displays to look at. I can imagine it gets busy when Chinese New Year is celebrated. Supposed to be the cleanest Chinatown in the world

Yokohama chinatown ( apparently largest in the world ) was amazing. The streets strewn with lanterns and lights stretch on and on and on seemingly never ending as you wander past Chinese shops and restaurants. As I let myself get lost in the streets I felt as if I was really in
My partner and I had a great time exploring China Town. It has some amazing Chinese shrines. The detail is fantastic. Loads to do, see and enjoy

One of the biggest Chinatown in Japan. Housed over 300 shops. Honestly I have not been able to cover the whole area even though I have been there a few times. Still get lost in the maze of all the Chinese shops. I sometimes wonder how the shops survive by selling the same food

We had lunch at Chinatown the day we arrived and it was its usual high standard. The restaurants and tea rooms are all excellent and just comes down to what you prefer. It is still the best Chinatown I've been to.

Despite being in Japan which is a great place to explore, spending time in China Town in Yokohama is a must. For the food lovers this is the place to be as the fragrances of China and South East Asia envelop your senses. Dont hesitate to stroll along the back alleys where some

We arrived by Princess Cruise ship and took a cab to Chinatown. This is a pretty big area to walk and checkout. The area has around 250 Chinese owned businesses. Exploring the many street and alleyways is half the fun when visiting. If you are into photography, this is a
Wonderful street food and a raft of restaurants to choose from. Would highly recommend a walk down this area’s various streets and alley ways - there’s something for everyone!

We stayed at the hotel in Yokohama and visited this China Town. This one of the tourist attraction in Yokohama. We have spent there about two hours just walking the street, trying Chinese food and enjoying the crowd. Vet clean, colorful and comfortable place to spend some time.

When I 1st went here many years ago. It had a quaint feeling with street vendors that worked under canopies that had clothes hanginv above them from the apartments above. It is now mondern streets with lots of shops and resturants. The food is excellant and we went there

A friend took us here - so many streets of yummy Chinese snacks and comfort food, Chinese temple, and shops selling everything - we found the side streets had cheaper pork buns than in the main tourist streets.
This is a very unique Chinatown and well worth a stroll around. Lots of restaurants and shops to buy gifts. Also well worth taking a photo or two.

Had recommendations to come to the biggest Chinatown in Japan. But other than many restaurants that sell similar Chinese food (and these were just average in taste but tourist-priced!), there was nothing exciting about the place. Nothing to shout about and can be missed!

The Yokohama chinatown can be reach by the subway or walking. We walked from the Cup noodle museum which took about 20 minutes. As it was the winter month, there was cold wind blowing so it was not tiring. The chinatown consist of a few interlinked street filled with shops

A great place to come sightsee, tourist friendly. Many little pockets of surprises in the little alleys lined with lotsa shops and restaurants. I highly recommend to visit the chinese temple While you’re here
quite a few massage parlours, plenty of chinese restaurants, special trip not recommended, visit if you're in Yokohama..

An abundance of restaurants and eclectic shops. The restaurants range from up-scale, to casual, to take out windows. A popular tourist destination and high school field trip spot. I saw multiple groups of teens from different schools shopping and dining in the area.

You only need a 5-minute walk from Ishikawacho Station (by JR) to this place. There is nothing special about this place and like Chinatown in general. You can buy various souvenirs and taste Chinese food in this place. From this place, I walked to Yamashita Park, which is only a

We arrive after a long flight from LAX to Heneda AP and then local bus to Yokohama for boarding our cruise. We walk on block to Chinatown and everything we saw on the internet was right. The whole town is about food, one can pick among 142 dishes, any number of times and as long

A lively China in Yokohama is the best way for me to describe it. Literally thirty seconds across the street from Motomachi-Chūkagai Station and a five minute walk from Ishikawachō Station. There is a lot of things you can do and see here. Expect a good amount of walking.

Chinatown was packed. There was enough “room” for another couple of people, but not much. That’s the one downside to the Tokyo area. There are a lot of people. A lot. And they were out in full force in Chinatown yesterday. Not as crowded as the Meji shrine in Tokyo last April –
Like all Chinatowns, there are lots of choices and price range to fulfil your personal needs. Very popular to grab some dumplings early on the morning before restaurants open.
Very interesting place, full of shops and restaurants. Looks nice an the evening with illumination of street lights.
Most large cities have a Chinatown and Yokohama is not any different to any of these and this Chinatown is worth a visit albeit much similar to others that you may have visited before
It was ok but not as interesting as it was cracked up to be , part of the problem was that it was raining and a lot of places were not open

We walked around Chinatown on Friday evening. It felt very safe and was clean. There are many restaurants and shops. Have cash for some of the vendors. Nikuman is everywhere to choose from. There are ATMs near. We would return.

Yokohama's Chinatown is like so many Chinatowns around the world, with lots of restaurants and food shops. Gaudily decorated arches mark the entry points to the district. Thought I might find a museum in there somewhere telling the story of Chinese migration to Japan (and why a

Thoroughly enjoyed visiting Yokohama’s Chinatown. It’s not just Chinese shops here but all Vietnamese and other areas are represented too. Great for buying souvenirs, especially the food and drink variety. Lots of great restaurants too.
We walked to China Town again a very interesting part of town with good food and shops to visit lots to do
China town in Yokohama looks like most china towns with endless stores with food and cheap goods. Only recommended for a walk through
The Chinatown area is vibrant. It is also very clean and comfortable. Lots of good eating options and the obligatory souvenir shops !!

Depending on the time and day, Yokohama Chinatown can be super busy and crowds everywhere. Lots of places to eat. Prices varies a lot, cheap to expensive. Close to other attractions such as Marine Tower and Yamashita Park. Close to cruise terminal about 15 minutes walk. Very
It is a must see place in Yokohama! The China town is huge and fully packed by different restaurants and grocery or souvenir stores. There are also a few beautiful Chinese temples around.
Lots of food places, some with huge queues so you know they're good. I got an amazing pork & veg Bao from the store near the little pagoda/park area

Just half an hour from Tokyo, Yokohama offers you one of the most beautiful sea front and Chinatowns of the world. The colourful Chinatown is packed with restaurants and shops plus a gorgeous temple. I had some fried soja noodles and a beer for 1.500 yens that kept goofing

I've been to the one in Chicago, San Diego, New York, Hawaii, Singapore, Australia and the one in Japan is abit better. More food places. Dumplings galore and many snacks. Went to one of them fish pedicure things, that was fun. In all just fun to experience it in Japan. Nothing
Pretty large Chinatown. We have been to many around the world. Visited on a Sunday, super crowded! Lot of dim sum places to dine at. You can walk from the cruise port.

It's a good sized, typical Chinatown, with so much more in quirky shops, massage parlors, spiritual palm readers everywhere, it was fun. Sadly most of the food we tried was less tasty than hoped for, bladder and dressier than expected. I'd just enjoy the vibe and wait to enjoy

Many streets of shops and restaurants to please everyone. There are a couple of temples that you can pay to enter. One was being restored and not open. A few people were dressed in "traditional" dresses, very nice to see.
There are so many delicious Chinese restaurants in Chinatown! So many small alleys and shops to explore.

We've been in Japan for three weeks and Yokohama Chinatown is the first time we've been disappointed with somewhere. It's just a tourist rip off, worst food at ridiculous prices. If you visit we recommend you just walk around and take in the sites, sounds and smells and then
One of the largest in Japan. So it’s worth at least to walk the streets. Also you can get real food from china

This is a rather large Chinatown in the busy port city of Yokohama. This our second visit and we arrived by cruise ship both times. Chinatown is only a 15-minute walk from the cruise ship dock and is well worth your time!
We had a great time here, so many restaurants and things to see. It was wonderful. So much better and bigger than Nina Town in London.

The Chinatown was one of the largest that we’ve come across. However, in terms of offerings, it seems to be repetitive. Nikuman (or bao), Siew mai, and fortune telling dominates the scene. There are a lot of Chinese restaurants around which is a pity because you can only eat at

Go to the Kobe Chinatown! This Yokohama one is a must-Skip!! Worst Chinese food I have ever put in my mouth. We ordered this roasted duck, since it's a famous Chinese dish, but it was the worst roasted duck ever. The moment you put it in your mouth you can tell it has been

The place is nice and so interesting but don’t be fooled by the cheapest food they are offering like less than ¥1000 set menu but rather choose set menu that are a little expensive like ¥2500 and higher. It worth your money.

Having travelled quiet extensively I have seen many Chinatowns and frankly they are all the same (not surprisingly) Whilst always very colorful it’s basically a string of cheap end restaurants. Nothing special here.

My motto in Japan is ‘if you see a queue, get on it’ and this did not fail us for the soup dumplings! Yum! Chinatown is an assault on your senses - absolutely throbbing with people, amazing food everywhere you turn and the smell of all that amazing food just means you don’t

I had long wanted to revisit Chinatown because of fond memories from the 1980s. It was unrecognizable. Earlier, there had been neighborhoods, and a feeling of authenticity, whereas now it seemed mostly a tourist trap, with mediocre food and chaotic signs and souvenirs - somehow
Really nice large Chinatown. Lots of nice gates and Chinese style buildings. Very clean and pedestrian friendly. Good food and atmosphere.

At Motomachi-Chukagai station(Minatomiral line), walk towards Exit 2 出口. On street level, look for Chinatown80 and pick up map of Chinatown brochure. Look for blue icon that denotes 'food'. Check out these street food in Chinatown a)Tung Fat Egg tart ¥180 b)Endosei ¥500 pork

Fun to wander around, mostly all food shops and stands. There are several little stores but even wih the sale price (they all seem to have a sale) most everything was way over priced!. Just go hungry and walk around and eat!
The cleanest Chinatown I’ve ever been to. The people are also the most polite. Many yum cha places to try, so your dim sum craze will be satisfied.

huge that expected with a lot of all-you-can-eat restaurant, however, those was not special but worth to try if you were there. No need to select those with too many choice of dishes as you wont be able to try all in one go !

I haven’t been in the area for close to 10 years and it has changed. When I was there close to 10 years ago, stores seemed to be repetitive and buildings were rubbed down. They really cleaned up the area and prices are pretty decent.

Maybe we missed the mark on what Yokohama Chinatown has to offer but it was unexciting and somewhat dull. Perhaps we were there too early, perhaps it was simply a quiet day, unfortunately sad to say, been to better Chinatowns elsewhere. But nonetheless, good to look at, lots of

Don’t go for the all you can eat deals. The food is mediocre and not worth it. Spend some money and go to a decent restaurant in Tokyo. Temple charges money to enter. You have to purchase ¥1,000 incense to be allowed to pray. Have never experienced this as a practising Buddhist
We went twice here but first time with Chinese food buffet. Food was suck and bad quality. Better to pay a little bit more to get something more quality and delicious.
Typical Chinatown lots of shops and places to eat. Easy to get around. Not a lot of signs in English. Silk garden is near heard it is interesting but did not visit.
If you miss beloved Chinese food, this is the best place to enjoy some delicious eateries on the street and in one of the many restaurants around.
It's the largest China Town in Japan, with nice food and good price. The only bad part is that it wouldn't open until after 11:00am.

Came here for dinner after exploring the Minato Mirai area. There are plenty of places to eat with many restaurants offering all you can eat deals with food fresh from the kitchen after each order. There are many things to see and do here. Plenty of palm readers here too i you
This is a rather unique area of Yokohama. There are many shops and dining places with Chinese goods. Overall the prices can be a little high, depending on what you are looking for.

This should be the largest China town in Asia. There were plenty of restaurants and eating houses apart from the many souvenir shops in the area. The street shops would look more lively when illuminations were on. The street was clean and tidy and worth to have a stroll there

Nice neighborhood, plenty of places to eat and shop. If you are coming to Yokohama, one place to visit is the "Fish Doctor". Aquariums with tiny little fishes will give you a foot massage that you will gladly remember. Nice place to walk with family and kids.

There is pletiful food available from walk-up quick food to take out from inside grocery/gift stores, to sit-down cafes and restaurants. Oh yes, good bakeries too. Food can seem expensive in Japan, so the cheap eats places were welcome. There are two or three temples in
This Chinatown is biggest Chinatown in Asia. The feel is same as any other Chinatown. If you are in Yokohama good idea to visit.

The restaurants there are all similar, either Bau or eat all as you can. I didn't taste any but Bau is still recommend for tasting for travelers. The atmosphere at night is great, good for walking around. For eat all as you can, I don't think it is worth to try.
There were no real surprises here. There were plenty of food options but we found the prices were quite high compared to normal street/cafe style eateries.
Been to a few Chinatowns in Asia. This one is packed with people. It's one of the larger ones, lots of restaurants, gift shops. Good place to people watch.

It was a pleasant surprise waling at Chinatown in Yokohama. Apparently it's one of the biggest Chinatown's in Japan. There was lots of food on offer, mega sized pork buns, all you can eat restaurants and desserts. Tucked away on one of the lanes is an old bottle shop where you

We found it hard to find because we walked but found later there was a station nearby. Lots of street markets and stalls. A great place to buy cheap eats. Loved wandering around looking at all the stalls which are common in any Chinatown.

We've been to many Chinatowns in the world, and this is one of the better ones. First of all, it's surprisingly large, clean, and well-lit at night. There are lots of restaurants and places to eat. But portions are small, and it's not cheap to eat here. For best food, try

Spent an afternoon exploring the many shops and eateries here. It's a little larger than I expected. I didn't realize how many Chinese immigrated to this area. You can get authentic food, unlike the ones you find in the USA where they make everything for the American palate.

This is arguably the largest Chinatown in Asia outside China. The four entrances are glamorously built with different meanings. Interestingly is the variety of food from different parts of China in such as a small area, ranging from Beijing, Sichuan, Cantonese, Shanghai,
Gives a good insight into a slightly different kind of Asian culture. Good Chinese food as well as a nice spot to acquire some omiyage.

It is Japan’s largest Chinatown and you might need a compass to find your way. Apart from food, there are two 2 temples, Kanteibyo and Masobyo you may want to visit. An interesting spot you should not miss is the senshutei (public toilet) of Chinese architecture (of course).

If you like snacking, and Chinese snacks in particular, this street is for you. With that said there's an abundance of 2500 yen buffets you can choose fromif you're extra hungry. Otherwise just roaming around the streets trying anything you fancy is good too, you'll get juicy
A must see while your here in Japan. Lots and lits of food.All you can eat.Street food and all kinds of shops. Enjoy

We arrived before most of Chinatown was open. Mostly they open around 10 am, on Saturday anyway. But we did find a great little restaurant open early. It was good to wander around anyway with few other people.

It's a bustling active area, crowded with sightseers and locals. Essential place for your China grocery supplies, and catch up on Chinese food. Usual shops selling overpriced trinkets, and higher end shops catering for the discerning tourist
No need to worry about being hungry when you visit here. You can enjoy a lot of Japan style Chinese food here.

Nice bustling area, welcome to the biggest Chinatown in Japan! has a couple of main roads, you can easily see on the maps around the area. Don't forget to checkout the Chinese Temple, it's pretty unique! price of restaurants tends to be high compared to other Chinatowns around
Red paper lanterns, bustling people and many smells of fresh food being made as you walk through corridors of winding streets. There are stores to pop into and get trinkets or just people watch.

I took Tokyu-Toyoko line (Minatomirai Line - continue from the same vehicle) until last stop and alight Follow the sign board and look out for Chinatown (中华街）exit Easy to identify. I like the 生煎包the most.

Amazing area, dizzy and confused, magmatic and immersive..shops of any kind,oddities,smells and food, pandas and fortune tellers in the same area! An incredible melting pot that makes your curiosity boil! An unmissable mix of postmodernism and chinese elements as contradictory
On weekends it is better to avoid Chinatown due to enormous crowds everywhere and long lines to all restaurants. Restaurants' employers are not welcoming to foreigners
Aside from a few Chinese looking arches I wouldn't really say this is a genuine Chinatown! Most, if not all the restaurants and bars are Japanese.

Biggest China town in Japan with loads of activities round the year. Proximity to Yamashita bay and Motomachi street makes it a perfect place to visit during the weekend.

A great wander after dark to see the local restaurants and life. Probably one of the cleanest Chinatown districts I have visited (well it is Japan after all). Good restaurant options plus classic Chinatown gate. Worth a wander if you are staying locally.

If you have any other option, just go for that instead of wasting your time in chinatown. You'll only get rude behaving greedy merchants and a crowd. It is neither China nor Japan!

Feast to the eye and stomach! Great vibrant place with lots of authentic food to choose from. Go to places where there is long line, they will not disappoint you! Only downside is most people don't speak English and most menus are not in English, hence, if you follow the line
Many things Chinese although we were in Japan. All kinds of Chinese products can be bought here. Good to take a leisure stroll through the streets.
Visited Chinatown in the cool evening of Feb. Lots of chinese restaurant, buns shop and fortune telling. A interesting mix of chinese culture in Yokohama.
No complaints from me. We have been here a few times and is always nice escape from the house. Lots of Chinese food options for sure.
This Chinatown is immense! I enjoyed walking around ogling all the treats and had a bun or two. Very clean and had a fun vibe.

Great area to grab a few chuhi's from the conveni and have a walk around - try different kinds of food, and just take in the vibe. Its super busy and some times you have to line up for a while at the food stalls but its worth the wait.

Omg. This place is a perfect place to try all kind of Chinese and Japanese food. It is so crowded and various of traditional food. I came there in the Chinese New Year 2017, the streets are beautiful and full of restaurants. You can try many delicious food here. A must go place

I love to walk in Chinatown, and eating on the numerous Chinese and Taiwanese restaurant over there. During the winter is really suggestive. Do not miss the old and new Chinese Temples. A must in Yokohama.

It's been long time and numerous visits to Chinatown. There is always something new and fierce competition among restaurants offer great value to customers. The current trend is buffet style deals days and nights at various places. Lunch set menus are also great deal. Enjoy

Amazingly huge, organized and attractively glaring in red.. Must visit when in Yokohama especially during Chinese New Year time. Makes you forget that you are in Japan. Had lunch in Tung Fat restaurant.. Nice and tender roast duck, siew yoke with char siew, the fried siew Mai
Not recommended for those coming here for shopping and chinese as there is nothing atypical of a chinatown else where.

The Yokohama Chinatown is HUGE!! From here a few minutes walk will take you to Motomachi Street with lovely shops. There's oodles of dim sum and Chinese restaurants and we went into one hole-in-the wall to eat and it was delicious!
Nice area to visit for a visitor and local alike. Good selection of restaurants although you tend to pay a premium for the privilege
There were so many gates & plenty of xiao long bao shops around the area :-) Excellent spot to take picture with the gate. You can also buy lots of cheap souvenirs from the stall.

This is the best place which you can taste Chinese food in Japanese style. If you like cute panda, you will be enjoy for shopping the panda products design such as dolls, sweet with panda printed on its package.

China town is very nice but most of the shops there are restaurants I went to San Francisco china town and I remembered a lot of shop to buy souvenir and cloths Here is really nice but few shops to buy souvenirs The restaurants are very good!
We were there on new year, so it was very busy everywhere. Many great places to dine and it does look like you are in China. We enjoyed it.

We were pleasantly surprised at how larger Yokohama Chinatown is. There are lots of restaurants and a lot of shops that sells Chinese and Japanese snacks, & souvenirs. It is a place that typifies chinese towns - noisy, lots of people, colourful. There's also a chinese temple in
yokohama chinatown is 2nd largest chinatown next to New York but for the cleanness and safety , yokohama is the best everyone can enjoy for food, shopping, or even just walk around
Same China town other country. But I suggest fresh dumping. you can walk to Yokohama bay from here about 500 m.

Lots and lots of restaurants - from dim sum to sushi. Everything seems good, but food looks like it is largely guangdong and Japanese Chinese style. Also includes tourist shops and small markets, but not the large Chinese markets you might see in NYC. It is a very clean

this is totally different place from other places in Japan..lot of crowd in there...but you can see the china tradition in there and there is a 3D arts museum and it is very nice place hope to visit there again some day

Yokohama Chinatown is one of the biggest Chinatown in the world. There are loads of Chinese restaurants (Japanese style), places to eat - lunch and dinner and some souvenir shops. Other than that, there is really not much to do. Visit this place only if you have some extra time.

As with most of Japan, our evening visit to Chinatown Yokohama presented us with a very clean & organised atmosphere. It was a very short taxi ride from Intercontinental Grand Yokohama, costing approximately ¥1000. There was no shortage of dining & bar/entertainment options. We
By far the cleaniest China Town I have been to , Everything seem so commercialised to attract tourists . Walking distance to the pier to enjoy a beautiful sunset view.
Everything just doesn't seems real, it is too touristy. Nothing interest us much. All the shops are selling the same stuff
This a tourist area where you basically just wander around the streets and lanes and take in the colourful sights and smells.Nothing extraordinary but glad we went.

This is a great place to wander through side streets and junky tourist shops. We had fun exploring all of the gift stalls and restaurant windows. All the food stands we passed smelled amazing! Good photo opportunities everywhere!

This a large Chinatown! The food and shopping are abundant. I recommend you walk through in the morning and at night if possible. In the morning its quiet and you really get the opportunity to see the architecture and decoration. At night it is vibrant and full of people

This town is loud and cheerful regardless of weekday or weekend. There are many restaurants and it requires lots of research to pick a right restaurant. Also popular restaurants have 1-2 hour long line to wait. If you like, you can spend all day here. Relatively quiet morning,
Mostly restaurants and nice to stroll. One block from New Grand Hotel and Yamashita park. Sit down restaurants and street food as well. Also very nard to find but there is a 100 yen Daiso store

Very similar to Kobe Chinese town, just way bigger. Lots of places to grab a snack, souvenirs and Chinese restaurants. Almost always packed with people, both locals and tourists. But overall a nice experience!
Supposed to be the largest Chinatown in the world. Many many places to eat and shop. Extremely clean and people friendly.

We were there on 6 Nov (Sunday) and the place was bustling with people. The size of the Chinatown is much bigger than the one we visited in Kobe and has a lot more restaurants here. An interesting to visit when you are in Yokohama
Chinatown offers cheap food of course chinese food is available and also other stuff like tea and it has a lot of Panda stores.
Walking around the market is very exciting. Chinese food all around and some souvenir stores as well. Worthwhile visiting

I was told it's the oldest and largest Chinatown in the whole world. Having travelled a bit and checked out the Chinatowns all over the world...this one is the biggest fail. It's so tired looking, shops selling the same kind of food - roasted chestnuts, buns..etc. the souvenirs

Felt like a part of the culture. Welcomed by many food places with samples and treats galore. Worth the walk through.
Quite small compared to San Francisco & Vancouver Chinatown. We went for some Chinese Porridge at one of the Restaurant. Good experience !

If you're there visit it. Various restaurants and shops. I like the street food. Hard to tell you which restaurant to eat at because there are so many. I would tell you which one to avoid but I don't remember the name. I'm sure there's probably better ones than the one we went

We visit chine town at Yokohama evry evening.It s very nice big and full off deliciose restaurants. Full of impresive lights frendly envirment collorfull shops. I highly recommend for everyone who come to yokahama

Characteristic? Enough...Colorful? Yes...What you can see? Restaurants, restaurants, restaurants...little essence

Best place for dim sum!!!lots and lots of restaurants with good food; best place to buy souvenirs .I am from Florida and never seen such a large China Town.Lots of cafes serving drip coffee, we even tried Kopi Luwak.You will need at least a half a day to spend there.

We were there October 1st, national day for China. There were lion and dragon dance parades, lots of music and dancing. It was great.

My God ... I was kind of lost and my Google Maps App was guiding me ... I was kind of nervous and suddenly I found a lovely and magnificent place with a neat architecture ... pagodas and more ... lots of place to have something to eat and to buy curiosities

Lucky one night at Rose hotel before I go on work. Just went out of my hotel door and there I have China town. Clean and relax place

Possibly the most colourful & culturaly interesting area of Yokohama. Spoilt for choice when it comes to food, many intriguing looking restaurants & cafes. Also many Chinese shops selling imported products from China. There are also Japanese shops selling more unique & quirky
Good place to get cheaper souvenirs. We could not find any halal food outlet, maybe we did not look enough. Easily accessible via JR lines/subway.

We came on a very rainy day and couldnt really enjoy it.. We didnt find good shops, things were much cheaper in Tokyo. I dont think you should wait to get to Chinatown to buy presents. Asakusa, Shibuya and Harajaku offer a way better options. But is a nice place to visit, like

Like much of Yokohama near the city center, Chinatown feels like it was built very recently and did not have the same awesome craziness and energy as Chinatowns in New York or San Francisco. We had a good meal. Would visit on next trip to Yokohama, however, the size does not

I took a walkabout at 10:00 am so most of the shops were just opening. Few hour later I bet there will be lots of more people among other tourists. Here you can find the souvenirs for sure. Lots of things to see and buy and food to taste.
Like a lot of chinatowns around the world you will find a list of restaurants and tourists shops. What is missing compared to NY or SF is real life.
Larger than most Chinatowns elsewhere but otherwise identical. Crowds, restaurants, noise, and very hot on the day we visited. Probably OK for a meal.

I can say not only good Chinese restaurants but unique souvenir shops. You can find roasted chestnuts some Chinese fast food.

There is nowhere in Kanto area of Japan where one can enjoy double Kawaii of Chinese and Japanese. We are not attracted to all you can eat dim-sum restaurants but small take out snacks were nice to walk around the town.

Our day trip to Yokohama included a customary visit to its famous China Town and this did not disappoint. The place is huge, busy but well maintained and clean unlike those in Europe. The delicious all-you-can-eat dim-sums (100s to chose from) were to die for and good value at
Walked through Chinatown at lunchtime. Very warn and typical Chinatown. Very busy but great atmosphere. Visited Buddhist shrine and had a pork dumpling. Great day

Mostly restaurants that don't really cater for us Gaijins, not much in terms of other shopping, there are better ones around the world.
We're spoilt with good Chinese food in Melbourne, so we shouldn't have gone to any chinatown in Japan. Big mistake. Worthed a picture and that's all.
I reached this place walking from the Yokohama int. Port, I expected to see a different Chinese atmosphere, but it wasn't and it took my time and energy!

Colourfull, overflowing with restaurants, though language is going to be an issue in many of them. A handful of restaurants had English translations on their menus, but speaking to thewaiters was difficult in most cases. A very entertaining couple of hours, best seen after dark.

As this was my first trip to Asia, I wanted to experience also China. This is possible in China town - many restaurants, many shops od different price levels from very cheap to very expensive. All the shops did close at 22 o´clock, the restaurants stay open but do not sell food

Lively and busy it's a short bus ride from yokohama minato mirái. There is a beautiful temple and some nice Chinese restaurants some of them pricier than others. Nice for an afternoon stroll. Lots of souvenir shops as well

We walked to Chinatown from the Pacifico conference centre through yamashita park. This is a very clean, neat and organised Chinatown with lots of restaurants and shops. We were lucky to watch a hungry ghost month parade too!

Very typical of a China Town, lots of restaurants, really, lots! Shops selling a great deal of Japanese goods too. Worth a walk through the lanes. It was too hot and humid today, choose a cooler day.
We loved walking around the area which is in the heart of Yokohama, as strange as it may seem the food is not great we didn't care much for what was on offer.

Heavenly to find some Chinese food after eating Japanese for weeks. A great chinatown with bright lights and so many restaurants so well priced too. Don't miss this chinatown it is spotlessly clean and has a great atmosphere.
We had a stroll through Chinatown, visited the temple, and had dinner here. It was interesting. A lot of the same sorts of things though. Occasionally some interesting foods and herbs for sale.
there is a big china town.many restaurant moreover street food is delicious and comfortable. walk in this street sometime is crowded.

Just like any China town. Lots of small Chinese shops selling cheap stuff. Lots of restaurants. Nothing fantastic perhaps good for an evening dinner or lunch
There is a lot food,gifts shops and in general interesting things to see. Must go place if you visit Yokohama.

Yokohama Chinatown is the biggest Chinatown in Japan, and it is an important touristic attraction. In my opinion, it is however too commercial. It is rather for tourists than for Chinese residents in Yokohama.
