We came here on a rainy day and this probably explained why the crowd was so few. We were not extremely impressed by the shops as we could see them in our country too. Nevertheless, the locals seemed to like it a lot. I guess its appeal was that it had gave you an exotic feeling
For some reason I like to experience each countries Chinatown. This one was was impressive. Pick a restaurant and enjoy all you can eat for $20pp. The food and atmosphere was excellent.

We walked through here on the way back from the top end of Motomachi to the SeaBass terminal. A more downmarket and dour area is hard to imagine. Every street is a mix of fast food outlets of the worst variety and tourist souvenir shops of the trashiest variety. We didn't stop

I was told to visit Chinatown as it was worth going to and it did not disappoint. Lots of street vendors selling wares and restaurants to sample. Only 3 blocks and easy walking distance to/from the harbor.
If you have time then go there. You are visiting japan! So unless you are chinese there is not much too see. Also the food here was terrible.
Just an area packed with Chinese restaurants. Maybe a good attraction for tourists. There are also a few temples in this area.

This is a very large Chinatown with hundreds of restaurants but very little else to offer. We were looking to shop and so were lots of other people which meant you couldn't move in the one or two shops which appealed to us. Go there to eat if you are game, we thought the

The entry gate to China Town is probably the most impressive thing about it. After that, it's just streets and streets full of cheap tourist novelties and all you can eat restaurant with mediocre service at best. Unless you have the money to spend and then you can go to one of
Interesting to start but became less so. The place was just a grounddog day of dumpling shops and shops selling the same tourist things. A few nice temples and features but just too touristy.

We walked through Chinatown after 7pm. It was alive with people. All the shops were open and the place was full of restaurants offering different priced meals, from minimum street cart food to cheap meals to expensive fare. Great for people watching, and night photography. It

This is a large and clean Chinatown with shrines and temples to visit. There are of course a zillion shops and restaurants. Additionally you will also find street vendors selling snacks. We go often for date night and always find it enjoyable.
One of must see place in Yokohama. This area you can have good Chinese food. The most famous Chinese food in japan. Most of restaurant there have buffet menu but some are set menu.
Very clean Chinatown. Nice to walk around and have a meal. Lots of shopping and resturants. No need to spend more than one hour

Such a beautiful place... You can spot it easily thanks to the big chinese Torii at the entrance of the street. Lots of shops and restaurants around, you can have a nice walk and be fascinated with some facades, buildings, parks, temples, peoplet, etc... We did really enjoy our

With so many shops lit up, Chinatown is a great area to walk around in the evening. Enjoyed a well priced, delicious meal at one of the restaurants. There are so many shops to look at and so much character. Just leave yourself enough time.
Very nice to visit night time, it's full of shops and places to have something to drink and eat. A bit expensive somewhere but worth to visit!

One of the largest Chinatowns in the world, this is a great place to wander. Very clean and enjoyable to walk around. The children enjoyed the big pandas everywhere. I loved seeing the pretty temples (also very pretty at night). Great food everywhere.

It's really food, food, and more food! You can really get a ton a food snacks and many restaurants to choose from to dine in. On the flipside it is really commercialize, you can tell that it is really geared to entertainment and attract tourists! I would suggest visitors to

I had travelled out to see the Imperial Palace in a brutal rain storm and was utterly disappointed. Just wanting to get back to my hotel and call it a day (staying in Kannai) I decided I needed to eat and would try food from a street vendor in Chinatown. The weather cleared,

I've been travelling to Japan for over 20 years and have visited Chinatown a lot over the years. I'm sorry to say that on this visit our food was very bad. We made the mistake of going into one of the big street front restaurants and to be honest felt ripped off. The food was

After the first 5 minutes of walking through the town, one will see redundancy of products sold. Multiple vendors try to entice you to eat at their restaurant. We ate at a restaurant although I would not consider it top end dining, food was OK.
It's a great place for Food. Loads of street food and restaurants providing Chinese cuisine. It's a fun place to visit and very safe although it is located close to a very down area of Yokohama.

Everything seems to be overpriced for what they are. I've been to a few restaurants around there, but didn't find them impressive. On the street, many places sell meat buns, but the price for one bun ranges from 350-500 yen. Wow. I think I can find something much better
So many things to buy and see and taste and hear. We had an excellent sushi meal, an exquisite Chinese meal and a delicious cremia cone

So many restaurants, so many shops, so many people ! Always very busy and lots of fun ! Love this vibe just like China but clean !! Eating, Drinking, Shopping and having some sweet and shopping again ... We enjoyed very much !!

I enjoyed the visit to Yokohama China Town (located nearby to Yokohama Baseball home) but became fed up with the endless food outlets and smells. Was worth a visit but not a place I will rush back to.
Grew up in the Bay Area, so I know China Town! I understand the pork buns, but what's up with the water chestnuts? Worth the visit.
Yokohama's china town is great, lots of shops and restaurants. Karaoke bars the lot... so many places to visit, open late too.... you won't be disappointed with your visit to Yokohama

As with Chinatowns in other parts of the world this is a colourful, vibrant and lively destination with great food shops and restaurants. Clearly it is a great place for reasonably priced food and a late night stroll.
Lots of food shops and restaurants, a fantastic gilded temple, an array of interesting shops for gift buying

If you getting to Yokohama Chinatown by train and holding JR Pass, you can alighting at Ishikawacho Station by JR Negishi Line, and start walk around from here. Surround is chinese food restaurant and snack stall, but some look like Japanese style, even staff is from Chinese
You can see chinese archways and eat some great food here. The dumplings from here are particularly popular with the Japanese.

This is a typical China town precinct which has been here for a very long time in Japan.I think it was the first Chinatown in Japan.Its food is typical Chinese,with lots of greasy street foods on offer with spruikers trying to get you to buy their stuff.Prices are on the high
We had a nice stroll and some good dumplings but wouldn't make a special trip there. There is a superb Chinese restaurant with very flashy 10 course meal but I don't know the name.

We've been on a rainy evening and because of that there wasn't much activity on the streets.. I guess this is why I was not that impressed about the place... it seemed lifeless. I also expected to find more shops, instead it was mostly full of restaurants. We picked up randomly
Lots to see, people, food, temples. Tried the soup dumplings... different but very nice. All very tourist orientated with prices to reflect.
google: Come hungry! Yokohama Chinatown is chalk full of delicious Chinese restaurants. Avoid the places where hawkers are trying to pull you in. There are so many other superb restaurants - spanning a wide range of cost - that you’ll do well doing a bit of advance research. Enjoy!

If you miss and crave for something Chinese in Japan. Yokohama Chinatown is the best place. You can also get the  Minatomirai pass for approximately 800 yen. It will save you a lot of money 😏 to go back and forth from Tokyo.
It a good tourists place to go, maybe the snacks are fine but the restaurants are not recommended.
A great place to spent an evening at this place. This place has Vibrant and colorful shops and buildings, great restaurants and beautiful Shrine.

It is big and has a nice atmosphere but the lack of variety in food was a big disappointment for me. A lot of copy paste restaurants selling exactly the same thing, that it’s hard to distinguish one restaurant from another. If you’re looking for authenticity, you will not find it here.

It was a great experience walking through Chinatown and sampling the authentic road side Chinese dumplings. There are beautiful Chinese shrines and stores along the road way which give off an atmosphere of being in China. It was a very fun visit.

This is a very fun place to spend the afternoon.  If you are a foodie and like Chinese foods from different providence's, then this place is for you 100'S of fun eateries here.  Make sure you try the Shanghai meat buns or pork dumplings. …

Get your more confortable pair of shoes and be ready for the adventure.
The food variety is amazing so don’t get breakfast that day and be open mind.
Prices are very good and lots to do and see here.
The neighborhood is very busy but not chaotic, just take your time.

text.quote: Family amusement park featuring a huge Ferris wheel, a high-speed roller coaster & other rides.
trip: Cosmo World is a nice amusement park with the kiddie rides on the mainland and the adult rides on the man-made island. The kids would surely have a blast because there is also a village made specifically for them. You have to cross the bridge to get to the adult section of
Just gonna give this one a 5 stars because I successfully propose to my girlfriend here, I'll visit this place again and again. It's a very relaxing theme park, not overcrowded.

Yokohama always have something hidden in its sleeves I had to try one slide with my kids which six months ago was not possible because my younger was not tall enough It was real fun a bit wet but we had fu 😁
We really enjoyed the view from the ferris wheel in the evening. So many lights and the bay of Yokohama.
If you do not have kids, do not waste your time. Nothing else to say. Go for Disney, this is just a local small park with silly stuff for kids.

It's a good place to hang around. Try ferries wheel and if you can roller coaster. Rest of the attractions are sheer waste of money. But nothing like walking from China town through yamashita park in the cold evening. Simply awesome. Stop at red brick warehouse and click few

Lines are a lot shorter when paid for individually, rather than the US standard of paying park admission. We experienced Vanish! (the pink coaster that dives into a tunnel in the water), the beautiful ferris wheel (which offers some fantastic views of Yokohama Bay), a 3-D laser

The park had only a few persons besides me and my boyfriend when we went there. It was about 6-7 pm. The ferris wheel was nice and we didn't even have to wait in line. The price was decent (about 800 yen if I remember correctly). This is no Disneyland but it's fun and I

There's no entrance fee and you pay per-ride. We went on a weekday during the Summer school holiday season but the place was very empty; I.e., no waiting line. My kids (both 12 y.o.) loved it, but I found the rides short and very expensive. Can easily blow 10000 yen in 2 hours

This is definitely an area geared towards families with children. It is not a large amusement area but probably enough rides to satisfy small children. The most interesting feature is the giant ferris wheel with the digital clock. The ferris wheel is amazing at night when it

Great roller coaster park right across the road from a shopping center. Free to get in, rides were about AUD $7 each, great food, you must try the crepes! OMG! Cool rides, very clean for the amount of people flooding in and out, I recommend even if you just want to walk around

This Park size is not too big compare to most theme park yet it has it's charm. Probably because of the location as well and those ferris wheel is truly incredible. The only downside maybe was the overprice tiket per ride? but me and husband just went there to enjoy the

It's not often you find a park like this in the middle of a cityscape. It offered a bit of fun for a while, paying for each ride, or a ride pass, no entrance fee. The views from the ferris wheel (Cosmos Clock) were great.
The rides here are pretty expensive. The roller coaster was fun, but the haunted house ride, which cost $6 per person was very stupid.

A fun place but not too many rides and has some was hard to figure out the opening hours. It does have a larger arcade area for skill games. The best ride is the ferris wheel which can give a good view of the city and has an interactive map of what you are looking at.

This place is great and I hoped to spend all day here with my son who was just at the height limit, but the day got rather expensive because you have to buy ticket with set amounts to use each time you ride vs paying to enter the amusement park. Also, if you are 100 yen short,

When we went on a week day the place was like a ghost town. We were pretty much the only ones there! There's really not that much to see. We ended up going on the big wheel which gave a really cool view of the bay and Yokohama. We had other things we wanted to see so we didn't
I love big wheels. Absolutely fantastic views of Yokohama Bay. Really enjoyed it and good value. Would recommend it to e everyone.
Went too late, and they are closing soon by 7pm, suggest to go earlier as there are a few rides for young kids as well. And pretty sight at night.

We went to Cosmo World just to ride the ferris wheel, which the kids loved. It cost about $60 (AUD) for our family of 6 to ride and it takes about 15minutes to do the loop. Being a drizzly day meant that the views weren't as spectacular as I think they would be on a clear day,

As a group of four we spotted the theme park in the distance, marked by the giant ferris wheel, and were suuuuper keen to go have some fun. The park is well setup and offers a whole bunch of rides from log rides to roller coasters as well as traditional carnival stalls. You
It’s great for couples to have a romantic experience. One of the landmark in Yokohama area . Once you’re on top, you can see the whole view of Yokohama

The park is separated into areas for different ages, so it was the perfect place to take my 4 year old to kill a few hours we had in the area one morning. The Ice World was a bit of a rip off but she loved the other rides like the Family Banana Coaster, and Merri go round, etc.

There’s no entrance fee since the tickets to rides are sold separately. The wait for the more popular rides could take up more time, (the roller coaster took us half an hour) but you could probably finish your visit within a couple hours. If anything, it’s worth dropping by for

Free Entry, Pay per ride; 800Yen for the Ferris Wheel I timed it perfectly and even with the 20minute wait to board the wheel I reached the top at perfect sunset point and was able to get great photos of Mt Fuji between 2 buildings. Lots to do in this complex, some rides
We stayed at the Intercontinal hotel and loved walking around this park. Unfortunately the large Ferris Wheel was close the entire time we were there because of the wind.

The park was free to enter, however the rides are sold individually. This is a great place to take photos of the beautiful night view of Yokohama. Definitely worth the visit. Do stay till night time as the Ferris wheel is beautiful.

Came with friends for youngest son birthday. It also happens to be the beginning of the Pikachu Outbreak 2018 week. There’s no entry fee as the attractions are pay as as you. There’s personal wall lockers to store your belongings at each ride. This can lead to longer wait times

A fun little park to visit, had some rides as well as arcade but we had a lot of trouble catching it while it was open. Ferris wheel does have a display to tell you what you are seeing but not very comfortable.

We only did the Ferris wheel ride, lots on offer however, if you have the time for some fun. Ferris wheel ride was affordable and the views excellent. Roll coaster looked excellent and also some other daring rides on offer also. Located in a lovely setting, well laid out and

At 370 feet, or 33 stories high, once the world's tallest ferris wheel, holding a Guiness World Record. The iconic attraction is impressively lit at night with dazzyling rainbow colour combinations, can be seen for miles, and is often the focal point of evening photographs of
Often visit when they open in evening , located besides water channel from the sea. Many play stations include very high ferris wheel, landmark of them. Recommend for all kids and teens.

Cosmoworld is a small amusement park right in the middle of all the actions in town. It's right across from the World Porters and Cupnoodle Museum, across the bridge from the Queen's Mall etc. It's a small amusement park but with two huge, noticeable rides--the roller coaster
The main roller was probably the best ride, and as basic as this little amusement park is, it was a great little family outing at night after dinner.
Apart from the Ferris wheel, this was a typical theme park with nothing outstanding in particular. The arcade games area was small and a bit of a rip off actually.
The Ferris wheel is impressive day or night. They light it up, and it can be viewed for mile. A bit too high for me though. Must be 25 stores.
A good place to go without planning. We had really fun taking roller coasters. It was better to buy multiple tickets in the end. Waiting time was not long considering it was public holiday.

I past by this amusement park in the morning while heading to the Cupnoodles Museum. The distinctive ferris wheel has a large clock display at its centre, is a focal point for photo in this bayfront area. I returned in the evening to enjoy and capture lightings of the ferris
A round takes around 15-20 minutes. The baskets are a bit small. 4 people is ok in one. At night the lightning is nice, of the machine.

Located in Cosmo world amusement park, Yokohama. It is a giant ferris wheel located in Minato Mirai. It has 60 passenger cabins and takes about 20 minutes to complete one round from starting point to the top and back. It is accessible from the JR Sakuragicho station on foot.

This is my second time going to Cosmo World. It's just a fun little place for adults and kids alike. Carnival games that you can play & a good handful of rides to have some fun. I rode the Ferris wheel once again. But this time it was at night. Come here in the evening to

what a great little amusement park with roller coasters , a large ferris wheel that doubles as one of the world larges clock at night . with many rides and thing to do , Beware that you can not get a all day ride pass. you have to paid for all rides, a great park in Yoko

It is located right in the middle of Minato Mirai 21 and the kids had a good time there. The rollercoaster was awesome but too short a ride. Not to mention you had to pay for every ride. There was no all day pass at this place. You could get a little bit of discount by buying
A fun and well facilitated little "theme park" situated near landmark tower. Great fun to visit with kids as there's lot to do and see.

The Yokohama Cosmo World is a pretty typical carnival with rides, games, food, etc. The distinctive ferris wheel is beautiful from a distance and taking photos, and is worth going on at least once, but it's hardly a must-visit.

We swung by after visiting the Cups noodle museum. Old school amusement park which did not appeal to my teens. Even the most thrilling ride they could find in the park, was a piece of cake and wasn’t thrilled at all. To be fair, this will appeal to younger children. If your

I'm already in the area. Let's see the views from this huge ferris wheel. It'll cost you eight dollars to go up & it'll take around 15-20 mins to go completely around. Well, it was worth it. The views are awesome & I don't think you'll be disappointed. Also looked pretty good

A short walk from Yokohama station, we initially visited cosmo world to check out the Ferris wheel (cosmo clock 21). The Ferris wheel was great and the information about other local attractions was useful. After the Ferris Wheel we went to the arcade. We had fun trying to win
Went here to ride the ferris wheel. The ride is worth it especially at night -- you get spectacularly good views of Yokohama for ~15 minutes.
if you take the big wheel, you can use the tab to get the tour information in Yokohama. you should not miss the chance to take the wheel. Inside the wheel, you enjoy the different night view.

If you are looking for an amusement park that has no entrance fee, this is a must try. The fee is per ride but they also have a ride all you can or combo. Plus, if you come in a group, you can receive discount like buy 2 take 2, buy 3, take 1 tickets per ride. I'm just not sure

Cosmoworld is an average park with various rides. There is a roller coaster that dives into the pool. A giant Ferris wheel called Yokohama cosmo cloc. Smaller rides for kids. Parking a bit of an issue. Overall not too bad for a few hours and also you can have a walk around
We tried to get on, but no time. I take time to shoot some photos and asked price. It was 750Y for adult. Hope this help TripAdvisor users.
Its a free entrance yet you need to pay for the ride. No queue so far during weekdays . Ride the ferris wheel . Great view of yokohama even you can see the skytree tower .
Been here numerous times already. Never fails to entertain me and the kids. We love the games and the mini rides for our little ones. Also great for photography and perfect for sightseeing.
My son very interested to try the Vanish Roller Coster since we saw it on yo*tube. So we let him to try it alone, then he gave us his big smile, and asked for more.. hahahaa..

As my title says, I would definitely recommend this place for you who want to go for a localized type of date, or even if you just want to get some nice pictures from the huge ferris wheel (what I did) after the sun's past the horizon.

Awesome amusement park in tha middle of everything. Easy to find, thanks to the huge ferris wheel. Insanely expensive thou. On ride to any machine is around 700 - 800 yen per persion. We had four of us so do the math. 😁 On the other hand you can easily get sick with these

The kids begged and begged to go on the giant ferris wheel at Yokohama Cosmo World and we weren't disappointed. It's a very large Ferris wheel (cosmo clock) and consequently a very long way to the top. Excellent views and an interactive screen to tell you about local

Cosmo World is one of the highlights of Yokohama. The ferris wheel is one of the main sites in the skyline. We didn't have time to go during the day, so we decided to check it out at night. Everything looks amazing all lit up. However, it was really cold and windy the night

Our family has fallen in loved with the roller coasters in Japan and we have visited many areas and ridden various different ones, but one of the more interesting ones would have to be Cosmo World's which plunges into the water!! Our last visit to Yokohama was only a couple of

The jet-coaster is so fun because it goes fast! Water sprays at you when the jet-coaster goes under the ground! The jet-coater is very scary because it goes up very high and then down quickly like a rocket, so fast. It feels faster than a car!

Visited the park with our grandchild. The highlight of the park was the Cosmo Clock 21 Ferris Wheel. Some of the cars are completely clear. The view was absolutely amazing across the city. Entry to the park is free, but you buy tickets from the booth for each ride. A great

My kids enjoyed it, it's kind of small, but separated as cluster, the best thing is to go and spend your morning then go to the near mall across the street to ha e a refreshing juice or cup of coffee while your kids are dozing off on your lap. Really a memorable experience

Good stop to have a little fun. There are a few rides but the must go ones are definitely the vanishing roller coaster and the ferris wheel which gives you a great view of the city. Note that it uses a pay per ride system. So you have to pay for each ride. No entrance fees

It's not Unevirsal or disney but this place has sooooo much positive energy. People are having fun. Kids are enjoying . The location is super good. The price is low. Good is good. Family fun day. Take pics and enjoy the positive energy all over this town. Dr SD 2017.

This park has pay per ride system, which means you just need to pay for the attraction that you want. My goal was the vanishing roller coaster. It was under maintenance when we came, but fortunately it's back on running just before we left. They have a small park that is nice

Took the ferris wheel at cosmo world and the view from above was fabulous. The entrance to the park itself is free and the fees for the ride on ferris wheel only 800 yen. Best time to visit yokohama cosmo world definitely at night!

Built in 1989, one of the largest ferris wheels in Japan. From 1 November 2016 to 28 February 2017 the Yokohama Cosmo 21 Ferris Wheel features its Winter Light Up. The 60 spokes are illuminated in various combinations of dazzling bright coloured lights, the patterned sequences
Great place to visit at night. No crowd wonder how they stay open perhaps busy during warmer months. More people during the day. Free entry only pay for rides & food.

The ferris wheel was about all the excitement we could manage at the fun park as we are well past being thrill seekers. The large wheel (100 metres diameter) gives superb views over the city and harbour as it rotates gently over the 15 minute rotation.
This park has a few basic rides. Nice to enjoy at night if you're bored. Ferris wheel is a definite must do.

Yokohama is about half an hour away from Tokyo, taking the JR line. From the train station its an easy walk and also with good view over the harbour. There are quite some fun attractions to play or just take the big wheel ride (800yen) to enjoy the birds view.

The Cosmo Clock ferris wheel is one of the largest in the world, and an iconic symbol of Yokohama. It is a great experience to ride the wheel and come near the top of the highest buildings in the city. The other attractions (log flume, roller coaster, etc.) are also enjoyable.
Amusement park with the light show to match!!!!!!! Spent a lot of money but it was worth it!!!! Highly recommended!!!

It is a nice place to spend the evening. However, the cost of the attractions is quite high if compared with a park such as Disneyland. For a nice view of the city, I recommend their Ferris wheel, which is very popular with couples in the evening.

A place to go to pass some time with the kids, a little expensive for the rides. Recommend getting the 2000 or 3000 yen pass to get a little discount and that way you don't have to keep going and getting tickets.

After dinner we walked down to Cosmo World as it looked very appealing with all the lights and rides - it was great! I found it to be relatively cheap (there was only the two of us). We had a go on a few of the rides, and went around the Ferris wheel which offered amazing views
Awesome roller coaster, have to do the eye. Lots of fun for little ones and big ones alike. Really affordable, pay only for rides you want to go on. Very cool on a hot night.

The 100m Ferris wheel which doubles as the worlds biggest clock is a landmark, ensuring you'll never get lost in Yokohama (or not know the time). Go at sunset and try two things: the wheel and the fun roller coaster. The first gives you the best view of the harbour and city

Yokohama is my favourite place in Japan. In 2012 on my first trip i saw this place from a restaurant window from Landmark Tower, but didn't venture down. However, i was absorbed by the clock so when i got home, i looked into it and thought it seemed fantastic. When i went back

I really enjoyed my trip on the ferris wheel! I had just arrived in Yokohama and wanted to get a good view of the area and get my bearings. This was an ideal first port of call and so glad that I took my camera because the views are stunning!

This is a funny place - not big, but we did have a lot of fun with the japanese attractions - bright colors, loud music, everything is cute. The ride with the wheel is expensive (800 yen), but we did it. As my japanese friend recomended, we did try some vending photo. This was
Its very beautiful, not far from the Red Brick Warehouse. Its a fun place to be with, especially for couples. The ferris wheel is the highlight of the place. It is romantic.
A nice place to enjoy with friends and family. Book one of the ferry rides and enjoy different shooting games inside this fun park

If you like big wheels then you'll love the view from this one. You can see across to the Yokohama bridge and allegedly on a good day, Mt Fuji, but I can't confirm that as it was hazy in the distance. It states it's 800 yen each but as there were 3 of us they charfed

A great theme park! You can purchase tickets for each ride and there is no admission fee. The rollercoaster is very unique disappearing into the ground. It makes for some fantastic pics at dusk. Check opening hours as its closed on Thursday's.
We were actually in our way to the ramen noodle museum and walked through this cool place! We did some of the rides and went to.rhe arcade .

If you are on a date, this is where to go. If you're by yourself, this is where to go. The theme park itself is extremely small with only about 10 activities, including a splash mountain, haunted house, 4d theater, rollercoaster and most importantly - the Ferris Wheel. This is

The Cosmo Clock is here. The big ferris wheel that you can see from all over Yokohama. You can even see it from the Sky Tree, on a clear day. A cool little amusement park right in the city. The view from Cosmo Clock is worth the trip.
This is perfect palace for family. There is a lot of activity's. Rollercoaster are cheap but arcade are cheaper in the city. Near by there is a shopping center and pretty bay.
Cosmo World is an amusement park for adults. The main attraction is a ferris wheel, which is a symbol of Minato Mirai area. The area is not big, but a nice place for date.

I think Cosmo World looked and sounded better online than it was in person. In fact, online it made it seem like it was a lot bigger than it really is. When we arrived, we were a bit disappointed by the size and the activities. The indoor arcade had much of the same games – many

This park is charming in a slightly dilapidated way. It is free to walk through and conveniently located between two shopping malls and near the Cup of Noodles museum. You pay for rides on an individual basis with rides costing around 400-700 yen. I visited in the day time and

This place is well worth a visit. When we were there the big ferris wheel was lit up at night. The lights were quite stunning and came on every 15 mins and ran through an array of designs that you could stand and watch. Riding the wheel gave you an amazing view of Yokohama,
We went there because of the sight from the Ferris wheel "Cosmo Clock 21". A very nice experience. If you want to have an overview of the harbor, try it.

We had a few hours of fun on some amusement rides, ventured onto the log flume and watched the beautiful sunset on the ferris wheel. We also had another go with one of my favourite ever Japanese things, their wonderful photobooths!
I went there after cup noodle museum and you will able to see the overview of Yokohama from the Ferris wheels. Spent half and hour here.

We all know Japan can be expensive, but this seemed a little too expensive. We looked forward to the roller coaster but were disappointed as it was a very quick ride. If you are dying to go to an amusement park, why not? But there are other more interesting things to do

Yokohama Cosmo World is hard to miss; located close by Landmark Tower and Queen's Square. The once world's tallest ferris wheel, Cosmo Clock 21, stands tall in the Yokohama skyline with screaming visitors on attractions zipping by. Entry to the park is free; each ride costs

We went up the Cosmo Ferris Wheel clock just as dusk fell over Yokohama. You can enjoy a superb view of downtown Yokohama and out towards Mount Fuji (if you are lucky). It takes about 30 minutes to go round and is well priced compared to other ferris wheels I have been on.
A Yokohama landmark that should not be missed. The mental image I have of Yokohama is this infamous ferris wheel. The view of the skyline is just beautiful especially when it gets dark.

Went w/a group of photography buddies, so even though we didn't try many of the attractions, plenty to keep us interested. Great view of the lil bricked up river, and the rides, and took many good shots. Had fun people watching whilst meandering around the place. Do be careful

Cosmo World is one of the most fun and picturesque places in the Tokyo area. Located right on the water, it offers great views for all to enjoy as you walk around the park and ride the rides. This is simply a great place for a family outing. The only reason I didn't give it "5

Its an outdoor activity/ fun park area for kids. there is 1 ferris wheel and a couple of rides/ video games for kids. Nothing great about it and not really worth going, unless you are simply wandering in the city

this is a rare theme park which is situated near by the skyscrapers.There are no entrance fee and very reasonable price compared with Tokyo Disney Resort which costs more than 7000 yen.At night lighted up and riding Cosmo Clock maybe the best date spot in Yokohama

If you are travelling with children they will love you forever if you take them to Cosmo World. It's a place all ages can enjoy not just children.
Yokohama Cosmo World is a nice little theme park. I enjoyed Vanish - The Diving Coaster and it is also great to look at. I also enjoyed the cold freezer room attraction.

This is NOT Disneyland. It is a compact amusement park with some great rides, very conveniently located. We had two hours to look after the grandson while his mom shooed nearby and this place was ideal. All reviews have already noted the view from the Ferris wheel. The other
scaled-down version of amusement park and thrills. decent costs. lots of shrills.this ferris wheel is famous in japan.

A lot of fun, you can't beat the view from the Ferris wheel. Only bad part about my visit was being told my daughter was tall enough to ride the attractions at the ticket booth and then getting turned away at every ride.
i thought the roller coaster that disappeared into the water would be pretty cool but it was just pretty meh... and the place was generally pretty empty. not much going on.
If you have younger childern this is a good place to take them for rides and fun. Not Disneyland, but not crowded either

I like the coaster which run through tunnel in the middle of the water pond. Plenty of in house ride which is also good gor a raining day.
a good place to have a good day of fun. There are alot of amazing rides and fun. Be sure to try out the ferris wheel.

This place is really fun, there is loads going on. A roller coaster, a log flume, the big wheel, kids attractions, you won't be bored! Definitely make a visit here!

This is thing that you need to do in Yokohama. The Cosmo World is full of enjoyable for kids. Yokohama clock is fabulous. Just sitting and chill out, you will be love it. The fun Park is starting from 500 yen. Better go in the evening to see lighting. The weather is quite cold

Don't forget to try the Cosmo clock. You may have to wait a long queue. Don't worry if you forgot to purchase a ticket at the entrance. You can do it at the counter on the same floor where you will get into the carriage. Second interesting for me was the flints tones car!

Cosmo Park can be a fun place if you're in the right state of mind. It can be quite romantic and/or thrilling. The place is kind of a bust during the day, but once the sun sets and neon sets the sky ablaze, this is the time to check it out. There is no fee to enter and
Fun cheap satisfaction. Try ALL stations highly recommended!! Worth the money and awesome thrilling rides, haunted house, ice land and game centre. Fast queues. Worth every penny!

It literally takes zero effort to go to Cosmo world if you are already in Minato Mirai. I highly recommend it if you have children with you who don't quite understand why being in Japan is so cool, so you can get them super tired and go about enjoying the rest of your day :)

Cosmo World is nice place to go for enjoy on your day off. First, you can feel free to go Cosmo World, because of a price system and a location. Normally, we need to pay high cost fee to enter these scale of theme parks in Japan. As you know, Tokyo Disney Land® and Hujikyū
Lots of fun! The Ferris Wheel is definitely a must do for an AMAZING view of the city for only $500yen.

I was keen to experience the wheel / clock to see the views, and I thought it was worth it to see the panoramic views. The cars don't swing in the wind (a relief), and although the ride is short, you have chance to look around in all directions. We didn't try any of the other

The world's largest clock Cosmo Clock 21! Beautiful views of the Yokohama Bay area. Definitely a must see for anyone traveling to the area!
Good value if you don't want to pay a hefty entry fee and not go on many rides. Most rides are ¥500-100 per person. Great views from the Ferris wheel.

If you have kids and you are around the area, don't miss it. It's not that much big, but your kids will enjoy the rides with less waiting time compare to other places in Japan. Very clean and well maintained equipments and safe.

If you go to Yokohama, it is almost impossible not to see the Cosmo wheel, iris the largest in the world. We took a ride at night and the view was spectacular. Well worth the entrance fee. The roller coasters are good, one even goes underground! But in reality it is just another

Even you are out in the Yokohama area and want to spend some time on a few rides, then this place is pretty good. The good side is that you only pay for the rides you want to ride. The downside is you have to pay for each ride you want, which can get expensive if you want to
This is a cute little amusement park. Free entry you just pay for the rides you want. Definitely recommend the Ferris Wheel

The giant ferris wheel at Cosmo World is visible from so many places, it's a real drawcard. I really liked the fact that you don't have to actually pay to get in, but can walk in and check it all out before deciding which ride(s) you want to go on. I didn't have to queue to

The Yokohama Cosmo World offers a nice walk amidst the busy tourist areas of Yokohama. I love taking photos, but did not try any of their rides. No admission fees. Recommend a walk in the afternoon / late afternoon / sunsets.
I really enjoyed Cosmo World! The rides were fun and there some yummy treats to be had. It's a fun place to spend a couple of hours.

Went there on August 1, 2012 and got to ride the "diving roller coaster" (for 700 yen). Very thrilling and fun didn't have time to go on anything else though since there were so many people there waiting to see the 27th Kanagawa Shimbun Fireworks Show. The firework show was very

This amusement park is right on the water in Yokohama (part of it is even separated by the water across a bridge). The setting is very nice, especially when the sun starts to set and all the lights come on. One good thing about Cosmo World is that there is no admission fee to
Most excting Ferris Wheel i ever did see. And the biggest! Cosmoworld was plently of fun, especially the excilerating roller coaster Vanish.
google: Perfect for a sweet evening, some rides are closed due to coronavirus. Else total cleanliness care is carried out. There's a Hawaiian town nearby - food+shopping, that's cool.

I think, I have fully utilized my 900Yen by enjoying the moments. It has lifted us in such a height that we can clearly see the beauty of the city as well as the sea. Also it was moving slowly and we have got chance to shoot more photos.

I really liked this place! I rode the water log ride. So cool cause you can sit with your partner in the same seat very romantic and fun! I also rode the ride at the top that turned around it was such a thrill to be turning around so fast …

text.wiki:
Yokohama three towers are a group of historical towers at the Port of Yokohama.  They have been given the nicknames The King, The Queen and The Jack.  The best view of the three towers is considered to be from Ōsanbashi Pier.


== Three Towers ==
The three towers are:

Yokohama Customs building (The Queen)
Kanagawa Prefectural Office (The King)
Yokohama Port Opening Memorial Hall (The Jack)


== Legend ==
There is a legend that if you go to a place where you can see all three buildings at the same time your wish will be granted.  The origins of this legend vary with one version being a foreign sailor whose wish came true after looking at the towers.  Another version talks about how these three towers are lucky because they withstood the 1923 Great Kantō earthquake.

		
		
		


== References ==
text.quote: Landmark red-brick building with a 118-ft. clocktower, used for public meetings & completed in 1917.
trip: A welcoming reception and invitation to explore this colonial building. Spectacular and well kept interior. If you have the time, check it out, the building is stunning and the history very interesting.
It's an amazing colonial building declaring the port vocation of the city. Go inside to see the well-kept interiors.

The casual visitor sees a classic, but not very old building, some pretty stained glass windows and beautiful old stairs and floors. Most of it was rebuilt though, and not that long ago. Nice for a quick view, and there's an English-language brochure on request.

text.quote: A city landmark, this 860-meter cable-stayed vehicular bridge features dramatic night lighting.
trip: Japan is a different "world" and the Yokohama Bay Bridge is just another true example fo that. It was like the brother of the Rainbow Bridge in Tokyo.

I cruise a lot and have transited under many bridges. But this one in Yokohama is only surpassed by the one departing Copenhagen in my estimation for excitement. I'm sure glad the Captain knows exactly how tall the tallest point on the ship ... and the lowest point on the

What a bridge - it is very big and yet, if you are on a ship going under it, not big enough. It is one of those times when you hold your breath as you see the top of the ship go through with only the smallest of margins.

We got to see the bridge for a few days from different distances as we waited aboard ship in Yokohama bay for a storm to pass so that our cruise could proceed. There is a toll to cross over, but not under, the bridge.

We stayed in Yokohama for a few days and everywhere we went, we saw different angles of the stunning Bay Bridge - although the best view was from our hotel window - day and night! We drove over it a couple of times and also saw it from Yamashita Park, the Red Brick Warehouses

I have viewed this bridge both during the day and evening. It is most intriquing at night when it is lit up. It has a magic of its own in the evening. Very much a part of the Yokohama harbor scene connecting two land points.

This was a great bridge and marvel of modern engineering when we saw this from afar and gazed in amazement at the Japanese ingenuity - it just stretches so far and seems to be unreal in its look or that’s how it seemed to me at least.
It is dubbed as the most beautiful bridge in Japan. And it is especially at night with all the lighting
It is one of many famous bridge in Japan . Really awesome view during night with all lights . Heart of the city .

The bay bridge at Yokohama is an iconic structure. Viewed from the bay front areas at multiple places in Yokohama, Kawasaki. Few of the prominent viewing places are the Osanbashi passenger terminal deck, Yamashita park, Minato Mirai or take a sea bus cruise over the Yokohama

You have to take the bridge to get into the city, but the views from a car or bus are not very good--to lim9ted in what you can see. It is critical to get on to the harbor to get the full impact of the bridge design. Going out on a cruise ship, you have to go beneath the

This bridge's four spans are one of the symbols for Yokohama, and it's clear there is great pride in its beauty. You can see it from nearly everywhere as you walk around the downtown. Take some time to stroll the parks along the waterfront - you'll see people doing tai chi,
We arrived in Yokohama by cruise liner which sailed under this bridge so it is quite high. Very impressive bridge
We drove across the Yokohama Bay Bridge on route to Tokyo and the drive was very comfortable and smooth. The bridge is truly majestic and provides a unique character to the city.
The Yokohama Bay Bridge is a suspension bridge. It is both an engineering marvel and aesthetic . One cannot miss it while travelling from Tokyo to Yohohama
If you are staying in Yokohama and drive to Tokyo chances are that you will drive over the bridge coming and going it is a beautiful structure and very much a highlight of the Yokohama skyline

Accessed this bridge from Tsurumi instead of Yokohama for a different and surprisingly pleasant view. Take bus no.17 from JR Tsurumi station to reach the spot. From there bus no. 109 can be taken to Yokohama station which crosses the bridge while offering wonderful views of the

Yokohama Bay Bridge is a modern design bridge crossing the entrance of Yokohama Bay with a container port on below. The bridge is used when taking the Limousine Bus to Haneda Airport and great views can be had of Yokohama and even Mount Fuji if the weather is clear. One can also

The captain of our cruise ship said we would have a five foot clearance as we made our way under the Yokohama Bay Bridge on our recent visits there. As we went under, it looked closer than five feet, but I know he wouldn't take any chances. We did have to wait in port one time
A huge bridge spanning the harbour. It looked just as spectacular from below as it did as it loomed up ahead and the ship just managed to clear it.
We sailed under this several times as we left Osanbashi Pier and drove across it once. Its clean lines and delicate architecture belie its strength.
Was not actually on it . But pass under it on the cruise ship we clear it by 3feet it was quite spectacular sight from the ship
I was not actually on it, but saw it from one the many parks dotting the city. Makes for a pretty photo op, for sure, as it is a distinctive Yokohama landmark.
This bridge you can see from anywhere around the port area. It carries two layers of transport and is quite spectacular if you sail underneath it. Other than that, worth a picture.
This double decker bridge which spans Tokyo Bay is quite spectacular both during the day and when lit up at night. Great view up close when you sail under it.
When arriving with the Ycat bus from Narita, you will most definitely cross this bridge. The drive over the bridge will provide you with an amazing view of the Yokohama bay area.
I was able to see this while riding the train.. It is an amazing work of art. Nice to take photos if you are on the cruise.

Although it is called the Yokohama Bay Bridge it actually crosses Tokyo Bay. It was built in 1989 before the Rainbow Bridge in Tokyo and is a two layered structure with a pedestrian walkway as well.It is quite impressive and of course a practical link between Yokohama and Tokyo
This bridge is an amazing work of art structure which is earthquake proof. It is the way to reach Yokohama Bay from Narita airport.It is a great view and on a clear day,you can see Mt Fuji.

Normally one could view the bridge from Yokohama coast or closer from the Cruise Terminal. We were lucky this time as our cruise Princess Diamond started our cruise trip and passing underneath the Yokohama Bay Bridge. The experience of passing underneath the bridge was really
The bridge looks very modern, reminds me of the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco, California. Great views from the bridge.
This bridge stands out and can be seen from many places in Yokohama. At night it is lit up quite well and stands out.
It's remind me a bit the Bay Bridge in San Francisco. Nice view of the bridge especially during night.
An engineering marvel which is also a work of art! Illuminated at night which is a stunning addition to the port.

This is a very impressive double deck bridge that you pass under coming into Yokohama harbor, and when crossing it you get a great view of the harbor, docks and marine traffic. It appears to be very well constructed in view of the ever present earthquake threat.

If you're fortunate enough to cruise into Yokohama then you'll really enjoy going under the Bay bridge. For those that just want to view it from afar, then a good place for this would be Osanbashi Pier. Sunrise here is beautiful as it rises behind, and at night it's lit up well

An architectural masterpiece on the sea in the Yokohama bay area. Best viewed either while taking a ride on the sea ferry or from the Passenger terminal deck. A great place for some photography and enjoying the sea breeze along the coast.

What a beautiful bridge! And the view from the bridge is even better. A great view of Minotamirai and the area. It's worth a taxi ride over and back just for the view. The limousine bus to the airport offers a great view from up high.
Travelled on this bridge while going to Narita Airport from my Hotel. You can get to see the view of the Yokohama Bay

I did not have high expectations of a bridge looking ordinary from the pictures, but reality was even more disappointing. It's far from the port area you will likely visit, but probably there would be nothing to look at even from close distance. Just a bridge, anyway.
Its like any normal bridge in any city- NY, SF etc. There isnt much to see. You can get a view of the bridge from Red Brick Warehouse. There is not much to see around. It can be avoided.
I think the San Francisco-Bay Bridge was copied from this o.ne! The similarities are just so darn unbelievable

Every morning when we drew back the curtains from our hotel room we were greeted with a beautiful view of the Bay Bridge. When we left Yokohama on our way to Narita Airport by bus, we were delighted to travel across this iconic landmark.

Took a train from Tokyo Shinjuku / Shibuya station to Yokohama station. No change of train required. At Yokohama station, change to Minato Mirai line which will take you the way to Yokohama Chinatown. Suggest stop at minatomirai. Its a shopping centre but it is walking distance
We did a drive by of this bridge. It is lovely to see and has some great places to visit in area Lovely to visit at night time all light up.
Not really much to see here or to impress me. There are some bridges that demand attention and praise, but this not one of them. You can find much better things to do with your time in Japan.

Went across this bridge a couple of times once during the day and then again in the evening to take shots of different views of the bridge and yokohama during the day and night. Stunning views that you will treasure and never forget!

We went on it a couple of times to and from Yokohama. Then we went under it a few times on the back to back cruises. I would say going under it was more interesting. Gorgeous looking bridge that's like a landmark for the area but it's not really a destination or a must see.
Spectacular looking bridge located in Yokohama Bay. The Engineering is very Impressive and the views amazing.
Could see it from our hotel and looked lovely. Didn't even think of walking over it as it is quite a distance from where we were staying.
Wanna walk in the air? This is it Bay Bridge in Yokohama. Its a long walk in the air over the sea. Don't miss it.
This is an ordinary bridge, which is hardly an attraction by itself. Still, the bridge is nicely illuminated at night and provides a decent photo-op for anyone strolling on the boardwalk.

This a just a long bridge. There is nothing special about it now. Its nice at night if you cross it in a bus or taxi. There is no expectation of something great on the other side like you do when you cross a bridge of this size other cities like Istanbul for example. Don't go

I'm impressed by the simply, elegant lines of the bridge. It is a beautiful way to get cars over the bay. Still, it is Just A Bridge. I am not sure why this would be considered a destination or attraction. You can see it from most of Yokohama, so there is no point in making a

Its spans one of the main rivers and can be seen from most places in an around Sagarichu / Motomatchi, good views if you get River taxi or if you walk around Intercontinental hotel. Impressive but not worth making a special trip to see it.

Unless you're a structural engineer, it's not really that fascinating. It is visible from plenty of spots all around the Bay, but it is not a striking as it was when it was first completed. The suspension design has been replicated liberally throughout the world.
Very neat bridge to see across the water, looks incredibly neat at night. If you want an amazing view go to the top of the hill at Harbor View Park, you will not be disappointed.

Situated behing Landmark Tower, this museum hosts exhibitions by Europeans or local Japanese artists. There are also permanent works including Picasso and Dali. Opened from 10 am until 6 pm. Closed on Thursdays. Adult visitors have to pay 500 yen but children go in free.
Spanning the entry to Yokohama while carrying traffic to Tokyo any beyond, the Yokohama Bay Bridge is an impressive site from almost any angle.
Very interesting as the bridge was built to withstand the strong earthquake that are common in Yokohama.
Nice view and place to move around for shopping, this place is full of restaurants, shops and malls with local and international brands

It was fun view the bridge from the tower. Yokohama is on the water and it is so lovely there (it is also a shipping port and cruise ships go out here). The bridge is beautiful. A great work of engineering.
