text.quote: This former estate is now a 144-acre park with diverse garden areas, grassy expanses & a greenhouse.
trip: Nature trip in the middle of a city? If you're looking for a place to eat and do sightseeing, you've come to the right place. Family-friendly, the cherryblossoms are so surreal. They have tons of different trees and flowers inside (educational for the kids, too!) I went here

Less crowded than the Yoyogi Park, the Gyoen National garden is absolutely beautiful with different areas, decors and ambiance. You have to pay a fee to enter the park so better to go there for few hours, the time to go all around the park and enjoy it fully.

Located in the center of Tokyo right after the New-York-style shopping-buildings this garden will immerge you in the zen atmosphere only Japanese people master. The garden is so huge that you don't see the city once you're in. No car-noise and you won't be too close to anybody

Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden is perhaps the most beautiful garden in Tokyo, nestled in the heart of Shinjuku/Shibuya within walking distance of Shinjuku Station, this garden to me exemplifies a large Japanese garden, once the private garden of the Naitō family in the Edo
This is a huge beautiful garden right in the middle of Tokyo. Good to visit in any season. Probably best in fall and spring. Quite nice place to have a photography session too.

actually i didn't plan to visit National Garden for this trip during Dec 2019. i thought it have nothing to see but when i were there, oh,.. it was amazing to see some colorful trees and flowers during winter time. it should be great to visit during summer times. the area is

Bring your picnic mat, enjoy a day in a relaxing spring time here under sakuras. Watch out for those wind that carries some of the dirt and can get through the eyes. There's restrooms everywhere but some doesn't have soaps. There's a place that sells food too so you wont get

The park is huge with specific points of interest that you can walk between. The glasshouse was particularly nice and there was a small manicured circular area with flowers in bloom. However, in February the rest of the park was pretty bleak and empty. The Japanese section of

Went in on my own to pass some time whilst waiting for a train. Was only 500 to get in and it was worth every penny. Such a beautiful tranquil place, it’s huge, I spent just over 2 hours walking about taking it all in, and could of stayed at least another 2. Plenty of seats

I am still amazed that cherry blossoms were in bloom in February - and... there were oranges on a tree! Don't miss the conservatory either. We were fortunate to catch a glimpse of a young woman in traditional kimono as well. So peaceful and beautiful!

Beautiful park!! A trip to Gyoen National Garden is a must if you are in the Shinjuku area. It was very peaceful and relaxing after being in the bustling city all week. Perfect place for a picnic or a nice walk away from the city streets. There is an entrance fee of 500yen for
We came here to view cherry blossoms and were not disappointed. I think we paid 500 yen per person to enter the garden. Quite a big garden. Be prepared to spend at least 2-3 hours to walk around.

did a solo walk on my own, best 500 yen I’ve spent so far! it’s pretty easy to navigate your way around, there’s maps in different languages. The tea houses were closed when I went but I enjoyed the green house. I went towards end of feb so lucky there were some cherry blossoms

Shinjuku Gyoen Gardens is a welcome respite from the business in Tokyo. The entrance is Y500 which gets you into a huge park filled with trees and flowers. We spent a couple of hours just strolling around the park and resting on the benches to admire the sakura flowers. There

Really beautiful large garden within walking distance from Shinjuku Station. Has several lakes and sections which will give different spectacular scenaries during the 4 seasons. I went in early spring so there were a few cherry blossom trees showing it's beauty. Can imagine how

I get it, Tokyo is on all the time! All the lights, sounds, smells, digital tones can be a little overwhelming. Walking into the Shinjuku gardens relieve the senses of all the overload. We visit twice during our time in Tokyo. Despite the rain, the Japanese traditional garden
Entrance to the park costs around 500¥, but is really worth it. So many nice spots and a big garden.
A lovely location in central Tokyo evening in winter it’s worth visiting and the early blossom appearing makes it even better. A great place to take time out and enjoy the peace.

Have been here before after snow had fallen and it was a delight. It is closed on Mondays and I cannot figure out why. We watched about 20 people from overseas come up to the gates and be disappointed. Unfortunately I also booked a nearby Hotel so that we could spend time in the

Last visit was in early autumn, when the trees were in their full glory and the roses in the rose garden were still in full bloom; this time it was in April, and the visit was even more worthwhile, to see the stunning azaleas and rhododendrons. This place is huge. If you are

My wife and I lived in Tokyo on several occasions. This garden is particularly popular during cherry blossom time. There is a small admission fee to enter the park and it's quite large. They have trees and flowers planted so that there is something blooming just about all year.

Beautiful park near the heart of Shinjuku and easy walk from the train station. 500Y entry fee but could stay here for hours (have a picnic)! Be sure to walk around the green house. Free park map at the entrance. Would be nice for running too but no bikes allowed.
These are stunning gardens near Shinjuku. Well worth a visit and the 500Y entrance fee. Such a peaceful place to walk around. One of the best parks in Tokyo.

I have been to Shinjuku Gyoen Park in Spring, Summer and Winter and never been disappointed. The differences in the foliage through the different seasons is quite beautiful. And if you are lucky enough to be in Tokyo during the Cherry Blossom season, this is the perfect place to

i came here in December 2019, i didn't expect to see flowers much as winter time but its worth to visit here. it is a huge garden and have many spots to take photos. you won't lost the way because you can borrow a smart guide tablet from counter which can introduce and explain
strange that a park will open late, were here at 8am was shut, it's big and probably would be beautiful for Spring and Summer, not so much in winter time, we didnt get to see it unfortunatly,

紅葉の時期に行きました！ アクセスが良い為、外国人観光客もたくさんいました かなり広い為、1周しようと思うと半日はかかります イチョウの木が綺麗で、みなさん映えの写真を撮ってました！ 芝生でピクニックをされている家族もいて良かったです Easy to access from Shinjuku. It’s best to see at a autumn season! A fee is 500 yen!

Gorgeous gardens divided into different sections - woods, western, Japanese etc. I was a bit disappointed that the greenhouse had a closed sign 30 mins before closing meaning I missed this part of the gardens. 500 yen entrance fee.

On one of our last days in Tokyo, we decided to visit Shinjuku Gyoen - a nice, leisurely walk from our hotel. We arrived right as the gates opened (9am) which was perfect as we practically had the whole place to ourselves. The surrounds were beautifully kept and just absolutely

Lovely garden, I am sure it would be more beautiful in spring and summer. We liked the Japanese garden and large open spaces. Fee for entry for adults, students need to show id for discount. Cafe and greenhouses

These gardens were beautiful and well worth the visit. It makes for a nice leisurely walk though landscaped areas, lakes, avenues lined with trees, a rose garden and huge green spaces, even a tea house though was closed when I was there so be certain of the opening times. There
Worth the visit. Japanese gardens are always lovely, no matter what time of the year. We enjoyed getting out of the subways and shopping precincts and crowds, for a walk amongst nature :)
Famous for cherry blossoms and Autumn leaves. I visited during winter and not crowded. Good to walk around and bring some food to eat here.
we visited this place during the winter , so did not see anything.. all trees are brown in color.. might visit again during summer and i can imagine how beautiful this will be

If you go to Shinjuku, you can enjoy not only shopping but also relaxing at this huge park. First time when I visit, I couldn't believe this kind of park is in middle of Shinjuku. This park is big and has some themes. Stunning place. There is a green field, too so sometime I go

Visit in winter time with a very nice weather. Park has very big space to walk along, experience the beautiful garden, big tree and lake scenery. The traditional japanese garden and Green house are beautiful and attractive. There are some tea cafe to take some rest, drink hot
Great to get away from the crowds and relax but not amazing or spectacular. Great walks and very relaxing. 500 yen entry fee

This garden had many cherry blossom trees. However, in winter season for our visit, we found the garden very dry and grass yellowish. Hardly any flowers and land mostly barren grounds. If you go, recommend to visit the water pond area in the Japanese garden section.

Absolutely beautiful!! I felt like it was Japan’s version of Central Park- the city skyscrapers were all around but this little piece of heaven. We walked all over this park- it was so peaceful when the city outside is a hustle and bustle. There was so much beauty in the history
What a wonderful garden to view the cherry blossoms and have a picnic beneath these gorgeous trees! So many gals in kimonos too. Be camera ready!
The park is big and clean. We went there late autumn. The colors of the foliage are magical. Great for nature walk.
A lovely, peaceful place in the bustling metropolis of Tokyo. Spent a couple of blissful hours there.
We took a lovely stroll through the park. Low cost to get in at 500 yen. Pretty treescapes and flowers. Great views of Shinjuku skyscrapers. It was a slice of respite in an otherwise very busy city.

We paid for the entrance to enter the garden, hoping to enjoy beautiful scenery and to snap photos for our album collection. Unfortunately, we were there in early December where most leaves had dropped, no autumn colors. It was brown and dull but still crowded with tourists. It

Massive beautiful garden near Shinjuku. Whether you're visiting for Cherry Blossoms in March/April or Autumn Colours in November/December, this beautiful park has it all. And don't miss the Greenhouse for something a little different.
A must visit if you are in Shinjuku. Great walking, gardens and ponds. The traditional Japanese garden was my favorite. Lots of big old trees too!

It was a beautiful walk around the garden. It was big. Took us about more than an hour to slowly explore the grounds. The centre in a lovely place to just lay on the grass and enjoy a picnic and the sun. Adults pay 500 yen. If you are 15 years and younger, you get in for free.
I took a day trip to the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden and loved it. It's a beautiful place which I can only imagine is even more spectacular in warmer seasons when the cherry blossoms are in bloom.

Beautiful and huge garden with long walks, flowers and water features. Felt very cool and peaceful. Food and drinks available. Directions very well marked plus an indoor display garden. There is a entry fee and seniors get a discount

This is one place I never miss in Shinjuku. Whatever be the season the national park is beautiful, peaceful and full of life. This time around in winters, it was beautful, trees covered in colorful shades of leaves, bright day added to the beauty. It is very close to Shinjuku
I in the National garden this month, lovely colours but, due to the Typhoon damage, some areas were out of bounds. But had a enjoyed my 3 hours walking round.
Walked around this great gardens in the morning sunshine. Took some lovely photographs. Beautiful scenery, ponds and lakes. Very calm, quiet and peaceful.
Very beautiful and pretty peaceful place. I bet the forest area would be nice and cooling in the summer. Love to re-visit in other season

A true representation of Japan - pristine, balanced, intricate, uncluttered and artistic attention to detail. This garden is amazing! It is so beautiful to walk around especially during cherry blossom season. The cost is ¥500 for an adult to enter but it is worth it. There

I'd love to have one of these parks in my neighborhood, but I'm not too sure it's a tourist activity. It has plenty of well-kept lawn to relax on, a solid greenhouse with plants from all over (with a Japanese touch especially where it's involved in endangered plant species

Definitely a highlight when visiting Japan! Tokyo is a wonderful city with lots to do, but this should definitely be on your to-do list. Plan good walking shoes, and a few hours to enjoy. Concessions & vending machines for drinks in middle of park-priced reasonably. Gorgeous

I love this garden! It's amazingly well-manicured garden that's a photographer's dream. I've been to many fantastic parks (NY's Central Park, London's Hyde Park, etc) and this blows them away! There are also numerous rest areas in the garden which sells some small eats/drinks.
great place to walk if the weather is nice. beautiful park, water with a picture perfect setting. worth a visit.
I wasn’t expecting anything other than a park. It opens up into the Tokyo version of NY’s Central Park, but much nicer. This is a can’miss on your list of things to do in Tokyo.

We went there last week. Entry fee is 500yen per person. They use vending machine to sell the ticket which is pretty cool. Since we just came back from Mt. Fuji, the autumn leaves in this park is nothing to compare to the ones in lake Kawaguchi. Maybe they we’re blown away by

We decided on our last day in Tokyo to be more relax and walk in the park. Reminds me of NY Central Park with views of the buildings in Shinjuku. Very relaxing. You see families with kids playing on a beautiful Saturday. There is an entrance fee for adults 500 yen and free
It was really nice, and since it was fall the leaves in this part of the garden were all colours of fall, really pretty. Some places were closed off due to the typhoon tho :(

We went at what was called "peak" for autumn foliage and, while it was lovely, there are more stunning places in or shortly outside Tokyo. But "peak" sakura (cherry blossoms) are awesome and everywhere. Because it is just a short walk from Shinjuku station and subways, it
This is a stunning garden with many lovely sections. Such a wonderful oasis in crowded busy Tokyo. Worth at least two hours to revive and reconnect with nature
Good to walk around on a hot day. Very well laid out some open spaces amd lots to explore - good cafe located within the grounds. Easy to get around
Very quiet and tranquil compare to Meiji Jingu park. Very large park. Very relaxing and close to transport. Would recommend.
A fantastic park to wonder around in Had many beds of beautiful floors lovely meandering pathways with the Japanese trees and a few buildings Great way to pass the time
Nice park. Clean and beatiful. Very nice place for some peace and quiet in all the noise of the city. It costs money to visit the park, but not much at all. Worth it.
The entry price has gone up to ¥500. Not worth it without the chrysanthemums exhibit, too early for autumn colours (prob next weekend) and parts closed
Definitely a park to go to with friends or family! A good place for picnic. Awesome during fall when scenery is starting to change!
Lovely garden, well worth the visit. Second time there and found it a lovely, well kept garden that has a peaceful and relaxing feel.
Was a fantastic park/garden. Well kept and lakes and trees were spectacular. Visited on a Sunday when it seems all local families go for a walk.

With all the hustle and bustle of Tokyo there are not many quiet areas but this is one. 500 yen to get in and you can spend the day there wandering the paths and looking at all the gardens and plants. Some nice lakes. A very peaceful spot and one of the highlights of tokyo

A walk through these beautiful gardens is a wonderful experience given the various different and thought provoking scenery. A welcome break from the hectic city life and traffic. Plants from around the world, beautiful flower arrangements and a large greenhouse all offer a very

Although we visited on November we did a lot of fun. I had to stop the hole time in order to take pictures. Every corner and plant is so carefully treated and looks nice ! The 500 yen to pay is not much for such a nice place.
I was there during sakura time, the lines to enter Shinjuku Gyoen were insane, but because it's so spacious inside, it didn't feel like a lot of people. And blooming sakura trees were soo beautiful
We went here a bit before sunset and had a chance to explore most of the garden. As everything in Tokyo, this garden is beautifully manicured and very clean. Great for a peaceful stroll!

There is a small entrance fee which, coming from the UK, seemed unusual. However, it offered a lovely respite from the rest of busy busy Shinjuku. Lakes with koi and turtles surrounded by beautiful gardens with the contrasting background of the skyscrapers.

Very disappointed to visit the park in reality against all the 5 stars ratings given in the review. The park was huge and full of green. Nothing extraordinary to see and experience except the chrysanthemum flowers display which was just OK. The entrance fee of ¥500 per adult was

Even on a grey day, this was a great break from the hustle and bustle of the city. Strolling through park seemed to rejuvenate me after the long flight and figuring out the city. The Japanese are masters of landscaping and it is on full display here.

I spent nearly 3 hours taking in the remarkable beauty of this national treasure. It's nicely laid out with toilets unassumingly tucked away. It's a large park with lots of open space perfect for a family picnic. The greenhouse was the highlight for me. Think absolutely

This is an oasis in the midst of a bustling city. Its 144 acres are divided into Japanese landscape garden, English and French. We only saw the Japanese, which includes a quick peak of a soon-to-be-bride being photographed by the side of a pond. Perhaps we did not see the other

My husband and I spent our last morning in Tokyo here and it was a great way to relax and decompress from all the train riding and traversing through the city all week. We went in October, just a week after the typhoon so some sections were closed and just before all the autumn

After a morning walking around the busy shopping centres of Tokyo, taking a well-earned break at these stunning gardens provided a counterpoint to the hustle and bustle. The green house have a good collection of plants whilst the old tea rooms and lakes provide a timeless sense

Quite some areas are still closed due to the impact of the Typhoon. Moreover, October does not seem to be the best month to get most out of this park as flowers blooming is mainly limited to the rose garden and it is too early for real Autumn leaves experience

This is a very big park in the middle of a bustling area making it a very good place to chill out. Unfortunately, a typhoon hit Tokyo three days before our visit so there was quite a bit of tree damaged, closed walks and closed tea houses that were damaged. However, we still

Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden provides a peaceful respite from bustle of Shinjuku. The garden is an easy walk from Shinjuku Station and provides a variety of landscapes - from open lawns to forested areas, a Japanese garden with lake, and a greenhouse containing tropical and

A pleasant walk around the gardens in the sunshine. We stopped for tea in the traditional tea room which was a fun experience. Beautifully maintained gardens despite the recent typhoons and well worth the visit
You canot travel to Japan and Tokyo and not visited the parts! Every parts is different and very well described. This is a real pleasure and a source of case in this flamboyant city
First day in Tokyo, a great place to stretch out the achy limbs. Quite a lot of restorative work ongoing getting ready for the Olympic visitors

Japanese garden was pretty, pity the tea houses were closed. Nice for a stroll in a park, greenhouse had some unusual plants. Wouldn’t rush to see it if you’ve got limited time in Tokyo - if you’ve got loads of time you can pay for a bit of peace and quiet.
The gardens are fabulous and very quiet given how busy the surrounding areas are. The greenhouse is also well worth the visit. We spent nearly 3 hours there. Loved it.

Visited these gardens as they weren’t far from our hotel, after a day of exploring. A lovely way to finish the day. Beautiful, serene, calm and the direct opposite of all that was going on outside it’s perimeters. Well worth taking a stroll around these gardens.

Cost 500 Yen which gives you access to the large gardens with three different designs, we loved the Japanese gardens the best and the Imperial Greenhouse. A beautiful walk in the rain with a lovely tea house break in the middle.

You people just have to go there and enjoy. You can even close your eyes and just breathe the air. It is a bliss... I am saying that, as I have been just locked at my hotel room, due to the recent Typhoon; any fresh air is good after that, but that place is really worth
If you want to take a breather, I suggest heading to the Garden and Greenhouse. It is a lengthy walk but many benches and rest areas to catch a moment.

This place is huge! Stunning gardens though, and a wide variety, from traditional japanese, to english rose garden and even a glasshouse. Even though it wasn't really the season for them, we managed to luck out and find a few cherry blossom trees that had begun to flower early,

I guess October isn’t the best time to be visiting Japanese gardens and with the preparations for the olympics this garden is currently not really showing at its best. Give it a few weeks and the leaves changing may make it worth the effort.

With a mid morning arrival, we spent a day with glorious weather in an enormous and beautiful park setting. The colours of the cherry blossoms were bright and vibrant and the variety of the various schemed parts of the park made for a very rewarding visit. It was late in the

This is a big park located in shinjuku which surrounded by tall buildings. You can find a lot of trees and flowers during sakura season. They also have botanical garden, japanese garden, western style garden. Definitly a place to see if you enjoy trees.
Came here to wait until we could get into our hotel room. Lovely gardens, and glasshouses to visit. Even on a rainy day it was a nice escape from the city traffic and noise.
Nice garden for a morning walk. Took us an hour to cover as some areas are being refurbished. Enjoyed the green house which displayed a lot of different tropical herbs and plants.

Had a such a beautiful morning strolling through this garden. It was a lot bigger than I was expecting with rolling lawns, zen-filled streams and bridges and beautiful traditional buildings. We were staying in Shinjuku and walked from one side to the other continuing on to
Only need about an hour and it’s a great opportunity to see Japanese gardens done really well. Went non-cherry blossom session and it was still beautiful.
You need to pay to get in to the garden and it is nothing special (in comparison to most other countries I suppose). A fair few mosquitoes around so make sure you have appropriate gear for this.

We enjoyed visiting the park as a bit of respite from the business of the city. We enjoyed having a little picnic with bento boxes purchased from a nearby department store. Look for the teahouses to find rubbish bins! There's plenty to see in the park including buildings, ponds

Even in the dead heat of summer, this garden was amazingly beautiful and lush. Each section has its own aesthetic, but all are traditionally Japanese. There are ponds, authentic tea houses, bridges, sculptures, wide-open spaces, with a modern skyline as the backdrop in many

The garden is beautiful and artistically done. In the tea garden, especially, every angle is wonderfully composed, like a painting. Some reviewers said this garden wasn't anything special, but for me, who had only seen Japanese-inspired landscaping in non-Japanese botanical

It was very interesting to walk through this garden/park. There are amazing large trees that we don’t see in North America. The lawns were huge and being enjoyed by many people on a hot evening. I do think that botanically it is a little tired and IMHO experiencing a lack of

Spent one morning here, they charged us ¥500 per person to get in. We were searching for the traditional Japanese garden - passed English and French, the place is huge. There is traditional tea house and Japanese garden is beautiful.

I wanted to get away from the busy city but not have to travel too far. This was perfect. Pretty traditional gardens to see. And nice rest areas everywhere. Families relaxing and having picnics. Highly recommend as an escape.
The gardens surrounding the Shrine were a great place to be in the heat of that day. Definitely worth a visit.

Nice clean and quiet central park with excellent routes and good signage. The water features are very nice (as you'd expect in Japan) and there is a small cafe. Plenty of vending machines around if it's a hot day and you need a cool drink!

Well worth the meagre entry price - huge gardens, very well kept, and not hugely busy so felt very tranquil and away from the hustle and bustle of tokyo. Good facilites, and a nice little gift shop/cafes etc.

Cherry blossoms, yes but what people don't always talk about are the little tea houses inside the park. Great for kids to get a taste of a tea house. My 7 and 5 year old shared a tea and dessert with me. We were quiet and enjoyed witnessing this tradition.
I had to the opportunity to visit the park at my arrival to Tokio. After a very long and crowded trip. It was such a refresh to walk in this quiet place enjoying the gardens and palaces within.
What a lovely place. The garden is so huge and the scenery is so wonderful. The entrance fee for adult is 500¥ but it was worth every yen!
It was a very nice visit even on a very hot day. Lots of shade trees, many places to sit and rest. The concession/ rest area inside park had nice selection of refreshments.
No cherries during the summer😭 There is a good signing. They charge ¥500 entrance. Good place for families

If you like botanical gardens, don't miss it, also if you are in Tokyo in Spring, DO NOT miss it, excellent site for cherry tree watching. At any other time of year, the green house is a delight of tropical and desert plants.
The beauty of this place hits all your senses, the smells, the sounds (or lack thereof in the middle of Tokyo), the sights and incredible plant life. Great place to get away,
This garden is a wonderful and ideal place for a picnic, especially in the spring when all the trees and flowers are blooming and not too hot. A best place for spend time in relax.

This gardent is worth the visit.It is a great selection for who want have a memorable Trip. It is a very friendly place with toilet every where.Morever it also have other varieties of flowers like tulips and azaleas,which make me impress and will never forget.However I hope it
Pretty park, but not worth it to pay for it. There are plenty of other pretty free parks in the city you can go to instead.

I was surprised to see a price to enter this park when most other tourist spots were free. It was lovely and shaded and must be a sight to see during Cherry Blossoms ! It was quiet and peaceful and a good moment to get away from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo. Reminded me of
I just wish it opened earlier but it was worth the wait and the 500 yen. Great selection of plants, good photos opportunities and a good place to go for a run or a picnic.

This place was a lovely visit - do not miss the glass house and flower bed. It is great to spend a few hours with the kids here .. its a very friendly place with toilets everywhere - resting areas- and signs all over the place the only downside was all the labels on plants were

I visited this garden during peak sakura or cherry blossom season in Tokyo. This garden has acres of different varieties of cherry blossom trees and all of them blooming is a breathtaking sight. There were also other varieties of flowers like tulips and azaleas, but the sakura

Small entry fee for adults and kids over 15 (student discount available). Took my kids there on a Sunday for a chill day. We only stayed for 30min because of the crushing heat, so I didn’t get to see everything, but it’s definitely worth a visit. Beautiful Japanese gardens and

Spent some time wandering through these gardens soaking in the traditional Japanese garden feel and look. The time of the visit was not good from a flowering perspective, but nonetheless the gardens were refreshing and attractive on an otherwise typical hot summer day. Within

Enjoyed these beautiful gardens and especially the walk through the old residence which has been wonderfully maintained. The green house was excellent and the amenities superb. Worth the money if you have the time to visit.

Nice and quiet place. I recomend this place if you want to rest a little bit from the city rush. There wera actually a lot of people, but the garden is big enough, so you can enjoy the greenery and some peace on the bench.

One of the best gardens in Tokyo and conveniently located near Shinjuku station. In the Autumn you can see the leaves changing colour which is lovely for a stroll around. The garden is bigger than I expected and you could spend an hour or longer inside. It’s a very quiet,
This is a lovely, quiet park to walk through as an escape from a busy neighborhood. Everything is perfectly manicured, and it is fun to see a little wildlife.

I decided to visit the gardens, even though the heat and humidity is pretty unbearable at this time of year. I ended up spending almost two hours wandering the grounds, taking some time to just sit and listen to the sounds of the wind rustling in the leaves and the insects and

This is a must visit when in Shinjuku. I’ll admit, at first it didn’t sound that interesting to me since we had so many other choices, but that changed quickly. It is so quite and peaceful here and a great place to just take a stroll and admire Japan’s beauty. It was a little
Just beautiful - would have loved to have seen it in its cherry blossom glory but it was still gorgeous to walk around.
A very hot summer, bring your shades and hat! The garden was well curated, giant bonzai plants were pretty. Quiet park.

Honestly, I was not aware how popular this park was with tourists. I got the idea to visit here from one of my favourite anime and came last week. There's an admission charge which I guess is ok to upkeep the park. Students do get discounts as well as the elderly, make sure you

We visited Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden in the midst of the cherry blossoms season, and it was magnificent! We visited other cherry blossom areas in Tokyo at that time, but Shinjuku Gyoen is the best of them all! From Shinjuku Station, we took a short train ride. It is a bit

Easy to get to from Shinjuku or Yoyogi station. Full of magnificent trees, lots of ancient cherries, it would be spectacular in blossom. Beautiful rose garden, all named. An oasis in the city there are places where you could be miles from a city then around a corner & there's a

The park is divided into sections with different types of gardens. My friend and I enjoyed it so much. And it was a best place for photography. I recommend this place is a great place to spend your time with relax if you are in Shinjuku.
Visited on our first morning. These gardens are beautiful and well set with lakes, bridges and walkways. Spent a very relaxing couple of hours here

This garden was a welcome relief from the buzz of the metropolitan area. A quiet oasis. We were there after a long hot dry spell and then major storm. So not at its 100% best but pretty good. A number of cafes/ vending machines around the park meant that could always get iced
It's a really beautiful garden. It's relaxing and has great views. Very enjoyable to stroll around with friends and take in the nature.

Good place to enjoy hanami with friends and family! Was sad to know that the entrance fee had increased from 200 to 500 yen from April onwards. Nevertheless, a must to visit especially during the Sakura season!

Gyoen National Garden is less than 500 m from the hustle and bustle of the center of Shinjuku, but once you have passed the entrance gate (entrance fee is 500 JPY), you feel as if the noise of central Tokyo is very distant. Walk to and around the Japanese garden with its ponds,

Though much of Tokyo is hustle-bustle, the garden is a delightful, quiet respite. Of course the greenhouse deserves a walk-through (just be sure to avoid the camera toting folks trying to get the perfect shot). The garden itself is wonderful for strolling, with benches tucked
The Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden is lovely. The grass and trees are trimmed beautifully. If you enjoy taking landscape photos this is the garden for you! There is a small entrance fee.

Right next to train station and a lovely park, disabled friendly. Very manicured gardens and wonderful glass house. Well worth the visit. Don't forget to take your seniors card for admission discount.

This park is huge. And it's beautiful. We didn't manage to check out all of the park, only a small area in it. We visited the tea house which is a nice change of pace in the park. The entrance fee is not much, so don't be alarmed by that. But beware, you cannot bring bewerage
We had a lovely time walking around. Don't miss the beautiful rose garden, the Old Imperial Rest House, or the Taiwan Pavilion.

There is an entrance fee but it’s well worth it. The park is huge and well maintained. Hard to imagine such a huge lot of land existing in Tokyo considering everything else is compacted to save space. The greenhouse is really nice so be sure to make a stop there during your

Beautiful! Calming walk through the cherry trees! Best place to relax from the hustle of Tokyo city, Very nice place to take pictures with background of cherry blossoms! To add more, ice cream made of cherry flavor, enough benches to take rest also available. Except a very few

We had been to a nearby department store and decided we needed to take a break and have some tea. This is a huge park in the middle of the city, with large lawn areas for spreading out blankets, or you can just stroll about and enjoy the manicured shrubs and multiple trees,

Not all the grounds were well kept. Some of the lawns need mowing and weeding. We could see weeds appearing in bushes. There should be signs showing where each path leads to. Even though we were given a map, it is not easy to navigate and know where each path leads to. The

Such a beautiful and peaceful place to escape the hustle and bustle of busy Tokyo. We strolled around the huge gardens taking in the various gardens. They have huge sections of lawn that you can go and relax on and have something to eat. The ponds have huge fish and turtles. The
Had a nice stroll in this park. Some parts has the city buildings as background which is an interesting mix of concrete and nature. The landscapes and water features are very lovely.

Shinjuku Gyoen is always a peaceful retreat in the middle of the city thanks to its size and the 500 yen entry fee (recently increased from 200–300). Personally, I like to wander around the Japanese garden and the Taiwanese pavilion. The rose garden is also beautiful.
We spent 2 hours wandering around the gardens. To be fair, coming from Australia, nothing I hadn’t seen before. Was a nice change from the craziness of Tokyo.

Our group walked this garden after a large lunch for the purpose of a stroll and looking at some wonderful Japanese gardens. Not only were they great, the park (in early June) had some of the most breathtaking roses in bloom that I've ever encountered. Well worth the stroll!
Absolutely gorgeous garden. Must visit if in the area. Lovely place to stroll through. Nice and cool clean garden
Even though we missed the cherry blossom season, this park is beautiful. There's a small lake, many great trees and a traditional Japanese garden inside.
During my stay in Tokyo I run in the park at least once. the park is unique as it has Japanese part, English part and also botanic garden part.
This garden is a must see. Lovely space to wander and enjoy. Very traditional Japanese design. So beautiful and peaceful amongst the busy city that Tokyo is.
A wonderful place. Take time to walk, learn the history and see this truly beautiful area. You’ll have no idea you are surrounded by a large city. Peaceful and a great place to recharge!
The gardens are so tranquil and is a gorgeous bit of peace in the city. We loved walking around and thought it was a must see.
This is a uper huge park in the city. It is certainly worth a visit but you must be prepared to walk so its important to have proper walking shoes. Be prepared to spend at least 3 hours.

A great oasis from the busyness of Shinjuku. Gorgeous Japanese gardens with bridges, Japanese stonework, azaleas, ponds, and a wonderful tea house. The botanical garden in the greenhouse was also neat.

Very beautiful place in Shinjuku. A lot of places to walk and enjoy the view of the different areas. Possible to sit down with a picnic or conbini, or just buy something in the park.

This park was the perfect introduction to see how the Japanese celebrate sakura or cherry blossom time. It is quite large and there are many, many large cherry trees. It was so interesting to see families picnicking under the beautiful trees. We also walked around other areas

We stayed very close to this garden but be aware it is closed on certain days and has open hours check website for details. We had a very enjoyable time walking around the garden and entry cost was no issue . Like all gardens and shrines in Japan this one was very well looked
Pretty park with nice photo opportunities, a decent mini greenhouse exhibition and lots of benches to enjoy the sunshine.

Gyoen National Garden is located walking distance from Shinjuku Station. This is one of the most beautiful gardens in all Japan. Gyoen National Garden offers unique experiences of Japanese gardening and landscaping as well as superb views. Do not miss.

This place is well worth a visit despite the entrance charge. We had a bento box picnic near some wonderful sakura. Really beautiful place near Shinjuku. Stock up at Seitan nearby for an amazing picnic!

Really enjoyed this beautiful garden. You can come here to relax and enjoy the peace and quiet. We went to one of the tea houses and enjoyed a cup up tea and just walked around in the Japanese garden area.

We went here only to see the Sakura and took pictures. But never thought they still have it because we are in the late timing. Very very beautiful though it was crowded but you still can enjoy the beauty of it. One of the best spot to relax and enjoy sakura and took pictures of

The gardens are very pretty and very tranquil. It's a nice break from the hustle bustle of Tokyo's main city areas. They have a beautiful rose garden outside as well as a large greenhouse with some very interesting plants.
We had an amazing time seeing all the cherry blossoms in bloom. Many people with blankets having pic nics.
If you want to take rest from the crowdy, passion-like and chaotic atmosphere of Tokyo, this garden / park is the ideal choice.
What a wonderful place to visit so any cherry tree all were very beautiful and the people of this country are just so nice I would recommend going. Plenty of ammenities available.

We visited Shinjuku Gyoen National Park on a Monday as it was a fine and sunny day and there was no rain expected for that morning. Until we arrived at the park, we had no idea that it was a free entrance day. Instead of having to pay Yen 200.00 per person, we got into the park
Nice gardens to walk around lots of trees and flowers to enjoy any time of year. The greenhouse was the highlight for me, so many plants and flowers I recognized from my trips around Asia.

Beautiful, well kept gardens including rose gardens and the amazing rows of sycamore trees (my favourite part!). Also has Tea houses where you can participate in traditional Japanese tea! Does have an entrance fee but worth it given the upkeep.
It was relaxing to be in this beautifully maintained garden. Little ponds with cute curved bridges add special characters to the garden.

Shinjuku garden was massive! Small entry fee to enter. We went on the weekend. It was filled with families who brang a picnic with them. It was a lovely park which was well maintained. Plenty of toilets, vending machines and small food stores inside.

Beautiful park for a lovely afternoon away from the hustle and bustle of the city. One of the only reasons it’s not a 5 is that it is really for walking and enjoying, however, none of the descriptive signs have any English on them. Pretty to look at, probably more meaningful if

This is a nice place to relax and get away from the hustle and bustle of the city. We bought in some lunch from a restaurant outside and sat on a bench and enjoyed the peace and quiet. Recommended for at least an hour to reboot the system.

It is located close to the train station of Shinjuku. Agreed with fellow reviewers, this is not a must to visit place, but if you have time to relax, this is a beautiful and large garden to enjoy. The place is neat and fresh, and well laid. Entrance requires only a small fee.

The park is huge located centrally in Tokyo at Shinjuku. You can have a picnic or go for a run. There is a botanical garden also in the pack which has a variety of flowers and plants. Very beautiful. Must visit.

Park is located off one of the trains and there are three entrances to get in. Good time to spend and hour or two and get away from the city, layout is well done with ponds filled with carp and turtles. Would recommend if in the area.

Even thought its cost some money to get in. It was totally worth the small price. Lovely garden, very big area. Went with great weather.
Has been a nice walk through this huge park, enjoying the greenery and being away for some hours from busy Tokyo; luckily we still sow some Sakura trees in full blossom.

Beautiful and serene gardens in the midst of busy Tokyo, with elements of Japanese formal garden. Small entrance fee
Nice park to walk around and enjoy the park. Income fee 500yen but worth te price. Very clean and spacious, very big and nice for perfect pictures

It is a nice park that gives this special “away from the big city” feel. There are a couple of big lawns where ppl lounge, have picnic, or play with their kids. There are also some alleys with benches and a few central houses that sell food and drinks. It coats appx $5pp to

Beautiful gardens of approximately 124 acres. This is a very enjoyable get away from the hustle and bustle of the busy streets of Shinjuku/Tokyo. However it could be maintained a lot better and on a wet day the unsealed paths are wet and muddy which is okay if you’re prepared
Visited this park during Sakura festival in March'19. As it was full bloom cherry blossom season, the park was amazing. It is a huge park and well maintained. Must go.
It is unbelievable that this area of serene beauty is right bang in the middle of this huge crazy city. Certainly worth spending several hour wandering around this area and relaxing.

The gardens are beautiful, but just be aware that they don’t open until 9 am. Be prepared to walk a lot - the garden grounds cover a ton of area. But take time to stroll without being rushed. There are many picturesque views.

A very nice large park, combining a Japanese, French and English garden. We were here during the golden week and there were too many people in the park, but we still liked it.

I was lucky to see cherry blossom. It was a rainy day in early April. I only spent an hour there and got plenty of photos of cherry blossom. Would return one day hopefully on a dry day.
Beautiful Garden. Cherry Blossoms- spectacular. Pleasant walk through the garden. Easy to get to via JR line.

Great lawns, beautiful japanese gardens, signage well done but.. Worth some attention to landscaping and... why charge entry? Why not step on some lawns?

This is one of the best places to visit when it is cherry blossom time. If you are staying anywhere in Shinjuku you can walk there and the admission is very reasonable. Do not miss.
I visited here on my last day in Tokyo. It's a beautiful park, with a selection of ponds, trees and plants. Really nice to escape the hustle and bustle.
It was a holiday when we visited (greenery day) so we went early to avoid the crowds. Palce was well kept. Nice place to visit for some quite time.

Very relaxing gardens in the center of Tokyo with the buildings skyline . Everything nice and clean , beautiful small lake in The park , and several cherry blossoms’ trees . If you go to Tokyo you can’t miss this park
You can easily waste a day away here, beautiful, huge and nothing like national gardens anywhere else! xoxox

A great place to wander around for a couple of hours and admire the gardens. So relaxed in the middle of a hectic area. They also have so many different species of cherry trees and some of the blossoms are truly amazing.

It's quite a large park, so be prepared to walk. There is an entry fee for people over 15 years of age. The sakura trees are absolutely amazing. especially when the wind blows and you see all the sakura petals floating through the air.
Came during full bloom of the cherry blossoms season. Picnicked on the grounds. Go early before the crowd arrives. Queue builds up by mid to late morning, despite entrance fee.
Beautiful oasis in the middle of Shinjuku. Lovely gardens of several types. Some of the Cherry trees were still in bloom in late April.
it's a very nice park all year long but the sakura season is a special treat. entrance fee is 500 yen

We spent an afternoon at this park toward the end of March, not all the flowers were in bloom but it was amazing none the less. Very beautiful and picturesque. A great contrast to the hustle and bustle of Tokyo city. There's a great little tea shop inside as well, and plenty of
The best location in Tokyo for Cherry Blossom. most of the cherry trees around the lake at the south west area of the park.

Right in the heart of Shinjuku this park is peaceful and doesn’t seem crowded at all. The cherry blossoms still in bloom and they looked beautiful. We had a nice time wandering around and would recommend a visit.
Lovely park still lots of cherry blossom , lovely manicured trees bushes , flowers , bridges , tea houses etc ... worth a visit to see greenery and fairly quiet in middle of city !

We spent a morning with the whole family walking around the park and sitting under the cherry blossoms. It's beautiful -- definitely a welcome change from the hustle and bustle of fast-moving Tokyo. There's also a good enough restaurant inside the park, where we had lunch.

Very easy to find, the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden was a delight. We went here as a family to see the Cherry Blossoms in full bloom and we were not disappointed. Had a picnic here as well and although there were a lot of people around, it did not feel crowded. A beautiful

This is an absolute must do when visiting Tokyo, we were lucky to go there during cherry blossom season so the park was beautiful , the park was much bigger than i thought so you need to allow a good few hours to fully take it ll in, take a picnic and take your time exploring

Extremely pretty and beautiful. We went there during blossom cherry season and it was very pretty. Even though it was quite busy with a lot of people taking selfies (what can you do?) we had a relaxing experience and went there a couple of times during our stay.
One of the best parks for cherry blossom because they prohibit alcohol from the park, which would make this a better choice for families.

Garden visits would not be typically on our agenda for any trip, but this was recommended to us and was close to our hotel. It was absolutely gorgeous, with a diverse range of features including ponds, bridges, flowers, trees and more that made for a really enjoyable visit, and
Visited it at night. It was as nice as the view on the day. The trees are lighted. Perfect spot for a night photographer.

Possibly the most beautiful urban park I’ve been to. It definitely is up there with Central Park in NYC. When I visited the Plum Blossoms trees were blooming and attracting many birds. You pay a small entry fee to get into the park, but it’s worth it as the park is very well
This park was designed as an imperial retreat, but now it's a splendid park for every one. You have to pay to get in. The cherry blossoms are wonderful over here.

After days of shopping in Tokyo we decided to take a break and head to the park. So glad we did as the Cherry Blossoms we’re still in bloom 19th April, took some gorgeous photos. The park is very relaxing and has different areas to explore i.e. Japanese garden, greenhouse

We arrived in Tokyo on the 7th April Japanese garden and cherry blossom was absolutely fantastic there so many picture perfect places one place you could see red pink and white sakura trees all together a must visit places

Japanese Garden and Cherry Blossoms were absolutely stunning! Really enjoyed walking around with my family. Would highly recommend visiting!

We entered the Shinjuku gate of Gyoen around 9am and it’s rare to have to pay 500 yen to enter. The ground was well maintained, and blossom was splendid. The garden area is grand but lacks the sophistication and variety of plants. Even the greenhouse dome was not as impressive

The park was very crowded in the Cherry Blossom season. Outside this time it is worth a stroll away from crowds and the traffic.

We saw the Shinjuku Gyoen gardens at the peak of cherry blossoms - a most beautiful sight, even with the extra people. I thought the crowds would be unbearable, but these gardens are huge, so plenty of space for all. We didn't think to bring a picnic, but were jealous of all

The Shinjuku Gyoen gardens are a perfect retreat from the hectic Shinjuku. It costs ¥500 to enter and it is definitely worth it. There are so many beautiful areas and spaces with which to relax and take time out. It was a perfect place to get over some serious jet lag. Time

Such a beautiful place! Was worth the ¥500 each to enter. Stunning gardens that make you feel so peaceful. There are even traditional tea houses you can stop in and enjoy a cup of green tea. An absolute must!
Lovely park, well worth the ¥500 entrance fee which includes the greenhouse.spent a couple of hours taking in the beautiful blossoms.

Great selections of old cherry trees that display a magnificent exhibit of cherry blossoms. Expansive park includes pleasant walks among various garden sites that contrast with a backdrop of modern urban buildings.

It was easy to get here and we found it exceptionally beautiful. A beautifully spacious park right in the heart busy Shinjhuku. We were here during the Cherry Blossom season - a photographers delight! We thoroughly enjoyed strolling around here enjoying the quietness of Tokyo!

Beautiful and huge garden. We spend over 2 hours just walking around and enjoying the beauty of the place. Not as busy as I though it would be. Charge your camera and phone as there are many picture opportunities. Went in spring so cherry blossoms were in full bloom. Also

We were here during cherry blossom which made the park that much more beautiful. I would strongly recommend a visit, as it has lovely landscape and many nice photo opportunities

You can catch great cherry blossom sightings even 2-3 weeks after the main season here. Some late-blooming varieties. Great sights here. Must see for sakura but may not be that worthwhile for other times.

A must see if you are in Tokyo. The garden is in Shinjuku and it is a beautiful place to walk and enjoy the day. During the spring time the Cherry Blossom is fantastic.
Beautiful garden but crowded. Great place to take photos of cherry blossoms. Entrance fee of $5 and no alcohol allowed.

Very nice park to visit with family and kids, you can spend the whole day over there just bring your food you can enjoy a nice picnic within the mother nature. Beautiful nature and fresh air. 500¥ For adults and 250¥ for seniors and students.

Nestled among the city is a civic garden where the cherry blossoms flow on the wind and quiet abounds Destress and enjoy a walk amongst nature a short walk or as long as you like
Nice enough but not that exciting. The cherry blossom was past its best when we visited 12th April 2019.
Amazing spot to see cherry blossom, I was simply fascinated, living a fairytale. Easy to access by metro.

Best place to experience the cherry blossom season in Japan. We went to this park on a rainy day but still Gorgeous! Try early morning when they open and not crowded.

Beautiful park/garden with different type of blooming trees. We went at the beginning of he cherry blossoms season and it was nice to walk around. I am sure that a week later it must have been even more beautiful.
This reminds me of Central Park in NYC! Beautiful landscapes and ponds. The Sakura (cherry blossoms) were in full bloom!

Place is stunning, gets very busy though so try and get there early if you want some photos alone with the sakura!
The park was lovely, the cherry blossoms were in full bloom on 6th April 2019, we booked a tour through viator trips and had Michyko as our guide and she was fantastic, full of knowledge.

Perfect place for enjoying the cherry blossom season in the middle of tokyo! Must visit place in spring! J&S
Very beautiful cherry blossoms trees. Views that worth the entry fees. A big park but can be crowded during sakura season.

Great park to check out the seasonal cherry blossoms! Entry was 500 Yen per person. Park is very clean.

Absolutely stunning park with a really amazing green house. What a lovely place to wile away a couple of hours just strolling.

A magical park in the very center on Shinjuku. Ponds, Sakuras, pine and beautiful flower - all you will find there. Worth to spend and hour or two slowly walking.

The park is very nice and is a very peaceful place in the middle of Tokyo. There were already cherry blossoms blooming in late March. I really enjoyed walking around the Japanese garden inside the park.

Well worth a visit, an oasis in the middle of the crazy city of Tokyo. Lots of different areas to enjoy, from traditional Japanese, to English and French. Nice cafes and restaurants dotted about, and pennies to enter.
Accidently I end up in this gorgeous park while exploring the district and it was the most beautiful place in Tokyo.

The past 12 months have been my biggest period for seeing cherry blossoms in Canada, China and Japan. This is one of the top two of the four that I’ve seen. For many locals, it seems to be a desirable place for picnicking. The slightly chilly weather did not seem to bother any
Visited during cherry blossom season and was the best of all parks in Tokyo. Would visit again and was easy to get too

It is a beautiful park especially the Japanese style garden. Surrounded by the city but so quit and peaceful. A definite must see when in Tokyo
Somehow the size of the park feels like you walk into Central Park. There is an entrance fee of ¥500, you will easily able to spend 2 hours + there. Don't miss out!

Was taken there by my Japanese friend on my first day in Tokyo. Great experience. At the ticket booth we got a map of the area which was very useful. The garden is quite big with many different areas. There's even a greenhouse with many exotic plants.

Shinjuku gyoen is a park located in central Tokyo. During the sakura season it is crawded and plenty of people doing picnic under cherry trees( hanami). In other times it is calm and is very suitable to walk around and making sports.

Constructed on a grand scale, this garden has several distinct areas to enjoy. Good for a few hours and a nice little cafe/ restaurant for lunch. Some lovely magnolias in full flower now. A few early cherry trees in blossom, but the gardens will be magnificent in a week or two

Lovely gardens, great place to relax and enjoy nature. Large grated areas mixed with more formal gardens.
It is definitely comparable to the other well known parks such as Hyde in London, Central in New York, etc. it is very close to a subway station. We felt very comfortable walking in this park.

We spent nearly 3 hours today enjoying these lovely gardens and some early cherry blossoms. Very scenic and relaxing. It feels quite a bit like Central Park in New York City. Great spot for a picnic lunch too. The best part is the traditonal Japanese garden and Green house.
Even though there are plenty of parks scattered throughout Tokyo with similar scenery, it's nice to see a park that has enough room to lay on the grass and play, especially if you have a family.

Calm, soothing, spiritual vegans to describe the the gardens. Though crowded it lacked the hustle and bustle of stateside gardens. The early blooming of several cherry trees were the center of attention. My guide explained that soon all the cherry trees would be in bloom.

Easy to get to, centrally located, and exceptionally beautiful. What you will see depends upon the time of year that you visit, but regardless it is a beautiful oasis in the heart of an enormous metropolis. And entry is just $2. Don't miss it.

We visited the garden on a very cold and snowy February day. It was lovely. So many wonderful things to see. Entry is free. That have a great cafe and excellent toilet facilities - as most Japanese places do! Highly recommend it.

Concierge advised me to go and it was amazing more than what I expected it was breath taking a must to see in Tokyo ! Really enjoyed the walk and the park is sensational.. Guides are helpful take some food and drink to enjoy in the park.

A beautiful quiet place in the middle of a major city! It's out of season so the grass is brown and a lot of the trees are bare. However even with that it's worth a visit, also the botanical gardens! The best bit for me is the Sakura has started to bloom. The cost is only 200
A well kept enormous park. Costs 200¥ which is good value. Japanese garden was lovely but we didn't go early enough and you get asked to leave at 4.30pm.

Wonderful park!!! We went during winter, but still such a beautiful place. Just make sure to wear comfortable winter clothing. There are no indoor heated areas in the park. You will be outdoors the whole time. I would this this again!

Beautiful garden ii the middle of the city with lots of variety. Totally worth the entry fee. I spent a lot of time here, b/c there was so much to see.

A beautiful quiet haven in the heart of the city. The formal gardens are stunning and the park was full of local people enjoying the spring sunshine and early blossoms. From here it was an easy walk to Shinjuku or Harajuku - so great location too.
Absolutely beautiful gardens. Kept in pristine condition. So worth the very cheap entry fee, and a great way to escape the noise and the activity of downtown Tokyo!

This park is amazingly well kept and beautiful. This is an oasis in the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku. Amazing greenhouse and huge ponds to see all for a nominal fee.

Amazing garden in heart of Shinjuku - our favourite garden in all of Tokyo during our visit. Stunning.

Visited on a very rainy day but it didn't distract from the beauty and tranquility of the visit. The English landscape garden was a bit disappointing but thats the view of an English gardener.
Japanese garden, French garden, English garden. All beautifully presented, with space to lounge around as well. A lovely area to escape for an hour or two, whatever the weather.

Very beautiful. One for keeps! the most beautiful garden ive ever seen especially the japanese garden

It is about 10mins walk to Shinjuku station, south exit. Entrance fee: 300yen for adult and 100yen for children. There are many nice themed gardens inside. There is also a greenhouse to house mostly tropical plants and flowers.

near shinjuku stn, it a large park and you need to pay entrance fee. compare to some of the other paid park, i will recommended this. there some shop that sell food and drink within the park.

Loved this garden. 200 yen to visit but worth it. Garden and green house was very special to see. Relaxing to spend the afternoon walking around .

The gardens a well laid out and provide lovely walking routes. We went late on a Saturday afternoon and it was great to see so many local families enjoying an evening stroll. Well worth a visit at any time of the year

Large area which you can spend most of the day at. Lots of varied scenes to see. Lots of photo opportunities,
This place would be suitable for those who like to enjoy the nature in the middle of city and also a great place for some nature shots, especially good place for photographers.

I visited the garden just a day back. And during fall, you get to see the nature in its best colours, the garden is worth a visit if you have some leisure time. It is preferable to go early in the morning, the crowds are a bit less and you'll save time in the ticket lines.

Entry fee is ¥200 and it’s a short walk from Takashimaya (Shinjuku gate). There’s another 2 gates you can enter from. The gardens are big and divided to at least 4 smaller gardens/areas - traditional Japanese garden, English garden, French garden and the green house. This
Gorgeous and peaceful. Nature kept in its real form. Perfect We happened upon the flower festival and enjoyed the entire place. Once inside you forget you are in a city.
Amazing place in Tokyo! Relaxing and peaceful! Gardens are indeed interesting to see and a good spot for pics

Y'all, I just could not believe this place. One minute your being pushed through the crazy train station. I don't even know which way is up. These crazy people! Then, you pay $2 and your in a peaceful buddhist park. This city is so crazy!

We walked through these gardens late afternoon and loved the vast lawns and large trees and ponds. There were families sitting on the lawns enjoying the large spaces. There is a small fee to enter the gardens but well worth it.

A half hour walk away from Keio Plaza Hotel (where we stayed), this beautiful park was a delightful discovery. Serene, well maintained, and with wide walking/running paths, this is an oasis in the normally bustling Shinjuku business district.
Such a beautiful sight in Autumn, highly recommend to break away for some peace and quiet from the hustle and bustle.

Great for a long walk and to view the unique gardens and flowers. Truly enjoyable. You could spend hours here. Lots of people having a picnic, we didn’t do this, but I would recommend it if you have the time.

Great park in the middle of all the mayhem of Tokyo. Nice & peaceful, well kept. The glass house is pretty amazing.

Nice park right in the Shinjuku area. We took a lovely stroll through the garden, and it was wonderful to spend some time in nature amidst one of the great cities of the world.

Beautiful way to escape the neon madness just a short walk away. Well worth 200 yen, just to walk around in tranquility.
Stunning gardens, lovely glasshouse, serenity amidst the chaos of Shinjuku. Well worth a visit. Easy to access.
